question: An agile team member received certification on a new tool; however, this team member is complaining that the rest of the team is not using the tool due to lack of knowledge. How should the servant leader apply emotional intelligence to leverage this situation to benefit the project?
optionA: Request budget to reward the team member so others will be motivated to obtain the same certification.
optionB: Promote the team member to product owner to leverage the new knowledge with the clients.
optionC: Ask the team member to use their recently acquired knowledge to develop and provide training to the team.
optionD: Provide an incentive to team members who begin using the new tool on this project.

question: A project manager has been assigned to a project after the charter has been approved. While reviewing the charter with the team, the project manager finds that some major budget items, necessary for achieving the project outcome, have been missed. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Immediately discuss this with the project sponsor and request to revisit the budget to ensure its accuracy
optionB: Add the missing budget items to the risk log and present them in the next project steering committee
optionC: Start the project and deal with these budget issues as they arise throughout the project life cycle
optionD: Reduce the quality and cost of other deliverables to allow additional budget for the items that were missed

question: A project schedule risk has turned into an issue. The project manager foresees delays in project execution. What should the project manager do to resolve the issue?
optionA: Escalate the issue to senior leadership for resolution
optionB: Work with relevant stakeholders to determine possible solutions
optionC: Update the schedule baseline to the new project time line
optionD: Update the risk management plan and send it to the project team

question: A project manager is assigned to a project where a vendor has been engaged to build a new system. One week before user acceptance testing (UAT) is scheduled, the vendor informs the project manager that they can only deliver half of the promised functions by the UAT start date. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Communicate with the vendor and project team and explore possibilities for resolving the issue
optionB: Wait until the vendor cannot deliver and then invoke liquidated damages based on the contract
optionC: Escalate to management and prepare for project closure by canceling the contract with this vendor
optionD: Adjust the project schedule to accommodate the current development progress of the vendor

question: In a time-critical construction project, a misunderstanding occurred between the supervisor and the technician. The misunderstanding turned into a major conflict and the technician has complained to the project manager that they cannot continue to work under the supervisor any longer. The supervisor cites the technician's poor performance as the reason for the conflict. How should the project manager resolve the problem?
optionA: Use a direct, collaborative approach with the technician and supervisor
optionB: Provide a just-in-time training to the technician to improve their skill set
optionC: Replace the technician with a high performing resource as time is critical
optionD: Talk to the supervisor to tone down their approach and attitude

question: A project is comprised of team members who are not engaged and committed to project success. What should the project manager do to address this situation?
optionA: Contact the project sponsor to request approval to release the current team and hire replacement personnel
optionB: Call each team member to gain their perspective on the problem, then bring the whole team together to discuss a solution
optionC: Send each team member a direct email indicating that disciplinary action is likely if they do not change their attitude
optionD: Accept the situation knowing there is schedule slack available to release on an incremental basis when necessary

question: A project manager has been assigned a project to build a new solar farm that will provide clean energy to a new housing complex. The government has decided to reduce the tax on renewable energy products starting 1 January. The supplier has reached out and stated that the order placed for solar panels to be delivered on 20 December might be delayed until early January. On the other hand, the project will face similar constraints due to the December holidays. What should the project manager do about this risk?
optionA: Review the supplier's contract to understand the terms of sale
optionB: Insist that the supplier deliver the goods on the agreed date
optionC: Update the risk register and take advantage of the opportunity
optionD: Accept the risk and update the risk register

question: A project manager is assigned to manage a project for a previous client of the company. The project manager was warned that this client will likely try to add extra scope to the project without considering the impact of change on time, cost, quality, and risks. Which action should the project manager take to help plan and manage the budget and resources?
optionA: Refuse to allow the client to change the scope and examine the lessons learned register.
optionB: Decompose the deliverables into work packages and review the project charter.
optionC: Create tight scope statements and review the historical information.
optionD: Include a scope change process and review the project charter.

question: A project manager is managing a project with a hybrid approach and has requested a senior team member to perform a quantitative risk analysis. The team member responds that they do not have the knowledge to perform such an analysis. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Help the team member to perform the quantitative risk analysis through coaching, mentoring, and training
optionB: Escalate the issue to the functional manager
optionC: Perform the quantitative risk analysis for the team member
optionD: Contact the project management office (PMO) and request them to assign another team member who has the knowledge to perform this task to the team

question: A senior developer working on a large artificial intelligence (AI) project has worked hard and shown excellent results. The project manager is very happy with the developer's contribution and thinks that the developer deserves a reward. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Create an opportunity for the project team to recognize this developer
optionB: Print a recognition certificate and present it to the developer during a meeting
optionC: Send a recognition email to the team and copy management
optionD: Reward the developer according to their motivations and interests

question: A global program is being kicked off, and various distributed teams are involved in delivering the initiative. Besides planning and executing the scope for the initiative, team interactions must be considered. How should the project teams interact in their meetings?
optionA: Videoconferencing
optionB: Encrypted emails
optionC: Phone conversations
optionD: Chat conversations

question: A project manager is part of a global project team and is in charge of managing the scope defined by their country. There is a clear division regarding which pieces of the scope should be treated by global and local teams. During the last sprints, the project manager has been receiving requests that the global team should handle. What should the project manager do in this situation?
optionA: Assess the team's capacity to absorb the workload
optionB: Evaluate and understand the cause of the conflict
optionC: Escalate the situation to the project sponsor
optionD: Reject the workload back to the global team

question: A company is transitioning projects from a predictive to an agile approach. The CFO is concerned that one of the agile projects has an important feature for the financial department that is being delayed for a later iteration. What should the project manager do to clarify the situation?
optionA: Request support from the CEO on how to deal with the situation
optionB: Increase the size of the team in order to match any prior expectations of the CFO
optionC: Create an executive board to review the product backlog and replan the next iterations
optionD: Clarify with the CFO that the prioritization process is based on business value

question: A project manager for a technologically complex engagement reviews the key project indicators with the main stakeholders on a regular basis. During one of the meetings, the project sponsor explains that they are using the project manager's risk register as a way to communicate about the project at the executive level. How should the project manager ensure that project risks are reported accurately in the risk register?
optionA: Update the risks in the risk management plan
optionB: Review the risks throughout project execution
optionC: List the project risks identified in the kick-off meeting
optionD: Plan to update the risks at project closure

question: A project manager recently finished a project and started managing a new project with a different supervisor. As part of the early project activities, the supervisor from the original project is assigned to the team as a nonsupervisory resource and immediately begins challenging all decisions made by the current supervisor. What should the project manager do to resolve this conflict?
optionA: Ensure the new supervisor takes the lead when being challenged
optionB: Give the project team time to work through the issues with the new supervisor
optionC: Immediately remove the resource from the project team
optionD: Communicate with the resource on the roles and responsibilities of this project

question: A project manager sent the first communication about the project management plan to the team. The next day, two field engineers were asking about their roles and the project schedule. What should the project manager have done?
optionA: Sent the roles and responsibilities matrix along with the project management plan
optionB: Confirmed that the communication was understood and solicited feedback from the team
optionC: Briefed each team member on their roles before sending the project management plan
optionD: Discussed the roles with the managers to help explain them to their team members

question: A solution designer in an agile team often passes the design information to team members without any documentation. This has resulted in misunderstandings within the team. What should the agile leader do?
optionA: Move the solution designer to another team
optionB: Review the process that resulted in this situation
optionC: Ask the team to document the design
optionD: Stop work until the design document is completed

question: A software system is being built for a company. Once the system is in production, the team would like to collect usage data to evaluate the delivered value. Which evaluation practice should the project lead use to obtain accurate usage data?
optionA: Embed a feedback form into the system for users to respond
optionB: Build the functionality in the software to collect the operational usage data
optionC: Send out a questionnaire to all users regarding the most useful features
optionD: Interview a sampling of users to obtain the usage data

question: A software project using an agile approach is facing quality issues with every release, generating many production problems. What should the project manager do to fix the problem and improve the quality?
optionA: Use the retrospective meeting to better understand the root cause of the quality problems and put together a plan with the team to address the problems
optionB: Hire an external company to add an additional layer of testing, making sure that the final product is well inspected before releasing
optionC: Create a reward system granting incentives to the team members who are able to catch more defects
optionD: Seek extra funding approval with the sponsor to replace junior team members for more experienced ones

question: A project manager is managing a national rollout for an innovative product in a regulated environment that is expected to change. The project management office (PMO) needs visibility of the regulatory constraints while maintaining a degree of flexibility. Which tool can the project manager use?
optionA: Use a burndown chart to provide transparency
optionB: Use a burnup chart to provide transparency
optionC: Use a kanban board to increase accountability
optionD: Use a product backlog to manage changes

question: A project manager is managing a very important business transformation project. The goal of the project is to extend a desktop application with a mobile application module. The marketing department believes that a main competitor is working on a similar product. Which delivery approach should the project manager use for this project?
optionA: Extreme Programming (XP) delivery, to mitigate the high risk related to a new product
optionB: Traditional delivery, to ensure high quality and that the product meets market demands
optionC: Incremental delivery, to ensure that mobile capability is released fast to the users
optionD: Iterative delivery, to ensure that user feedback is incorporated into the second iteration

question: During the implementation phase of a construction project, a key supplier went bankrupt and cannot supply the contracted material. This issue could affect the project schedule. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Escalate to the management team for delay approval
optionB: Add the risk and the delay to the risk register
optionC: Update the schedule to include the delay
optionD: Update the issue log and act to minimize the impact

question: A project manager for a factory construction project in a small town is evaluating the necessary actions to engage stakeholders. The local community is speculating the impact of the facility. There are rumors of job opportunities and environmental impacts, which are listed on the project risk matrix. What should the project manager do with regard to community engagement in this situation?
optionA: Build channels to extend communication efforts to the local community.
optionB: Focus on the sideward stakeholders only and let the organization manage the community.
optionC: Use the city administration to address communication with the community.
optionD: Include the local union representative in the high-power, high-impact stakeholder group.

question: A project manager was replaced in the early phases of a new project. The new project manager discovers that the business team is not supporting the project. After discussing these concerns with the team, it is determined that the project does not have the full support of senior management. What should the new project manager do next?
optionA: Request the business team to clearly define their issues with the project work completed to date.
optionB: Send out a status report describing the situation to the stakeholders and request general assistance.
optionC: Study the stakeholder analysis to understand which stakeholder holds the most influence and seek their assistance.
optionD: Ask senior management to be more involved with the project and to provide their full support.

question: A company has rolled out the latest retail management system, and the project has been handed over to operations. The operations team finds that many of the day-to-day requirements are not covered in the system, and support for the project has limited hours. The project team has dissolved and the contract resources are no longer working on the project. As a result, the operations team has been facing numerous customer issues. What should the project lead have done initially to avoid this situation?
optionA: Involved operations stakeholders during planning
optionB: Reviewed the project management plan
optionC: Increased support hours for the hours of operation
optionD: Created a detailed operations manual

question: A project team is transitioning from a predictive to an agile approach. The project manager is trying to minimize the support issues that the product has had in production. One particular pain point is the transition to operations, where the issues usually arise. What should the project manager do to improve this scenario?
optionA: Engage the operation teams in the retrospectives and demo sessions and incorporate their feedback on project activities
optionB: Increase the focus on backlog items that cover support requirements, as well as product manuals and operation guides
optionC: Foster stakeholder participation by engaging them early on the backlog discussions
optionD: Ask the support/operation team to participate in the daily standup meetings to contribute to the project's progress

question: After signing an agreement with a vendor, the project manager notices that the vendor is continuously asking for changes on the procurement statement of work (SOW). These changes would improve the project outcome. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Consult the list of selected vendors for the bid and evaluate a possible change of vendor.
optionB: Revise the procurement control process to avoid undesired changes that might affect the schedule.
optionC: Assess the situation as an opportunity for improvement and perform a risk analysis.
optionD: Conduct an audit on the procurement process and inform the vendor about the audit's observations.

question: A project manager is performing earned value management (EVM) for a cross-country pipeline project. The project manager has determined the ratio of earned value (EV) to actual cost (AC) for the project and has found the calculated result to be 0.9024. What does this value mean for the project?
optionA: The project is earning less value than was planned
optionB: The project has started exceeding the planned cost
optionC: The project has earned more value than planned
optionD: The project is close to exceeding the planned cost

question: A customer complains that the user stories released so far contain too much jargon and do not reflect the expectations of the product. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Rewrite the stories to include the technical vision of the product
optionB: Ask the senior developer to rewrite all the stories
optionC: Engage with the customer and rewrite all the stories
optionD: Request approval from the company director to conduct training for the team

question: An unforeseen event has shut down public works projects for 4 weeks. Activities on the critical path will fall behind based on the project schedule. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Add 4 additional weeks to the schedule and request additional resources.
optionB: Ask the sponsor to obtain a special work permit to continue work.
optionC: Crash the resource management plan to keep the schedule on track.
optionD: Review the project management plan to see the impact of the possible delay.

question: During a regular project progress meeting, the CEO informed the project manager that a major stakeholder has been unaware of recent developments on the project. The project manager is sure that the stakeholder was duly identified and classified in the stakeholder register. Which project document should the project manager review in order to determine the reason for this issue?
optionA: Requirements traceability matrix
optionB: Issue log
optionC: Stakeholder register
optionD: Stakeholder engagement assessment matrix

question: A healthcare organization hired a new compliance specialist to ensure that the healthcare compliance needs are met. The feedback about the new compliance specialist from the team was average. What should the project manager do to help the new compliance specialist improve?
optionA: Coordinate a one-to-one meeting with the specialist to assess the situation
optionB: Escalate this situation to the manager of the area for a possible solution
optionC: Provide time for the specialist to adjust to the pace of the project
optionD: Contact the human resources (HR) manager about the team's feedback

question: A company has selected a cross-functional team to develop an innovative digital product to drive the digital transformation project for the business. What should the project manager do to ensure business value is delivered early?
optionA: Create robust incentives to the team members to encourage speedy delivery
optionB: Create a detailed project plan and escalate delays to the functional managers
optionC: Break down the deliverables into sprints and deliver value incrementally
optionD: Fast track the project and monitor tasks closely to ensure timely delivery

question: A company that uses a predictive approach and operates in a highly regulated market is losing profitability because its product life cycle is taking longer than those of its competitors. A new project manager has been hired to change this scenario. What approach should the project manager propose?
optionA: Migrate to an agile model, focusing primarily on an iterative approach, leaving the incremental life cycle as a next step
optionB: Change to an agile model, focusing primarily on the incremental life cycle, leaving the iterative approach as a next step
optionC: Maintain a predictive approach, but increase the focus on better planning and tracking to anticipate problems and avoid delays
optionD: Propose a hybrid approach, leveraging the benefits of an agile approach while respecting some aspects of the company's industry

question: A company is using an agile approach to launch a new product. In the second sprint, the team encounters a technical problem they have never faced before. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Organize an early retrospective with the team to analyze the problem
optionB: Ask the product owner to write the specifications for the related user story
optionC: Facilitate a problem-solving session with the team to analyze the problem
optionD: Inform the project sponsor about the problem faced by the team

question: A project manager assigned team members to work in pairs on a large amount of technical reports. At times, the project manager noticed that important information was not shared properly among the team. This has caused delivery delays and, ultimately, the failure to complete the project. What is the root cause of this issue?
optionA: Incorrect communication techniques applied during implementation
optionB: Lack of team member training on documentation planning
optionC: Improper assignment of tasks to team member pairings
optionD: Team cohesiveness was lost because team members worked in pairs

question: A key stakeholder has recently started in a company and has been assigned to a hybrid project. Although very experienced in their domain, the stakeholder has only been exposed to predictive project approaches. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Inform the project management office (PMO) that the team will use a predictive approach for this project
optionB: Inform the stakeholder that they must level their knowledge with other stakeholders
optionC: Allocate time to mentor the stakeholder in the selected project approach
optionD: Update the risk register with the potential impact and apprise the steering committee

question: A senior manager attends one of the project review meetings and expresses concern that the project will not meet the quality standards. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the senior manager to approve the user acceptance testing (UAT) plan
optionB: Inform the senior manager that there are approved quality standards
optionC: Review the quality management plan with the senior manager
optionD: Estimate the backlog items to forecast quality

question: Two team members were recently released from a project because the customer reduced the budget. However, the agile team is still receiving the same, if not more, work requirements as before. How should the agile project leader resolve this situation?
optionA: Update the project budget with the released team members.
optionB: Update the restriction log with the new team capacity.
optionC: Explain the new project requirements to the team.
optionD: Explain the new team velocity to the customer.

question: An IT project manager for a project that is 50% complete learns that a critical team member plans to relocate to another country soon. The team member is needed for the remainder of the project. How should the project manager improve team dynamics?
optionA: Require that all team members be physically present for the weekly project review
optionB: Offer the team member an incentive to stay until the end of the project
optionC: Replace the team member with someone who has similar qualifications and is located closer
optionD: Set up a weekly video conference to monitor the progress of the team member's work

question: A product development team has team members located in four different countries. A senior manager is assigned the task of recruiting a project manager to manage this project and the virtual team. Which skill is required for a project manager to successfully manage this team?
optionA: Possesses strong interpersonal skills to drive high-performing virtual teams
optionB: Plans and controls every aspect of the team's deliverables to avoid surprises
optionC: Speaks several languages and has lived in different countries
optionD: Implements the organization's standards and processes for the project

question: A senior project manager is working for a company that is not yet making a profit. However, the company has many innovative projects in development. Most of the project time lines have slipped, and the staff is overwhelmed. What should the project manager do to help the company meet their financial objectives?
optionA: Prioritize the projects, giving higher priority to projects that will increase profit
optionB: Ensure that all of the projects are of high quality and are delivered on time
optionC: Request that upper management hire additional staff to support the projects
optionD: Make sure the project is fast tracked so that slipped time lines are recovered

question: A project manager is assigned to a building construction project. The project manager has taken an agile course and wants to use agile practices in the project. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Choose the agile practices that can be implemented in this type of construction project and apply them
optionB: Hire a consultant to provide a second opinion about whether agile can be applied to a construction project
optionC: Review the stages of the project to allocate additional budget for agile resources
optionD: Assign a scrum master to the project to implement agile practices in the project

question: During project execution, a global project team was using a video conferencing tool to support the daily meetings. However, during these meetings, only a few team members were actively participating. As a result, lots of misunderstandings occurred. What should the project manager do to address this issue?
optionA: Check the ground rules of the meeting to review the initial agreement with the team members
optionB: Use round-robin check-ins to facilitate the meeting, so all participants have the opportunity to speak
optionC: Book one-on-one meetings with the team members who are not speaking up during the daily meetings to get their updates
optionD: Identify one team representative to speak up during the daily meeting and share the team updates

question: A company has a transformation project in progress. During a planning session, several stakeholders are in constant disagreement and often use personal arguments to support their position. Team members are getting frustrated with the situation. What should the project manager have done to avoid this situation?
optionA: Established ground rules before the discussion had started
optionB: Reinforced that higher-level management has the decision power
optionC: Invited a high-level sponsor to the meeting to reduce the level of disagreement
optionD: Asked stakeholders not to voice their opinions during the meeting

question: While monitoring a project at a work site, the project manager notices that the site team's work breaks have increased by a few minutes every week. How should the project manager approach this?
optionA: Dismiss some of the workers for failing to adhere to the break policy
optionB: Issue a formal written warning to all hourly workers for their break tardiness
optionC: Have a meeting with the team to discuss the issue and propose solutions
optionD: Reduce payment to the workers due to their extended breaks

question: A project manager is working on a construction project. The company owner asks the project manager to provide cost estimates for the new decoration project within 4 hours. How will the project manager be able to complete this task?
optionA: Call a meeting with the project team to identify the most appropriate approach
optionB: Tell the owner that a rough order of magnitude will be provided
optionC: Contact a subject matter expert (SME) for advice and consultation
optionD: Tell the owner that the task requires more time and expertise

question: A project is approaching successful completion, and all stakeholders are really proud of the achieved results. The project management office (PMO) recommends the project manager to lead the next similar project. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Engage key stakeholders to complete and deliver lessons learned.
optionB: Select the same stakeholders for the next project to avoid doing knowledge transfer.
optionC: Present the project achievements and delegate knowledge transfer to the steering committee.
optionD: Request the PMO to manage the lessons learned repository.

question: In order to increase a project's profit margin, the project manager and subject matter experts (SMEs) agreed to select the oldest model of a specific machine available in the market. When the machine reached its destination country, it was blocked by customs authorities who restricted the import of this machine model. What should the project manager have done to prevent this from happening?
optionA: Ensured that the SMEs correctly defined the project scope and the machine model.
optionB: Ensured the project sponsor provided enough funding to purchase the latest version of the machine.
optionC: Ensured that regulatory compliance was considered in the quality management plan.
optionD: Ensured that the technical team researched and selected the latest model of the machine.

question: A project is behind schedule because of a delayed equipment installation. This is affecting many other activities. The manager responsible for the equipment delivery notified the project manager that there is a capacity issue for the team doing the installation. What should the project manager have done to prevent this situation from happening?
optionA: Defined the skill requirements more clearly in the scope statement.
optionB: Asked the manager to follow the agreed-upon resource management plan.
optionC: Conducted periodic reviews with the manager on resource availability.
optionD: Consulted with the installation team on a regular basis to check for conflicts.

question: The scope of a project is to replace the street signs within a 10-km radius. The client does not want to sign the project closure report if the radius is not extended by 1 km, to be aligned with the council's development plan. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Delay the approval and ask the project sponsor for additional funding.
optionB: Contact the council and ask for their approval to extend the scope of the project.
optionC: Initiate a new project and discuss the request because it came in too late.
optionD: Obtain formal acceptance for the completed work and submit a change request.

question: A company has started developing a new product. During execution the project team notices that another competitor has launched a product with very similar functionalities and a cheaper market price. What should have been done differently to avoid this scenario?
optionA: A minimum viable product (MVP) should have been released to get feedback from the market.
optionB: More backlog refinement meetings should have been scheduled.
optionC: The Kanban method should have been utilized to optimize the work in progress (WIP).
optionD: An iterative life cycle approach should have been adopted.

question: An organization is about to start a multiphased project. Due to strict regulations, some of the phases must be completely planned in advance. However, other phases allow for more flexibility and experimentation on scope and schedule. The sponsor wants to pursue the project objectives as planned, but also wants to accommodate new information and changes as the project progresses. Which project management approach should the project manager select for this project?
optionA: Hybrid
optionB: Incremental
optionC: Agile
optionD: Phased

question: A project manager is leading an innovation project that is facing a lot of risks due to a high level of uncertainty. What strategy should the project manager use to manage these risks using an agile approach?
optionA: Develop an agile risk matrix to track, assess, and evaluate the uncertainty of the project.
optionB: Implement a scrum risk retrospective to analyze the risks at the end of the project.
optionC: Assign an agile risk manager to better understand and track the project risks.
optionD: Evaluate the risks constantly and reprioritize work as the project progresses.

question: A laboratory is launching a new product, defined to be executed in eight iterations with a fixed release date. At the beginning of the second iteration, the project manager realizes that a significant regulatory feature is missing in the project backlog. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the product owner to add the missing feature in the backlog.
optionB: Invite stakeholders to discuss the impact of adding the regulatory feature.
optionC: Estimate the related cost and ask for a project extension.
optionD: Increase the capacity of the team to include the missed feature.

question: A senior vice president requested the creation of more agile teams to run projects of varying lengths and complexities in parallel with each other. This will impact the amount of time the project managers will be able to dedicate to each project. The project managers typically dedicate 50% of their time to projects regardless of their complexity. What should the project manager do as a servant leader to help achieve this transformation?
optionA: Review the organizational process assets (OPAs) to evaluate mitigation plans for similar risks.
optionB: Create a risk entry regarding the project manager's capacity and develop a mitigation plan.
optionC: Empower the team to develop the necessary skills to move the project forward independently.
optionD: Issue a change request to hire additional project managers based on the increased workload.

question: A project manager is in a cross-functional agile team. The project manager has been assigned a software project with multiple features that will take the team about a year to complete. The CEO is insisting that the solution needs to meet business goals for the year end, which is due in 6 months. What should the project manager do to align stakeholders' needs and expectations?
optionA: Work with the stakeholders to create a prioritized backlog and release a roadmap.
optionB: Modify the requirements to those that can be completed in 6 months.
optionC: Implement fast-tracking and crashing activities to complete the project in 6 months.
optionD: Include all stakeholders in daily scrum meetings to keep them informed.

question: A project manager is managing a project to deploy new software to 200 end users. During the implementation, there is a missed process that caused some of the users to lose their computer data. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Meet with the team to discuss the root cause and encourage the team to take note of it and continue to focus on the deployment.
optionB: Record this case until the final lessons learned session is complete to prevent impacting the team's morale during implementation.
optionC: Meet with the team members and request they conduct a review of the case by providing feedback as lessons learned.
optionD: Invite a consultant to review the process in order not to repeat the same issue and share the results with the team.

question: A project manager is assigned to a major construction project. The project is critical to the city's population, and especially to the local government official who committed to delivering the project on time as an election promise. A new project sponsor has been assigned and wants to include aspects that the previous project sponsor did not support. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Meet with the new project sponsor to review the current project scope and the requested changes.
optionB: Rebaseline the project as there is now a new project sponsor, which is presenting an opportunity to review and recalibrate the project objectives.
optionC: Invite the project sponsor to a briefing with the project team to demonstrate progress and seek further support to meet project-committed deliverables.
optionD: Inform the new project sponsor that the new aspects will not be included in this project.

question: In an agile team, some of the team members are coming forward to ask for more autonomy on the project. What should the project manager do in this situation?
optionA: Encourage the team lead to make decisions.
optionB: Encourage the team members to make decisions.
optionC: Discourage them as conflicts may be created.
optionD: Discourage this request, as it is for the management team.

question: A project had scheduling delays, which necessitated the team to work overtime to meet critical milestones. This led to some misunderstandings among team members. The project sponsor has allocated a monetary award. How should the project manager utilize the award?
optionA: Meet with the team members and ask them how to spend the reward.
optionB: Arrange a luncheon for all team members and include team-building sessions.
optionC: Draft a points system to allocate a portion of the money for each resource.
optionD: Allocate the reward to the team leaders to spend on the team as they see fit.

question: A company is conducting a digital transformation project that has a hard deadline. The marketing team wants to combine this implementation with a new product, and the newly assigned project manager is not aware of all the dependencies. Using a hybrid approach, what should the project manager do to ensure the dependencies are taken into consideration?
optionA: Implement a project newsletter so the different team members can be informed about the progress of each project.
optionB: Make sure that each individual project schedule is aligned with the common deadlines.
optionC: Combine all of the small projects into one big project so the team can collaborate better as one big team.
optionD: Facilitate communication promoting a Scrum of Scrums so the different teams are aware of the dependencies and progress.

question: During an agile project, a project manager lost one of the resources, and at the same time, uncovered new requirements, which were added to the backlog. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Reevaluate the backlog priority with the product owner since the velocity has been impacted.
optionB: Reevaluate the scope of the current iteration to keep the same velocity and timeline.
optionC: Reevaluate the velocity as the iteration duration will be impacted by new requirements.
optionD: Reevaluate the project schedule as the velocity will be impacted by the loss of resources.

question: An agile project will be delivered to a client based on a fixed price in cryptocurrency. Due to the volatility of cryptocurrency, both parties have agreed to adjust the scope to the value of the cryptocurrency at the end of every iteration and halt the project when the agreed price is reached. Which approach should be used in this situation?
optionA: A flow-based approach starting with the smallest stories.
optionB: An iterative approach starting with the highest value epic.
optionC: A predictive approach with short phases.
optionD: An incremental approach with a minimum viable product (MVP).

question: A project is about to start. The project manager has found that the client does not have an appropriate knowledge management system and does not have a requirement for it. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Provide just-in-time knowledge to the client, upon request.
optionB: Utilize the cloud wiki to collect the necessary knowledge.
optionC: Ask the team to collect the knowledge locally and share it at the end of the project.
optionD: Coordinate with the team and the project stakeholders to collect the knowledge.

question: A team has individual daily start times for each team member. Sometimes the overlap between team member working hours is short. During those times, the interactions and work as a team are reduced and ineffective. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Inform the team members who are joining late to join early and work together.
optionB: Allocate the overlap time for each team member and ask them to adhere to the schedule.
optionC: Ask the team to define a team charter and agree on core working hours.
optionD: Ask the team to start at the same time to obtain the maximum number of team working hours.

question: A project team consisting of various professionals of different nationalities is struggling to achieve their project deliverables. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Provide the team with support to solve their own problems.
optionB: Inform the project sponsor and train the entire team.
optionC: Ask the human resources (HR) department to conduct performance training.
optionD: Ask the functional department manager to replace the team members.

question: An organization is struggling to start an important project. The project manager has identified that the scope definition is the main item preventing the project from starting. Although most of the scope items are defined and agreed upon among the stakeholders, there are a few items that are hard to grasp and very complex to define at this stage. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Propose that the well-defined scope items be delivered using a predictive approach and use an agile approach to deal with the complex items.
optionB: Maintain stakeholder momentum in working on the scope definition until a full detailed scope is achieved prior to starting the project.
optionC: Recommend splitting the project into two smaller projects in order to work exclusively in an agile environment without interference from a predictive approach.
optionD: Update the risk register and escalate the issue to the project management office (PMO), requesting more resources be added to help define the project scope.

question: A project is ending its fifth out of six iterations. During the iteration review, a customer adds a new regulatory feature that exceeds the capacity of the remaining iteration. What should the project lead do?
optionA: Register an issue and escalate it to the project sponsor.
optionB: Invite the stakeholders to discuss a new prioritization.
optionC: Estimate the impact and consult with the product owner.
optionD: Increase the team capacity to finish the project on time.

question: During the execution phase of a project, a new department has been created in the company. The manager of this department has requested to be involved in the regular project communications and reporting cycles. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the project team members to include the manager in all of their communications regarding this project.
optionB: Inform the manager that only stakeholders identified in the communications management plan should be involved.
optionC: Perform a stakeholder analysis and update the communications management plan to reflect the new situation.
optionD: Suggest the manager contact the steering committee and project management office (PMO) to be included.

question: Close to the end of a project, a customer claims that some deliverables have not been met and starts initiating change requests. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Refer to the requirements traceability matrix.
optionB: Escalate the change request to the project sponsor.
optionC: Revise the project scope baseline.
optionD: Review the approved project charter.

question: A project has met the agreed-upon product requirements and is closing. There is time remaining in the schedule and excess budget. The resources are not yet scheduled to move to other projects. Several product champions want to continue adding functionality to the product. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Use the remaining time and resources to add additional scope to the project without spending the project budget.
optionB: Ensure product quality by spending the remaining resources and time on additional quality checks for the product.
optionC: Acknowledge the project closure criteria has been met and release the remaining budget and resources.
optionD: Obtain approval from the sponsor to add additional functionality to the project deliverables with the leftover budget.

question: A company wants to be a pioneer in its industry and has announced the launch date of a new innovative product. After the first sprint planning, the team realizes that it is not possible to deliver all the features in the required time. What should the project manager do to ensure success?
optionA: Ask the customer to reduce the backlog to meet the launch date.
optionB: Increase the capacity of the team to deliver the completed backlog on time.
optionC: Assist the team in defining a minimum viable product (MVP) by the launch date.
optionD: Schedule a meeting with the stakeholders to review the contingency plan.

question: An agile project is running its third iteration with a duration of 2 weeks. A new operations director, who only has a predictive background, started working at the company. In the first meeting with the project manager, the director demands a weekly project status report. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Invite the director to attend the daily standup meetings.
optionB: Share this with the team and ask them to develop reports for the director.
optionC: Introduce the agile aspect to the director and agree on a solution.
optionD: Explain to the director that agile projects have live reports.

question: A company is working on a project to develop an integration of their existing systems. There are known issues in production. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Identify and remove impediments and mitigate the risks.
optionB: Ensure the product owner reviews requirements with the team.
optionC: Include acceptance criteria in the definition of done (DoD).
optionD: Review the quality control processes and procedures.

question: A company changed the product owner on an existing project. The new product owner has less knowledge of the product than everybody else on the team. Due to the product owner's lack of knowledge, the team does not consider the opinions of the product owner seriously and mostly relies on the project manager's opinion. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Work with the project management office (PMO) manager to generate an onboarding plan for the new product owner.
optionB: Schedule time to share insights with the new product owner about the product and project information.
optionC: Assume the role of the product owner while the product owner gets familiar with the product.
optionD: Organize a team-building activity and ask the team to respect the opinions of the new product owner.

question: A mid-size capital project has shared resources from the company's contract department. During the execution phase, the project team observed a delay in contracting. After communicating with the contract department, the project manager found the contract team is prioritizing other contracting jobs because they are not part of the project team. What should the project manager do first in this situation?
optionA: Report the issue to higher management and seek their direct involvement to complete the job from the contract department.
optionB: Arrange a meeting with the contract department to build trust and commitment by recognizing their critical support to the project.
optionC: Arrange several meetings with the contract department and ask them to contract the project as it is critical for project success.
optionD: Communicate with the contract manager to commit a budget for the resources required for project execution.

question: A team shared a complaint regarding the scrum master during the last sprint review. The team expressed that they were delayed because the scrum master did not remove impediments, such as scheduling some meetings with external teams and obtaining a room to work collaboratively, among other critical blockers. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Request an additional resource to assist in solving all of the impediments listed by the team.
optionB: Determine and agree when a situation becomes an impediment to be solved by the scrum master.
optionC: Request the team review and prioritize the open impediments to resolve all of them as soon as possible.
optionD: Push back, explaining that a self-organized team should address all of the problems to get the work done.

question: A project manager is leading a global project with resources spread out in different locations. The stakeholders have different interpretations of the requirements. The project manager is concerned about scope creep. Which action should the project manager take to control the scope?
optionA: Ensure that all key stakeholders agree to the project deliverables and there will be no need for changes.
optionB: Accept only those changes to requirements that provide additional value to the project.
optionC: Reject all changes that will increase the budget or increase the time line of the project.
optionD: Accept only those changes that are approved by the change control board (CCB) prior to being implemented.

question: During a kick-off meeting, the project manager notices that one of the stakeholders responsible for providing key information to the team has a low level of participation. This stakeholder believes that there will be no benefit from implementing the project. The project manager realizes that this could be a high risk for the project. Which action should the project manager take?
optionA: Facilitate a supportive level of engagement for this stakeholder.
optionB: Ask the project sponsor for advice as it might be possible to work with another stakeholder.
optionC: Perform a qualitative risk analysis using a probability and impact matrix.
optionD: Ensure the key information is accurate and monitor the situation as the project progresses.

question: A project manager is working on an agile project that is within the scope of a recently announced corporate audit. The project manager was appointed to attend the first meeting with the auditors scheduled for the following week. What should the project manager do to prepare for the audit?
optionA: Reserve story points for the next iteration if needed.
optionB: Review the project information.
optionC: Ask the development team to provide compliance information.
optionD: Ask for a waiver during the audit.

question: A development team is struggling to find design documentation for the upcoming sprint. Prior to leaving for vacation, the product owner communicated that the documentation had been uploaded to the project file repository. What should the project manager do to address this issue?
optionA: Assign a team member to manage project artifacts.
optionB: Audit the effectiveness of the management of project artifacts.
optionC: Improve email communication protocols to manage project artifacts.
optionD: Investigate new software tools used to manage project artifacts.

question: At a project meeting, a business analyst requires input from a marketing consultant to continue working on a task. The business analyst has tried to contact the consultant but has been told that the consultant does not have the time to discuss the project. What should the project manager do to move the project forward?
optionA: Escalate the issues about the consultant to the functional manager so the consultant dedicates the necessary time to the project.
optionB: Include a new project risk into the risk register and allocate the consultant as the risk owner as it is their responsibility to provide input.
optionC: Discuss the request with the consultant and set up time with the business analyst and consultant to discuss the project requirements.
optionD: Urge the business analyst to continue contacting the consultant to discuss the project since this is the responsibility of the business analyst.

question: A company is starting a critical project with a strict deadline. During the first planning meeting, the team realizes that the list of requirements has too many items to allow on-time delivery. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Update the risk register and present a contingency plan to meet the deadline.
optionB: Suggest to the customer to reduce the backlog to meet the date.
optionC: Increase the capacity of the team to finish the project on time.
optionD: Ask the team to propose a minimum viable product (MVP) to meet the date.

question: A project manager is working on a complex project with a high degree of change. What strategy should the project manager use to ensure a successful project completion?
optionA: Update the project management plan to reduce the possibility of scope creep.
optionB: Schedule a regular risk review with the project management team.
optionC: Increase the active engagement and participation of key stakeholders.
optionD: Create a project change roadmap to keep track of all unforeseen changes.

question: A project manager is leading a hybrid project funded by a time and materials (T&M) agreement. The project was completed, and the client accepted the delivery of the product. One week later, the client asked the project manager to fix two defects they found in the product. The project manager responded with an estimate of time and money and asked the client to confirm this. The client disagreed and insisted that the work should be done for free because it is a defect in the product. What should the project manager have done to prevent this?
optionA: Trained client engineers to support the product after its delivery.
optionB: Reviewed the project quality control plan with the client.
optionC: Suggested a fixed-cost basis and included free bug fixes for 1 month.
optionD: Planned how the delivered product will be supported after its delivery.

question: A project team has established contracts for purchasing vehicles and construction services. In the middle of project execution, the team learns that the vehicle supplier cannot deliver the vehicles. There is not enough time to find a new supplier without delaying the project. Which action should the project manager take to procure the vehicles?
optionA: Ask the technical team to revise the requirements, even if it requires extra budget.
optionB: Arrange a meeting with the client to request additional time to find a new supplier.
optionC: Review the existing service contracts to find an option to help procure the vehicles.
optionD: Procure the vehicles from another supplier and report the change to the change control board (CCB) later.

question: When a project is in its final stage, the project manager will request from the team to prepare a delivery acceptance document. What is the importance of this document to the project manager?
optionA: Needed to close the work breakdown structure (WBS).
optionB: Needed to share it with the stakeholders.
optionC: Needed to close out the project or a phase.
optionD: Needed to release the team at the end of the project.

question: A project manager is leading a project that has a dependency on the client's vendor management system for critical requirements. The vendor management team will not derive any benefits from the project. However, the project requires support from the vendor management head. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Get support from the sponsor to hire a subject matter expert (SME) from the vendor management team to work on the project.
optionB: Review the terms of reference of the steering committee to include the vendor management head.
optionC: Work with the sponsor on a communications management plan to obtain support from the vendor management head.
optionD: Obtain help from the sponsor to highlight any nonfinancial benefits for the vendor management team.

question: A subject matter expert (SME) external to the project team provides a suggestion that will save the project delivery time. This SME has available time to support the project, but was not planned to be involved in the current agile iteration. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Bring the SME on board immediately and discuss the implications later.
optionB: Ask the existing team members to collaborate with the SME and complete the activity.
optionC: Ask the SME to complete all of the necessary changes, which will save time.
optionD: Direct the team member to ignore the SME's changes as they were not planned.

question: During a project, the project manager finds an opportunity to reduce the project cost by completing a deliverable ahead of schedule with a minimal impact on project resources. However, the client has only been focused on the next milestone. How should the project manager approach this situation?
optionA: Apply additional resources to realize the early deliverable and ensure the next milestone is achieved.
optionB: Focus on the deliverable of the next project milestone as per the client's strict instructions.
optionC: Review the change management plan to discuss early benefits realization with the client.
optionD: Evaluate whether the client's request will add extra features to the project deliverable.

question: A healthcare company is in the process of deploying an innovative healthcare solution globally. The project team has completed a limited release. The stakeholders have raised concerns about global healthcare guidelines and risks. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Evaluate lessons learned from similar projects prior to deployment.
optionB: Perform a qualitative risk analysis on the identified project risks.
optionC: Review compliance and regulatory requirements with stakeholders.
optionD: Conduct a feasibility analysis of deploying the solution globally.

question: A project team is working on the design of a solution for a complex project. Due to a lack of clarity of the customer's requirements, daily meetings were agreed upon between the team and the customer. There are a few external contractors in the project who do not agree with this idea as they feel it is a waste of time. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Welcome and involve the contractors as part of the project team.
optionB: Ask the contractors to meet with the customer independently.
optionC: Ask the customer to develop a document with the requirements.
optionD: Warn and penalize the contractors who do not attend the meeting.

question: A project is ready to start, and resources are allocated. The development manager then informs the project manager that a critical resource is no longer available due to a family emergency. The development manager indicates that all other developers have been assigned to other projects, and there is no capacity for any developer to take on additional work. What should the project manager do next to fulfill this resource need?
optionA: Determine resource allocation options based on project priority.
optionB: Apply changes to the existing resource allocations and inform the development manager.
optionC: Meet with the sponsor to determine how to rebaseline the schedule.
optionD: Inform the sponsor of the situation and request an extension of the target completion date.

question: During the sprint planning of a project, the team members have a disagreement about the comparative size of the backlog items and if they would fit into the next sprint. Considering a hybrid approach, what should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask an external technical leader to provide input and plan the sprint.
optionB: Remove the items from the product backlog since the size couldn't be estimated.
optionC: Facilitate the discussion so that the team members can reach a consensus.
optionD: Make the decision about the backlog items based on what makes more sense.

question: An agile project manager notices that one of the team members is developing extensive knowledge in a specific matter. Other team members are likely to require this knowledge in the future. What should the agile project manager do?
optionA: Ask the team member to develop more expertise and become a subject matter expert (SME).
optionB: Ask the team member to provide a training session for the rest of the team.
optionC: Ask the team member to produce a lessons learned document and share it with the team.
optionD: Ask the team member to record highlights the team may want to know.

question: During daily team standup meetings, team members constantly ask about which tasks they should focus on first. How should the project manager ensure the team is fully productive?
optionA: Review the project backlog during the team's standup meeting.
optionB: Encourage project team members to prioritize the product backlog.
optionC: Ensure team members are working according to the project plan.
optionD: Work with the product owner to ensure the project backlog is prioritized.

question: A project manager is leading an automation project. The project team is colocated and includes people from both the technical and business units. The project manager discovers that personal differences and work styles are affecting the project negatively. How should the project manager address this?
optionA: Develop a schedule that ensures people with personal differences work separately.
optionB: Invite the functional managers of the different units to address their personal differences.
optionC: Use an approach to the project that does not involve colocation.
optionD: Meet with the team and agree on expectations from team members.

question: A facility extension project is in the execution stage. There is a project activity to connect the power of all new equipment to an existing facility, Point A, which requires a significant cable length. The construction team found that the power could be connected to Point B and save money. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Perform a cost-benefit analysis to evaluate using the Point B option.
optionB: Add the issue to the change log and request additional budget through the change control board (CCB).
optionC: Seek a decision from the construction team after explaining the project budget and schedule constraint.
optionD: Use the Point B option because it will save the project cost and time.

question: A project manager is working on multiple building construction projects using a predictive project management approach. Senior leadership within the organization is promoting the inclusion of more agile practices into the current project methodologies. The project sponsor now wants the projects to use more agile methodologies. Before mandating any agile methods to be used in a project, what should the project manager do first?
optionA: Provide agile training to those who will be part of the project team.
optionB: Shift all existing projects to agile methodologies with a strict timeline.
optionC: Pause the current projects to align them to the new agile cadence.
optionD: Assess the organizational culture and readiness for the transformation.

question: A local company is developing a new product and, for the first time, using a remote team for the programming tasks of features. The design for the product comes from the local team. During the third sprint review, the product owner has concerns about the project's outcomes. The remote development team is complaining that they do not clearly understand the requirements conveyed in the daily standup meetings. How should the project manager address this situation?
optionA: Determine the communication needs, environment, and tools to get the message across.
optionB: Document the risk in the risk management plan and use contingency reserves to hire a local vendor.
optionC: Evaluate and reassign the developing tasks to a local vendor who has worked on previous projects.
optionD: Review lessons learned from previous projects and organizational process assets (OPAs).

question: A project team created user stories after understanding the customer requirements. As the project progresses, the project manager observes that there are too many change requests. The team feels that the outcomes they are working on are not aligned with the customer requirements. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Refer to the configuration management knowledge base for similar projects delivered in the past.
optionB: Arrange for a workshop with the customer to understand the business values expected from the outcomes.
optionC: Include a representative from the customer to work collaboratively with the team.
optionD: Acknowledge that the current team needs improvement and hire more qualified team members.

question: A project manager is managing a project with team members who are working all over the globe. The project manager notices that each team member's deliverables do not meet the requirements. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Assemble the project team via conference call to tell them that disciplinary action will be taken if any more noncompliant deliverables are submitted.
optionB: Discuss the process used to create the noncompliant deliverables with the project team to see if there was a potential misunderstanding.
optionC: Schedule time with the project sponsor to inform them that the project schedule is slipping due to the time it will take to rework the deliverables.
optionD: Meet with the project team to explain that noncompliant deliverables must be reworked and submitted immediately to avoid project delays.

question: A project manager is leading a project to develop accounting software for a trading firm. As the outcomes are being delivered, a new risk is identified regarding an indirect tax regulation that is being changed by the government in the next 6 months. This risk will have a significant impact on the project outcomes. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Determine the impact of the risk and prioritize outcomes that do not affect the tax module.
optionB: Delay developing the indirect tax module until the tax regulation comes into effect.
optionC: Assess the impact of the risk with an expert and prioritize further outcomes with the client.
optionD: Analyze the impact of the risk and discuss with the team to determine how to separate the tax module.

question: An oil and gas project started without having acquired full funding for the project. The remaining funds were to be acquired during project execution. The acquisition of the remaining funds was delayed several months, resulting in a suspension of work by all contractors. What should the project manager have done to prevent this from happening?
optionA: Ensured the stakeholder anticipated obstacles to achieving financial closure on the remaining funds.
optionB: Ensured the risk was adequately assessed and mitigated by the appropriate stakeholders.
optionC: Ensured the stakeholder who was providing additional funds remained interested in the project.
optionD: Ensured the project team monitored and reviewed the project risk register periodically.

question: A project manager entered into a contract with a vendor to build a new system. During the acceptance test stage, the project manager noticed that the system quality was not satisfactory. How should the project manager support their claim to the vendor?
optionA: Provide the failed test results along with the agreed-upon acceptance criteria.
optionB: Share unsuccessful results from previous projects with a similar scope.
optionC: Document in the risk log that the issues in the system were already identified.
optionD: Show that the acceptance criteria were changed by the vendor without approval.

question: A project manager agreed to a team member's request to have an alternative working schedule whereby they begin working at 12:00 p.m. each day. This arrangement has worked well for the project, but has recently been scrutinized by members from other project teams because the company's core working hours begin at 9:00 a.m. What should the project manager have done to prevent this situation?
optionA: Broken down the situation to identify the root cause
optionB: Determined communication methods and channels
optionC: Analyzed the boundaries of the negotiations for agreement
optionD: Managed and rectified the ground rule violations

question: The project sponsor reports that a key stakeholder is complaining about performance differences in the metrics reported by the project manager, which gives the impression that the project is out of control. The project manager has been providing the project's status according to the agreed-upon communications management plan. This key stakeholder, however, seldom attends the status report meetings. What should the project manager do first to address this situation?
optionA: Evaluate the communication needs to discover the gaps and adjust the original plan if needed.
optionB: Use the contingency reserves to implement fast tracking and improve the schedule key performance indicators (KPIs).
optionC: Review the resource breakdown structure (RBS) to request the main stakeholder's manager to replace the stakeholder.
optionD: Provide evidence to the project sponsor that the project is on track and the communications have been sent.

question: A team has had issues with behavior on an ongoing project, which is causing conflicts. As a result, the team is losing momentum and falling behind in its sprints. How should the project manager handle this situation?
optionA: Engage a counselor to reconcile the situation between the team members affected.
optionB: Control backlog assignments and reduce direct communications between team members.
optionC: Revisit the ground rules and team communication protocols, and discuss what is happening.
optionD: Require team members experiencing the conflicts to take a day off from work.

question: The change control board (CCB) has approved a change request to add a new component within a product. The operations manager discovers the change after its approval and complains that the implementation of the change will cause significant disruption to the production line. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Formally acknowledge the operation manager's concerns and raise a new risk that the project may deliver late and over budget due to manufacturing difficulties.
optionB: Escalate the issue to the project sponsor, as the decision to add the component brings many benefits even though it will be disruptive to the production line.
optionC: Lead a root cause analysis workshop with the design team to identify the failures that led to the decision to add a component that was not compatible with the production line.
optionD: Meet with the operations manager to explain the background for the change and understand the operation manager's concerns about the change.

question: A project manager is leading a fast-moving project with strict deadlines and minimal time to deliver each milestone. The project manager discovers that one of the remote team members, who puts a lot of effort into delivering the project, has confided in an on-site team member. The remote team member feels they are not being adequately rewarded and recognized for their job. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Make arrangements with the resource's functional manager to relocate the team member to another existing project.
optionB: Send a copy of the engagement contract to the remote team member and indicate that the team member is entitled to what is included in the contract.
optionC: Inform the human resource (HR) manager of this situation and ensure this news does not spread.
optionD: Engage the remote team member, empathize with them, and let them know their contribution is appreciated regardless of their remote work status.

question: In a financial company, a strategic project has been planned to use a predictive approach. During project planning, the product leader requests that milestones be submitted for review. There is a defined scope and an established deadline to conclude the project. What should the project manager do first to meet the product leader's expectations?
optionA: Change the project charter to indicate that the approach will be different.
optionB: Inform the product leader that they must wait until the end of the project.
optionC: Meet with the software team to review the possibility of monthly milestone reviews.
optionD: Modify the project management plan to use an agile framework to incorporate milestones.

question: A project team is preparing a report for the stakeholders. The team gathers and collates a large amount of data to be included in the status report. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Ensure the team follows standard operating procedures (SOP) for creating a stakeholder report.
optionB: Instruct the team to make only a graphical representation of all the data for the report.
optionC: Instruct the team to conduct a meeting with the stakeholders before finalizing the report.
optionD: Instruct the team to analyze and interpret the data before including it in the report.

question: A project manager received a request to add features and functions to the project after the scope had already been established. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Follow the requirements management process.
optionB: Follow the stakeholder engagement process.
optionC: Follow the risk management process.
optionD: Follow the change management process.

question: A project manager has expertise in the technical domain. The project manager frequently demonstrates unacceptable behavior toward other team members; however, when confronted, the project manager denies this behavior. What is the reason for the project manager's behavior?
optionA: The project manager lacks necessary empathy.
optionB: The project manager lacks emotional intelligence (EI).
optionC: The project manager was not properly trained.
optionD: The project manager is in the wrong project role.

question: A project team member, who is inexperienced in system development work is not performing well. Currently, there are no other staff members available who are qualified to complete the work. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Assess the team member's development requirements and arrange for the team member to receive training.
optionB: Seek approval from the project sponsor to use some of the project budget reserve to hire a new resource.
optionC: Work with the functional manager to determine an incentive for the team member to complete the project.
optionD: Request a substitute for the team member with a new resource who is more skilled in system development work.

question: A newly commissioned project has had trouble recruiting team members because the turnover rate is high. The human resource (HR) manager has conducted several exit interviews. Many team members have expressed that the project manager has inadequate relationship management competencies. The project manager explains that the exiting team members were lazy. What should the project manager do to prevent this high turnover rate from continuing?
optionA: Avoid micromanaging the team, enforce stricter rules, and monitor employees.
optionB: Explain to the recruiting manager that a project is temporary in nature, making it different than an operational environment.
optionC: Develop relationship skills as a leader and also develop the teams' emotional intelligence skills.
optionD: Be more involved in the team member recruitment process to ensure qualified team members are chosen.

question: An enthusiastic, newly hired vice-president has been assigned as the product owner for a digital transformation project. The project manager advises the product owner that some of the functional requirements are not aligned with the chief information technology officer's (CTO) strategy. The product owner tells the project manager that the CTO is not part of the project and should not be engaged at this moment. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Advise the CTO about the possible impacts caused by the project.
optionB: Influence the product owner to review the engagement needed from other stakeholders.
optionC: Continue building the backlog since they are functional requirements.
optionD: Review the organizational process assets (OPAs) for historical information from similar projects.

question: A startup company has just appointed a CEO that has no prior project experience. The CEO wants to execute projects with their own resources and has appointed a project manager. What should the project manager recommend that the CEO do first?
optionA: Create a framework to justify project execution.
optionB: Utilize an agile approach for all upcoming projects.
optionC: Create a framework to support project success.
optionD: Utilize a predictive approach for all upcoming projects.

question: A project team was hired to perform on-site duties, but there were unexpected circumstances that required the entire team to work remotely. Some team members returned to their hometowns, and they are now requesting reimbursement for operational expenditures. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Review the budget and allocate funds for the reimbursements.
optionB: Update the project management plan with the incurred costs.
optionC: Ask the team members to draft a justification before processing the reimbursements.
optionD: Follow the Perform Integrated Change Control process and submit a change request.

question: An organization is adopting an agile mindset. On the first agile project, the project manager faced an issue because the team was unable to make decisions on time. What should the project manager do to address the problem?
optionA: Assess the situation to understand how the organization's culture impacts the decision-making process, and coach the team toward a new model.
optionB: Adopt an autocratic leadership style and dictate all decisions in order to speed up the team's velocity.
optionC: Invite senior leadership to a team-building workshop and restate the importance of accountability and leadership under the new company direction.
