optionA: Create the requirements management plan to outline how project requirements will be collected, analyzed, and documented, and then assign requirements to team members.
optionB: Work with the team to decompose the scope into a WBS and work packages in order to create required deliverables and timelines.
optionC: Start working on the project management plan with work packages, a detailed schedule, and work assignments for team members.
optionD: Work directly with stakeholders on the work breakdown structure (WBS) and assign tasks with a required timeline for each team member to start the work.

question: After a project has been approved, a key stakeholder tells the project manager that the current project management strategy is not well defined. The project manager is also informed that the key stakeholder does not want to hold a working session. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Share the project documents and invite the key stakeholder to discuss any concerns.
optionB: Invite the key stakeholder to the project's change control board (CCB) to discuss adjustment of the project strategy.
optionC: Ask the project sponsor to exert authority on the key stakeholder in order to maintain the approved timeline.
optionD: Proceed with a working session for teams that do not belong to that key stakeholder.

question: A senior business stakeholder with many years of experience is pressuring an agile team to deliver most of the promised functionality to the customer 18 months in the future as opposed to multiple, incremental deliveries over the course of the 18 months. What should the project lead do next?
optionA: Work with the agile team to schedule the incremental deliveries to enable delivery of business value sooner to the customer.
optionB: Work with the stakeholder to understand what the concerns are while, at the same time, conveying the benefits of incremental deliveries.
optionC: Schedule meetings with the customer to determine their ability to support multiple incremental deliveries.
optionD: Provide details of the concern to the agile team and adjust their goals and release plans to conform to the stakeholder's request.

question: A new project manager is assigned to lead an agile project. The project manager wants to use motivation to encourage the team to perform well throughout the project. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Implement a reward system aimed to keep the team engaged and motivated.
optionB: Find another method to increase the team's performance.
optionC: Use the management reserves to fund some team-building activities.
optionD: Inflate project estimates to provide a financial buffer for team activities.

question: A project manager is leading a project that is in an advanced stage. All high-level risks identified in the risk management plan have been resolved or are no longer a risk for the project. Only low-level risks remain. What should the project manager do now?
optionA: Reclassify low-level risks as high-level risks.
optionB: Notify stakeholders that all high-level risks have been resolved.
optionC: Reduce the priority of project risks as all remaining risks are low-level.
optionD: Reevaluate identified risks and update the risk register.

question: A project manager is managing a hybrid project. After attending an iteration review, a stakeholder tells the project manager that they are very busy and asks why these reviews are held so frequently. How should the project manager respond?
optionA: Record the issue in the issue log and escalate the conflict to the project sponsor for assistance.
optionB: Explain to the stakeholder that the stakeholder engagement plan requires their attendance at all reviews.
optionC: Discuss with the stakeholder the benefits of the hybrid project and how frequent reviews lead to greater value and less rework.
optionD: Negotiate a reduced review attendance with the stakeholder and update the stakeholder engagement plan to reflect this reduced attendance.

question: The product team is progressing with a prototyping approach to deliver a multiyear business initiative. A few user stories are taking longer to be delivered. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Determine the risks and identify a resolution during the retrospective meeting.
optionB: Inform stakeholders about the delay during project updates.
optionC: Discover the gaps in the communications management plan and address them accordingly.
optionD: Determine cross-dependencies and plan a spike in the next sprint.

question: A project manager has been managing a project for several months when an issue that had not been registered as a risk appeared. This issue may have a big impact on the project. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Avoid managing the issue as it was not registered as a risk for the project and there is no planned response to it.
optionB: Hold a meeting with the project team and relevant stakeholders to agree on the best way to manage the issue.
optionC: Delay the project until the issue is addressed and no longer presents as a risk to the project.
optionD: Inform the sponsor that the issue has arisen and that the project's success may be uncertain.

question: A research and development team is finishing up a two year initiative. The project manager is focused on the closing activities for the project. Which activity should be considered as a priority?
optionA: Release the resources and plan for a project completion celebration.
optionB: Ensure that knowledge transfer activities are executed as planned.
optionC: Hold a steering committee meeting to inform them of the project completion.
optionD: Mark the product backlog completion status and update the communications management plan.

question: An agile project team is looking to develop quality standards for a project. How should the project manager coach the team?
optionA: Determine the tools and techniques suitable for the project and ensure that testing is done early and continuously.
optionB: Ensure that the definition of done (DoD) is provided when the product owner agrees that all acceptance criteria have been met for the user story.
optionC: Insist that test-driven development is implemented along with the automated testing.
optionD: Inform the team that user acceptance testing is required to ensure that the product owner accepts the solution.

question: Due to delays on some activities, one of the project team members has increased the scope without any approval. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Remove the changes to match the original requirements.
optionB: Add team members to the project to avoid more schedule delays.
optionC: Update project documentation with the new scope.
optionD: Evaluate the impacts of the changes that were made to the project.

question: A retail chain is evaluating a project to replace payment systems across all its stores in multiple locations. The project does not pass the financial threshold but is also expected to increase market share, improve customer services, and retain more customers. The project is planned as a phased implementation, building on learning from the retrospectives during each phase. How should the business increase the value of the project?
optionA: Ask the benefits owner to reassess the identified risks that are impacting the outcomes of the financial benefits.
optionB: Use a fishbone diagram to find the root cause of the lower financial benefits with the benefits owner.
optionC: Consult with experts on methods to reduce costs and increase the financial value of the project.
optionD: Quantify the expected tangible and intangible benefits in the benefits management plan for each phase.

question: During the implementation phase of a construction project, the customer asked a key subcontractor to deliver a work package ahead of time. The subcontractor was not prepared for it and asked the project manager for additional budget. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Update the risk register and project log, and manage the budget closely.
optionB: Revise the project scope accordingly to cope with the budget changes.
optionC: Submit a change request to accelerate the project as requested.
optionD: Ask upper management for more funds, and update the project budget.

question: An agile project is running activities to define the minimum viable product (MVP). During the session, the project manager identifies some mandatory regulations, but there is no consensus to include these regulations in the MVP because it may extend the duration of the project. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the project sponsor to add more time to the project.
optionB: Get commitment from the team to include all of the required regulations.
optionC: Share with the participants the need to focus only on product functionality.
optionD: Train the team on the new regulations as requested by management.

question: A project manager is responsible for building a bridge. The high-level elements of the project are handled using a predictive approach. The software responsible for retracting the bridge has been developed based on agile principles. During software development, the workflow is often interrupted by various delays or impediments due to lack of information. How should the project manager handle this situation?
optionA: Increase retrospectives to deliver results fast.
optionB: Make work visible using Kanban boards.
optionC: Incorporate small batches of work into the project.
optionD: Apply lean manufacturing to limit the team's work.

question: A project manager who is new to an organization observes that an approaching deadline is likely to be missed because there have been some delays on the project due to a lack of resources. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Review the risk management plan to identify the response strategy.
optionB: Escalate the issue to the sponsor and debrief them about the situation.
optionC: Review the milestone list to determine which tasks can be fast-tracked.
optionD: Organize a team meeting to discuss the next course of action.

question: A project manager is tracking a project, but a key stakeholder will not accept the project's key performance indicator (KPI) results. Which tool or technique should the project manager use?
optionA: Change control tools
optionB: Expert judgment
optionC: Autocratic decision making
optionD: Context diagram

question: An agile team has been struggling to keep up with the planned pace, which is frequently resulting in sprint failures. What should the project manager do to help avoid this situation in the future?
optionA: Switch to a Kanban approach, implementing features on a first-come, first-serve basis, fostering a sustainable pace.
optionB: Replace junior team members with more experienced ones, and negotiate the project scope to compensate for the budget gap.
optionC: Ask the project sponsor to approve overtime to compensate for the lack of performance while adjusting the plan.
optionD: Review the velocity of the team over the last several sprints and adjust the plan accordingly.

question: A project manager is managing a complex research project with a high level of uncertainty. A request is made to implement a mechanism to measure the quality of the deliverables. Using a hybrid approach, what techniques can be used to achieve this goal?
optionA: Scrum master reviews and the quality Kanban method.
optionB: Daily Scrum and product owner quality assessments.
optionC: Paired work and the customer role method.
optionD: Time-boxed iterations and standup review meetings.

question: A new project manager learns the work assigned to the team has already been decomposed to its lowest level. The project manager reviews the work and feels some additional, useful information is missing. What should the project manager review?
optionA: The WBS dictionary
optionB: The requirements traceability matrix
optionC: The project charter and scope statement
optionD: The business requirement documents (BRD)

question: The programming activities of a project were planned to last 35 days per module, but the programming of the first module has taken 45 days. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Evaluate the situation and identify ways to compress the schedule without impacting baselines.
optionB: Ask the team to work overtime to complete the deliverable on time.
optionC: Submit a change request to the project sponsor to change the schedule.
optionD: Check the scope to verify if there is scope creep and get the project on schedule.

question: The marketing team is transitioning to using hybrid approaches for their projects. The marketing director is not knowledgeable about hybrid methodologies, and the project manager needs the director's support as the marketing director is a key stakeholder. What should the project manager do to obtain the support?
optionA: Train the marketing team and keep the director informed.
optionB: Mentor the marketing director on hybrid approaches.
optionC: Ask the marketing team members to coach the director.
optionD: Ask the marketing director to participate in daily meetings.

question: A project manager is appointed to simultaneously deploy a new solution to branches located in different countries. Deployment teams in each country will integrate and deploy the solution. The project manager discovers that the deployment teams each encounter similar issues. However, each team addresses the issues separately. What should the project manager do to help ensure more collaboration between the teams?
optionA: Ask the project sponsor to appoint new managers for the deployment teams.
optionB: Propose that some of the teams delay deployments in their countries.
optionC: Ask each deployment team to provide a very detailed schedule and action plan.
optionD: Organize regular meetings with all of the deployment teams to share issues and solutions.

question: A company has a lot of experience with predictive projects. The project management office (PMO) has been trying to implement iterative tools within the project management framework, and the project manager has been asked to use these tools in their current project. After the successful implementation of the iterative tools, the PMO asks the project manager to determine the benefits these tools brought to the project. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Determine the data to be monitored during the project as well as the expected performance and targets.
optionB: Update the communications management plan to consider performance review meetings with the project stakeholders.
optionC: Prepare and submit a status report to the steering committee to update performance monitoring.
optionD: Conduct reviews with stakeholders to discuss the potential benefits the approach may have to the project.

question: A project manager receives a voicemail from a business analyst on the project team. The business analyst indicates that an internal stakeholder is upset that they were not included before the project began. The stakeholder is asking for an addition to the requirements traceability matrix. What should the project manager do to improve the stakeholder relationship?
optionA: Update the stakeholder engagement plan to ensure the stakeholder is included in the project stakeholder list.
optionB: Consult the project scope document to make sure the addition is in scope.
optionC: Engage the stakeholder to solicit more information before responding to the request.
optionD: Initiate a project change request so the change control board (CCB) can decide if it is in scope.

question: Development team members are located in three different time zones. It is difficult to find a suitable time to hold the daily standup for all team members. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Give up the daily standup and replace it with a daily report.
optionB: Let the team members decide themselves if they want to join the meeting.
optionC: Encourage frequent, small team meetings with two or three team members.
optionD: Require all team members to join the daily standup regardless of the meeting time.

question: During the course of a project, a junior team member approaches the project manager for some direction and advice on risk mitigation. How should the project manager respond?
optionA: Offer guidance and follow up with some developmental activity for the junior team member.
optionB: Refer the junior team member to the senior team member who develops the risk mitigation strategy.
optionC: Inform the junior team member that risk mitigation is not part of their work.
optionD: Tell the junior team member that the information is available in lessons learned.

question: A company is implementing a new system. The project manager has identified that it is best to complete this project using a mix of Scrum and Kanban methodologies. The product owner is confused as to how to start delivering the functionalities required. How should the project manager assist the product owner?
optionA: Coach the product owner on how to create a product backlog.
optionB: Discuss the product owner's responsibilities within the project team.
optionC: Encourage the team to subdivide the project tasks.
optionD: Create a work breakdown structure (WBS) and explain the deliverables to the product owner.

question: A project manager for a strategic initiative realizes a new stakeholder is interested in the project and wants to ensure the stakeholder is fully aware of the goals, objectives, benefits, and risks of the project. What should the project manager do to enhance the success of the project?
optionA: Schedule a meeting with the new stakeholder.
optionB: Share the project status reports with the new stakeholder.
optionC: Update the stakeholder engagement plan.
optionD: Add the new stakeholder to the communications management plan.

question: During the course of the project, several obstacles are identified that are preventing the project from moving forward. What should the project manager do to remove the obstacles?
optionA: Have the project team work on other activities
optionB: Implement plans to remove the obstacles
optionC: Escalate to the project steering committee
optionD: Prioritize the obstacles for resolution

question: A project manager is working with a Scrum team that is continually missing deadlines. The steering committee is concerned about the project as it is not clear that it will deliver the expected value. After some analysis, the project manager discovers there is a mismatch of competencies in one of the teams. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Emphasize to the teams the importance of meeting the agreed deadlines
optionB: Provide appropriate training to compensate for the mismatch
optionC: Update the project schedule to reflect the delay
optionD: Accept the risk of the project missing deadlines due to the mismatch

question: The steering committee has asked a project manager experienced in agile to provide an indication of the time remaining on a medium-sized project. What tools can be used to provide this information?
optionA: A release burndown chart
optionB: Analysis of the business requirements document
optionC: Story points for the remaining user stories
optionD: Surrogate measurements

question: A team is ready to start working on a project with a customer who was very difficult to work with in the past because the customer was unable to describe exactly what they wanted. What approach should the project manager take to remove this impediment?
optionA: Follow a predictive approach in order to obtain formal acceptance of each deliverable
optionB: Work with the product owner to define the minimum viable product(s)
optionC: Reinforce the negotiation and soft skills of the team through training
optionD: Develop and monitor a plan with due dates to reduce the time of completing the product

question: A vendor supplying a piece of specialized equipment for a project has reported the potential for a delivery delay due to a technical issue with the sub-supplier. To stay on schedule, the vendor proposed replacing the sub-supplier's component with a similar part that is different from the one that is stipulated in the project specifications. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Accept the proposed replacement in order to keep procurement activities on track
optionB: Insist on using the component per the project specifications and air freight the equipment to mitigate the delay
optionC: Instruct the vendor to use the part that is compliant with the project specifications and update the schedule
optionD: Consult with a subject matter expert (SME) to see if the proposed change is acceptable

question: At the end of a meeting, a functional manager takes the project manager aside to raise some concerns on behalf of a project team member who is unclear about their role and responsibilities for the project. What should the project manager do in this situation?
optionA: Develop a work plan for the project team member with the help of the resource manager
optionB: Advise the functional manager and the project team member to review the resource management plan
optionC: Tell the functional manager and the project team member to review the project charter
optionD: Ask the functional manager to create a specific responsible, accountable, consult, and inform (RACI) chart for the team member

question: A project manager is struggling to figure out the performance of the project teams in an agile environment. For the same scope of work, team A has calculated 100 story points and team B has calculated 125 story points. Which team is performing better?
optionA: Team A as they have calculated fewer story points than team B
optionB: Team B as they have calculated more story points than team A
optionC: The team that completes the most stones selected from the sprint backlog
optionD: The team with the least amount of defects in their deliverables

question: During the implementation stage of a project, a newly appointed team leader approaches the project manager to verify the team's tasks and schedule. The work did not go as planned due to the team leader's lack of management experience. This could cause delays for the project. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the human resources director to appoint a senior team leader
optionB: Inform the project sponsor about the possible delay
optionC: Directly manage the project team to avoid project delays
optionD: Provide mentoring to the newly appointed team leader

question: A project for Company A was successfully delivered within scope, schedule, and budget by the end of the last iteration. However, during the project celebration ceremony, one of the business stakeholders says they perceive the project as a failure as it did not add any business value. What should the project manager have done to avoid this perception?
optionA: Involved the business stakeholders in the sprint review
optionB: Defined product backlog priorities with the sponsor and key stakeholders to deliver business benefits
optionC: Implemented a closing survey for key stakeholders
optionD: Confirmed that there is a communications management plan in place to make business stakeholders aware of the success

question: A project manager meets with external stakeholders to explain the objectives and outline expectations for a new project. A key stakeholder appears to support the project, with the condition that other unrelated projects will receive financial support. Due to cultural sensitivities, the project manager is reluctant to be direct with the key stakeholder on this matter. The project cannot proceed without the support of this stakeholder. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Proceed with the project without allowing scope creep to occur
optionB: Use the contingency funds to provide support for the requested projects
optionC: Cancel the project since the stakeholder's request is out of scope
optionD: Inform the sponsor and document the request in the stakeholder engagement plan

question: A key stakeholder for a construction project has been spending a lot of time at the site and interrupting the team's efforts. What should the project manager do in this situation?
optionA: Work to understand the key stakeholder's concerns and provide feedback in regular project status reports
optionB: Arrange an ad hoc meeting to address the key stakeholder's concerns with team members
optionC: Reinforce with the key stakeholder that the project is performing on schedule
optionD: Escalate the situation to the project sponsor because the key stakeholder's behavior is impacting progress

question: A stakeholder on a project has a reputation for being easily angered and unreasonably difficult on projects. The project manager would like to minimize the impact of the stakeholder's behavior on the development team. What training should the project manager choose for their team to help with this situation?
optionA: Communication training
optionB: Negotiation training
optionC: Emotional intelligence training
optionD: Agile training

question: A company is using a predictive approach for the development of a particular component as defined in the scope management plan. Due to regularly changing regulatory requirements, the development team has requested to utilize agile approaches. What should the project manager do about the development team's request?
optionA: Escalate the request for additional financial resources
optionB: Forward the request to the project management office (PMO) to amend the organizational process assets
optionC: Ask the project sponsor to obtain approval for implementation of the new approach
optionD: Analyze the requirements that will need to be addressed under the requested method

question: During a daily standup meeting, a roadblock was raised that is preventing one of the team members from proceeding with work. The project manager figures out that it is due to a technical issue. What should the project manager do to prioritize this critical impediment?
optionA: Solve the issue for the team member.
optionB: Perform a brainstorming session to address the issue and add the solution to the sprint.
optionC: Escalate the issue to the software vendor for technical resolution.
optionD: Coach the team to come up with their own solution and add it to the next sprint.

question: A project is being executed. The project's life cycle is defined as predictive; however, a major deliverable will be handed over incrementally to the customer. The assigned resources are experienced and reliable and are willing to make decisions that the project manager used to make after each incremental delivery on other projects. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Schedule a steering committee meeting and obtain their approval on the request
optionB: Support the decisions of the team and transfer the decision making responsibility to them
optionC: Inform the team that although this is a hybrid environment, the project manager must still be responsible for making decisions
optionD: Consult the product owner about letting the resources make decisions

question: After reviewing the project management plan with key stakeholders, the project manager was told that an 18-month release plan was unacceptable and the product should launch in six months. Based on the new timeline, what should the project manager do?
optionA: Plan for overtime, apply crashing and fast tracking, and share the risk of failure with project stakeholders
optionB: Review the project backlog looking for high-priority items and come up with a minimum viable product (MVP) that fits the expected timeline
optionC: Seek approval with the sponsor to triple the project budget, hiring more people to compensate for the compressed schedule
optionD: Go over the critical path with stakeholders, explaining why it is not possible to deliver all the scope in the expected timeline

question: A research and development department is planning to develop a product that will introduce a new line of business for the organization. What should the project manager do to increase the project's chances of success?
optionA: Plan a working session focusing on the scope, vision, and mission of the initiative
optionB: Start developing the project management plan based on a previous project template from the project management office (PMO)
optionC: Conduct benchmarking to determine the business viability of the initiative
optionD: Conduct an impact analysis of the new initiative to determine how the project should be rolled out

question: The product owner decides to launch a product after a couple of releases, knowing that the minimum viable product (MVP) lacks some features. One of the key stakeholders, the marketing vice president, is not happy with the results and questioned the release decision. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Support the product owner's decision and seek better alignment with this stakeholder in order to avoid this type of issue in the future
optionB: Coach the team on the decision-making process, assuming a risk-averse strategy towards product releasing
optionC: Assume the responsibility for product releases, making the final call on when something is ready for customer launch
optionD: Escalate the issue to the sponsor, questioning the authority of the key stakeholder regarding the product launch decision

question: In the beginning of project execution, the project manager finds out that a key resource will be unavailable for two weeks, which could cause a delay to the schedule. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Assign the tasks to another resource, and ask the resource to work double shifts
optionB: Update the schedule to reflect the project's changes in duration
optionC: Ask human resources (HR) for a replacement, and update the risk register
optionD: Update the resource management plan and resource allocation chart accordingly

question: The change control board (CCB) rejects a change request submitted by a subject matter expert (SME). The SME refuses to accept this rejection and does not want to continue the project without the change. What should the project manager have done to avoid this situation?
optionA: Requested that the sponsor approved the change request first
optionB: Assessed the change's overall impact to the project before submission
optionC: Ensured that the change request was aligned with the project scope
optionD: Submitted the change request directly to the CCB

question: A food company is developing a new product using a predictive approach, and the product is currently in the testing phase. Given the nature of the feedback of the tests, the project manager has decided to use an iterative approach. At the end of one of the iterations, a new regulation related to the product is enacted. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Make a change request regarding the project's scope to ensure compliance
optionB: Include an assessment to verify compliance in the next iteration
optionC: Conduct an iteration review to address the new regulation
optionD: Start the tests over, adapting the trials to the new regulation

question: A project manager is managing an innovation project for a big corporation. The project manager is planning to use email as the main communication channel; however, the product owner prefers to use another approved communication tool instead of email. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Contact the sponsor to request direction regarding the communication tool to be used by the project team
optionB: Update the communications management plan based on the product owner's preferences and distribute to the team
optionC: Suggest to the team to start using the communication tool suggested by the product owner
optionD: Request the product owner to use email because using another tool will increase the workload

question: The customer's project manager changes during the final stage of a project. How can the project manager avoid a project closure delay?
optionA: Update the stakeholder engagement plan
optionB: Review the latest project status report and update the stakeholders
optionC: Escalate the case to the customer's management team
optionD: Issue the project payment invoice to the customer in advance

question: In an industrial plant, the owner has decided to add more capacity to the plant by installing a new machine and updating the software used in production. This capacity enlargement will occur while the plant is still functioning and producing. The software update will be accomplished using an agile approach in order to minimize risk. The machine procurement, installation, and integration will be accomplished using predictive approaches. What types of communications will the project manager have to design into the schedule management plan to ensure the project will be on schedule?
optionA: Weekly colocated meetings with the relevant stakeholders
optionB: Biweekly conference calls with the relevant stakeholders
optionC: Weekly one-on-one meetings with each of the relevant stakeholders
optionD: Biweekly written status reports from the relevant stakeholders

optionC: Update the risk register with the risk and proposed impact
optionD: Ask the team to fix the system to resolve the issue

question: After gathering all the requirements for a project with dependencies on external stakeholders, the project team is finishing the second iteration. At this point, the project manager learns about a possible change in regulations that would prevent the product launch. What should the project manager do to realize benefits?
optionA: Add an entry in the risk log
optionB: Implement the changes
optionC: Review target benefits
optionD: Improve the team's velocity

question: After a couple of iterations, the project manager decides to present the product to a key stakeholder. The stakeholder's feedback is that the team missed the mark on many features. What should the project manager do to avoid this in the future?
optionA: Set up requirements-gathering sessions with all key stakeholders to evaluate the scope once again and reprioritize the backlog based on the sessions
optionB: Schedule adequate sprint demos to gather early feedback from the stakeholders and adapt the plan accordingly
optionC: Incorporate design thinking practices into the project life cycle to better understand the product's personas and be more effective to match their needs
optionD: Evaluate the team's skills to look for someone with experience in product design and assign that person the task of rebuilding the product interface

question: A company wants to increase the commercial value of one of its products in a highly competitive market. In order to do this, the company commissions a project to create a prototype. The team constructs the prototype incrementally. Which action should the project manager take as a priority?
optionA: Emphasize the use of Kanban methodology
optionB: Ensure the project sponsor is aware of the go-to market date
optionC: Deliver business value as soon as possible
optionD: Implement a plan-do-check-act (PDCA) cycle

question: During the daily meetings with the team the project manager notices that a new team member is not making the expected progress on an assigned task. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the new team member to follow the team ground rules
optionB: Ask an experienced team member to identify a replacement
optionC: Ask the new team member to reassess their own capabilities
optionD: Ask an experienced team member to coach the new team member

question: A company's project management office (PMO) has started to implement iterative tools. A project manager is starting a new project and has identified an opportunity to use the iterative tools. One of the senior managers is concerned about this modified framework as it is fairly new to the company. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Organize individual sessions with the stakeholders to build awareness and trust in the new framework
optionB: Look for external training on the new framework to eliminate the risk of low engagement from stakeholders
optionC: Send documentation to the senior manager about the advantages of the new framework
optionD: Escalate the senior manager's concern to the project sponsor and distribute the status to the team

question: A project in the execution phase is behind schedule and is missing some materials. The contractor submits an offer to supply the missing materials and reimburse the cost since the internal procurement process will cause more delay. The project manager does not agree with the costs submitted by the contractor for the missing materials. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Ask the project sponsor to allocate more budget to cover the costs
optionB: Update the procurement management plan and negotiate with the contractor.
optionC: Ask the contractor to review the offer and reduce the costs.
optionD: Update the procurement strategy and negotiate with the contractor

question: A project manager presented the project schedule to the mam stakeholders. They have requested that the project be completed two months earlier than the scheduled date. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Hold a stakeholder meeting to align timelines and scope expectations
optionB: Crash the schedule to shorten the timeline while keeping the scope unchanged
optionC: Update the cost management plan to allocate more resources to the project to finish the scope earlier
optionD: Reduce the scope of the project by removing activities and shortening the timeline

question: An organization is embarking on the deployment of a new digital solution that will revolutionize purchasing services. The project manager has created all the necessary plans and activities to ensure a successful integration and solution launch. There is a risk of a partner's system being unavailable which could impact the project negatively. What key activity is needed to ensure the project's success?
optionA: Communicate to the project stakeholders that full integration may not be possible and that the project will potentially be delayed as a result
optionB: Eliminate the risk by mandating the partner to change the system settings to facilitate an easier integration with the new solution
optionC: Continuously monitor the risk of the partner system's unavailability, and put the proper resolution plans in place in case the risk materializes into an actual issue
optionD: Mitigate the risk by developing alternative plans to make the solution ready and available without full integration capabilities

question: The CEO has authorized the development of a complex financial product for a company to provide greater future benefits. The budget has been acquired through financing with global investors who expect all risks to be identified as soon as possible. What should the project manager use to identify the risks?
optionA: An analysis of shared risks between parties
optionB: Strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats (SWOT) analysis
optionC: Expert judgment
optionD: A risk value assessment

question: The sponsor is supportive in leveraging agile approaches. The project manager is contemplating how to roll out the agile approach and gam buy-in from both project team members and stakeholders. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Determine which agile software tools will be required to support agile delivery within the organization
optionB: Select a current predictive project, define the approach, and provide agile training to execute the remainder of the project
optionC: Start with a pilot project of appropriate complexity, and provide agile training to those who are impacted
optionD: Determine how to transform the organization using agile techniques, including organizational training and communications

question: A technical manager newly appointed by the client, visits the project site to verify the project deliverables. The technical manager feels that the project manager has not been providing enough information. What should the project manager do first to resolve this situation?
optionA: Update the issue log and escalate to the project sponsor
optionB: Identify the lack of information as a risk and update the risk register
optionC: Schedule more frequent meetings with the technical manager
optionD: Review and update the stakeholder engagement plan

question: During initiation of a new product improvement project, a project manager finds historical data showing that a similar project resulted in customers complaining of an even worse user experience compared to the previous product version. How can the project manager prevent this outcome in the new project?
optionA: Hire a team of external users to perform acceptance testing on the product
optionB: Define a user focus group as external stakeholders with a high influence on outcomes
optionC: Hire a consultant to perform a benefit analysis as an input to the project charter
optionD: Define a high-level risk and plan mitigation after completing the work breakdown structure (WBS)

question: In analyzing a project for monthly status reporting, the project manager notices that the schedule performance index (SPI) is 0,75 and the cost performance index (CPI) is 1,25. The project manager must provide the first project status review soon and wants to emphasize that the project is under control. How should the project manager report the project status to key stakeholders?
optionA: Prepare a detailed presentation for stakeholders on earned value including how it is calculated and the project's current earned value results
optionB: Report that the project is behind schedule but that an additional experienced resource can be added to stay within schedule and maintain the budget
optionC: Perform a detailed root cause analysis utilizing a pareto chart and fishbone diagrams to demonstrate that the project is under control
optionD: Report that the project is not tracking as expected, but is still under control since the next project milestone is over a month away

question: After a meeting with the customer, the project manager receives special recognition because the project is always on schedule. Later that day, the project manager attends a regular project team meeting to follow up on the status of the deliverables. What should the project manager do in the project team meeting?
optionA: Share the customer feedback with the project team
optionB: Follow the meeting agenda and make a list of the next deliverables
optionC: Document this feedback in the meeting minutes
optionD: Start planning how to improve the dates of next deliverables

question: Team members are having a discussion with the project manager. In the last retrospective meeting, the team realized that the obsolete equipment could affect the next iteration of the project. The team recommends buying new equipment because it is critical to the success of the final deliverable. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Check the project budget to verify if there is enough contingency reserve
optionB: Review the cost management plan to determine how to address this issue
optionC: Tell the team members that more equipment is not part of the project's scope
optionD: Submit a change request to increase the budget and buy new equipment

question: A company's CEO has just returned from a conference on the use of artificial intelligence (AI) and would like the project manager to implement this technology in the organization. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Start developing a business case
optionB: Start a strength, weaknesses, opportunities and threats (SWOT)
optionC: Engage stakeholders and allocate resources
optionD: Gather requirements from stakeholders

question: A project manager is leading a project with several stakeholders in other functional areas of the company. One of these stakeholders has just been promoted to lead another functional area, and remains a stakeholder for this project. What should the project manager have the project team update to ensure proper communications to stakeholders?
optionA: Project management plan
optionB: Stakeholder engagement plan
optionC: Stakeholder register
optionD: Communications management plan

question: A verbal announcement is made that the new team member joining the Scrum team has limited mobility. The scrum master is aware that some team members are unsure how the dynamics of the team will change. What should the scrum master do?
optionA: Create a stakeholder engagement plan
optionB: Design a communications management plan
optionC: Update the team charter accordingly
optionD: Set up a meeting to discuss accommodations the team will have to make

question: Stakeholders in some industries prefer to deal with programmers and system analysts directly, bypassing project managers. This complicates managing resources on projects. How should a project manager solve this issue?
optionA: Propose implementing a new project management information system (PMIS).
optionB: Request a meeting with senior management to escalate the situation
optionC: Promote adoption of the communications management plan with the project team.
optionD: Host a team-building event to develop team cohesion and improve communication

question: During an inspection, the production phase was stopped because the inspector claimed that regulatory labels were missing. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Conduct an expert judgment evaluation.
optionB: Review the quality management plan
optionC: Update the lessons learned register
optionD: Review the risk management plan

question: A project team is having difficulties understanding technical details regarding requirements. The information was not initially provided by the customer, but the information is critical in the current iteration for clarification on how tasks need to be accomplished. How should the project manager approach this situation?
optionA: Request that the customer reviews and clarifies feature definitions for the current sprint
optionB: Send a burndown chart of the current sprint to the customer and seek clarifications.
optionC: Educate the customer and have them participate in daily standup meetings.
optionD: Schedule weekly meetings and product reviews with the customer to clarify requirements

question: A project manager has received an updated earned value analysis report. The following are the key findings from the report: * Budget at completion = US$1 million * Earned value = US$0,7 million * Actual cost = US$0,75 million * Cost performance index = 0,933 Based on this information, what should the project manager conclude about project performance?
optionA: The project will be completed exactly as planned
optionB: The project will be easier to complete than planned
optionC: The project will be difficult to complete as planned
optionD: The project will not be completed as planned

question: A project manager has been appointed to a multimillion-dollar project. The project is considered to be high risk since no similar projects have been undertaken before and there is no historical data. Some external stakeholders are reluctant to provide support. What approach should the project manager take?
optionA: Examine the plans, processes, policies, and knowledge that are specific to the organization undertaking the project
optionB: Establish dialogue with stakeholders on the project constraints, assumptions, and critical inputs
optionC: Convince senior management to close the project since the project lacks sponsorship and is considered to be high risk
optionD: Host a project team meeting, then update the risk register and the project management plan

question: A project manager is assigned to a project in a company that is transitioning to agile. Not all stakeholders believe in the project, and some stakeholders would like the entire project defined and planned out early in the project. However, the project sponsor needs a quick win to ensure the continuation of the project. What approach should the project manager use?
optionA: An agile approach as this would provide working functionality earlier
optionB: A predictive approach as this would please the senior stakeholders
optionC: A hybrid project as this will mitigate stakeholders' concerns
optionD: A predictive approach as this will show benefits for all stakeholders

question: A team is currently working on a mobile app solution. During sprint execution, one of the developers requires clarification about the acceptance criteria for a particular task. What should the project manager do to obtain the information required by the developer?
optionA: Request direction from the project sponsor
optionB: Write an email to the client requesting clarification
optionC: Seek support from the development manager
optionD: Work with the product owner to clarify the requirement

question: A project manager works with a global virtual team. The team is facing difficulty in communicating with each other and often misses important messages. This difficulty leads to missed deadlines. What should the project manager do to enhance project team effectiveness?
optionA: Implement team colocation to improve communication
optionB: Identify the root cause of communication issues
optionC: Initiate daily communication of project progress
optionD: Schedule a communications control board meeting

question: A team member misses a project meeting without it being approved and has been penalized as defined in the ground rules. This team member, as well as other team members, insist that it is the first time they have seen this rule regarding the project and they do not agree with the penalty. What should the project manager have done to avoid this situation?
optionA: Ensured the team charter was developed by the team members
optionB: Ensured the team members are fully supportive of all decisions
optionC: Distributed the project charter to all team members
optionD: Used a charismatic leadership style

question: A project manager has two projects that are being executed at the same time. The duration of the critical project must be reduced, but the project manager does not have enough resources to achieve this goal. In addition, the schedule does not have activities that can be overlapped. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Analyze both projects to determine the most effective use of common resources
optionB: Use resource optimization to justify requesting more resources for the critical project
optionC: Provide schedule optimization training to the project teams to improve their skills
optionD: Apply fast-tracking techniques to compress the schedule of the critical project

question: A project manager for a maintenance project has a contract that is renewed annually. The project started 6 years ago. After contract renewal this year the auditors reported that this version of the contract violates a new law that was passed last year. What has happened in this situation?
optionA: The contract has not been appropriately reviewed by the project team
optionB: The stakeholder engagement plan has not been correctly implemented
optionC: The legal department has not disseminated the law correctly to all staff
optionD: The project manager does not have enough knowledge on this legal matter

question: A project manager realizes that a project is becoming delayed because some key decisions are affected by contradicting views between the organization's senior management and external stakeholders. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Review the stakeholder register and ensure that communications are being followed in line with the communications management plan.
optionB: Isolate the project team from external factors such as senior management and stakeholders so that decisions can be made more quickly
optionC: Review the remaining scope and rebaseline the project's schedule to take into account delays in decision making
optionD: Review the adequacy of the project's governance and ensure that an appropriate structure is in place

question: A project just kicked off and management's expectation is to ensure that the deliverable of the first iteration helps the marketing team present the product prototype to potential customers. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Increase the details of the work breakdown structure (WBS) to minimize errors and delays
optionB: Split the backlog into phases to ensure that the key features are delivered first
optionC: Ask the sponsor to prioritize some functionalities of the product
optionD: Identify the minimum functionality required for the product

question: A project manager is in rapid development mode on a joint application development module. The company wants delivery to occur in two weeks. The module needs to be integrated with other modules on a similar timeline, but release management has a three-week backlog. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Push the team to deliver more so that the modules are developed and rolled out according to management's request
optionB: Speak to the stakeholders to resolve the bottleneck and see how the entire process can be streamlined
optionC: Have the team work toward the tighter deadline so that integration will be easier
optionD: Speak to the team and slow the current pace to ensure the team is in alignment with the release date

question: An organization is introducing agile to its projects. During an informal discussion the project manager learned that team members who are currently working on different teams are discussing how they would like to be together on the same team. What should the project manager do?
optionA: The project manager should not allow resources to choose teams because the project manager assigns the resources based upon project needs
optionB: The project manager should not allow resources to choose on which team they would like to work because they will always choose their favorite team
optionC: The project manager should allow the resources to periodically choose on which team they would like to work
optionD: The project manager should indicate that the team members have already been assigned to a team through workforce optimization

question: During a retrospective meeting a project manager hears that stakeholders have been constantly complaining at iteration demos about product features not being delivered as requested. What advice should the project manager give to the Product owner to ensure that product features are always delivered as requested?
optionA: Include stakeholders during daily standup meetings to monitor progress
optionB: Validate acceptance criteria with stakeholders prior to backlog refinement
optionC: Avoid including stakeholders in iteration reviews
optionD: Create a requirements traceability matrix and distribute it accordingly

question: A project for a new product launch is in a very initial stage and the requirements are evolving. Due to stiff competition in the market, the customer would like to launch the product keeping the scope flexible. The project team intends to start the work based on the forecast of a similar project delivered last year. Which project approach suits the scenario?
optionA: Execute it as a Scrum project
optionB: Execute it as a predictive project
optionC: Execute it using the same approach as the reference project
optionD: Execute it as a project with stage gates

question: The project manager of an agile project has been asked to reduce the budget by 30%. Since this is a small project team, the budget is primarily allocated to resources. What strategy should the project manager use in order to keep delivering value in a restricted environment?
optionA: Reduce the project staff and adjust the scope and timelines accordingly in support of the budget reduction
optionB: Balance the project team in order to accommodate the budget challenges, and provide training to mitigate the risk of low performance
optionC: Prioritize the product backlog looking for high business value and low effort, and adjust the project budget and staffing to account for those items
optionD: Restrict the project scope only to basic critical features and run the project with the current staffing level until all of the budget is consumed

question: During the implementation phase of a project, a new regulation affects the project, and a critical status meeting discussing the scope changes is required. The project manager discovers that a key stakeholder cannot attend the scheduled meeting. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Call for a change control board (CCB) meeting, and inform the stakeholder about the outcome
optionB: Update the communications management plan and implement the change
optionC: Meet with the project sponsor to discuss how to address the situation
optionD: Meet with the stakeholder prior to the meeting to obtain their opinion

question: A new project has been kicked off following a planning session. The project is under direct oversight of an executive in the organization. After a review meeting, the project manager overhears an executive request a dashboard from one of the team members to show the overall project status. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Update the stakeholder engagement assessment matrix
optionB: Update the communications management plan to include informal requests
optionC: Ask the team member to develop a dashboard to fulfill the request
optionD: Tell the team member to route the request through the project manager

question: A project manager is managing a project which has a very complex and long execution period. Although the project is mostly predictive, the team was able to break the design and execution into smaller packages using a hybrid framework. The business wants to keep track of the value delivered by this framework application but there is no defined set of measurable items for the framework. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Work with the stakeholders to determine which measurable benefits can be tracked and assign an accountable person to monitor and report them
optionB: Create a report based on the work breakdown structure (WBS) and update it on a regular basis.
optionC: Use the same benefits tracking process from the last predictive project and add this to the monthly status report
optionD: Research which templates of reports were used the most for this framework and incorporate them into the project

question: Early in the execution phase, a project manager discovers that recent changes in enterprise environmental factors (EEFs) will severely reduce the implementation cost and shorten the project schedule. How should the project manager address this situation?
optionA: Meet with the project team to decide how the remaining budget will be spent
optionB: Keep the extra budget as management reserve until project closeout
optionC: Give the team extra time to finish tasks within the original timeline
optionD: Follow the project escalation policy and communications management plan

question: A group has been working together for one month. During daily meetings a team member continues to express issues in completing their tasks. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Wait for the team to identify and solve the problem independently
optionB: Move the team member to another task that is more skill appropriate
optionC: Have a confidential discussion with the team member to identify the root cause
optionD: Start a discussion with all team members to help resolve the issues

question: A team has different ideas on how to address a feature of a product under construction and; although the sprint began two days ago, they have still not reached a consensus. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the product owner, who is the key stakeholder, to choose among the different ideas
optionB: Propose ideas to the group, ask everyone to vote, and then choose the most popular idea
optionC: Schedule a session to give everyone the chance to express their opinions about each idea, then vote and decide
optionD: Offer an opinion about the pros and cons of each idea and try to reach a consensus in a facilitated meeting

question: A junior staff member was recently assigned to the team. The new team member tells the project manager that they are confused because they are not familiar with what is expected of them on the project. What should the project manager do to assist the new team member?
optionA: Advise the new team member to enroll in project management training
optionB: Instruct the new team member to review the responsible, accountable consult, and inform (RACI) matrix before asking for help
optionC: Advise the new team member to review the project charter and stakeholder engagement plan
optionD: Review the resource management plan and provide mentoring to the new team member if necessary

question: A project team is engaging a development team in another country to develop software. During progress reviews, the project manager identified completion date delays due to rework because there were different interpretations of the client's needs. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Set up a meeting with key stakeholders to clarify requirements
optionB: Escalate to the project steering committee and request additional time
optionC: Travel to the development team's office to push the schedule
optionD: Create prototypes with the development team to confirm requirements

question: A team has been working on a project for several months, but the completion date is unclear because the scope is changing frequently as new knowledge is gained. Some deliverables have already been completed, but when new stakeholders join the team, they complain that project outcomes are not meeting business goals. How can the project manager prevent this situation from happening in the future?
optionA: Create a prioritized backlog and define iteration review sessions with stakeholders
optionB: Create a detailed work breakdown structure (WBS) and milestone schedule approved by all stakeholders
optionC: Schedule a daily meeting to review team performance and impediments
optionD: Schedule a kick-off meeting for every project phase to share the project management plan with all stakeholders

question: A company recently used desktop research for a feasibility study, which showed that the project is behind schedule. The project team also has concerns about the impact of scope changes on the project schedule. What should the project manager do to keep the project on schedule while still meeting project objectives?
optionA: Collaborate with the change control board (CCB) to review the scope and submit any change requests
optionB: Submit a change request to the CCB and update the schedule
optionC: Update the scope and add more resources to the project
optionD: Update the scope and move on to the next project milestone

question: A project manager has been using predictive methodology for more than 10 years and is switching to an agile project. The team members have not previously worked together. After two sprints of work, the team has not achieved any outcome and there is a lot of pressure to get work done. What kind of leadership style should the project manager use at this stage?
optionA: A directive style that makes decisions for the group to reach early outcomes
optionB: A leadership style that coaches people who want help and fosters greater team collaboration
optionC: A passive leadership style that allows the team to self-organize until the norming stage is reached
optionD: A democratic style that uses techniques where majority opinion prevails

question: A project manager has been assigned to lead a project to deploy a new system. The stakeholders disagree on the project objectives and approach. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Create a roles and responsibilities matrix based on the project charter and ask the sponsor to share it with all stakeholders to provide credible authority
optionB: Conduct scoping workshops with the project team to create a work breakdown structure (WBS), assign tasks to various entities, share this with all stakeholders, and ask the team to complete their tasks as scheduled
optionC: Conduct a general meeting with all stakeholders and review and address a list of activities for each of them
optionD: Breakdown the situation to identify the root causes for the disagreement and then work with each stakeholder and participating entity on their exact roles and responsibilities

question: The project manager started a new project and must ensure that the team members and stakeholders are adequately trained. After an interview with the team, the project manager discovers that all resources have experience in different agile methodologies. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Make sure the project team is aware of all agile techniques
optionB: Skip the training because the team already understands agile
optionC: Ensure the team has a common understanding of agile
optionD: Teach one agile methodology fully and completely

question: A project manager invites the company CEO, sponsor, team members, and an external client representative to a meeting to review the project management plan. The project manager starts to present the budget but the CEO suddenly asks to end the meeting. What should the project manager have done to avoid this situation?
optionA: Reviewed the communications management plan before inviting an external client representative to the meeting
optionB: Reviewed the cost management plan with internal participants and CEO prior to inviting an external client representative to the meeting
optionC: Performed a root cause analysis with the external client representative and documented the findings in the lessons learned register
optionD: Sent the presentation slides to internal participants first and then to the external client representative prior to the meeting

question: A project manager is assigned to a new project to deliver a product at the end of the year. The project manager was informed by the vendor that a core component could not be shipped on time, which will impact the schedule. What should project manager to do next to minimize the impact on the project?
optionA: Schedule a meeting with all stakeholders to extend the project deadline
optionB: Replace the vendor with a new vendor who can offer the component on time
optionC: Add an item to the next status review to make stakeholders aware of the vendor issue
optionD: Review and update the issue log and determine if any alternative components can be offered

question: In a hybrid project, the customer decided on a major change for the project design. This change was approved and the impact on schedule and budget is known. The software team leader, who is supposed to develop the software, refuses to commit to delivery dates claiming that they work using an agile approach and cannot commit to a final delivery date. The hardware team depends on this software to develop their part of the product. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Add this risk to the risk register and monitor it according to the risk management plan
optionB: Escalate this to higher management and ask for help to resolve the issue
optionC: Impose the delivery dates on the software team leader and notify the functional manager about the situation
optionD: Ask the software team leader to use a predictive approach and commit to a delivery date

question: A project manager is having difficulty acquiring final acceptance of some deliverables from a stakeholder for reasons that seem to be outside of the project acceptance criteria. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Persuade this stakeholder using emotional intelligence skills to obtain acceptance.
optionB: Obtain final acceptance from another stakeholder who is also familiar with the project.
optionC: Escalate this issue to the project sponsor and ask for support in obtaining final stakeholder acceptance.
optionD: Create a project acceptance waiver noting the stakeholder's concerns so they can be addressed later.

question: How should the project manager develop the project management plan to ensure that the project continually delivers the expected benefits?
optionA: Clarify project benefits with the sponsor
optionB: Identify the goal of each work product
optionC: Perform integration testing of each release
optionD: Include the entire project team in testing

question: During project execution, a project manager is informed that most of the project team members have enrolled in the newly implemented work-from-home company policy. How should the project manager reflect this change in the project?
optionA: Update the communication styles for enrolled team members in the communications management plan.
optionB: Update roles and responsibilities for enrolled team members in the responsibility assignment matrix (RAM).
optionC: Update the stakeholder engagement plan to include the emergency contact information for enrolled team members.
optionD: Update the resource calendar for enrolled team members in the resource management plan.

question: A project manager is assigned to a project within a program. The high-level requirements of the project are known, but the priorities of some of the requirements are uncertain as they are interdependent on some other pipeline projects within the program. How should the project manager prepare for the next steps of the project?
optionA: Escalate to the management team to increase the timeline based on the complexity of the project
optionB: Wait for the other project estimates before planning the schedule
optionC: Prioritize and estimate the milestones for the high-level requirements based on historical data
optionD: Ask the project management office (PMO) to estimate the tasks for all the projects and share the project management plan

question: A new team member has joined an agile project, replacing a team member who recently left. The project team needs the new team member to speed up their ability to contribute effectively to the project. What should the project manager do to help in this situation?
optionA: Assign the new team member the same tasks that were assigned to the previous team member who they replaced
optionB: Schedule knowledge transfer sessions and assign less complex tasks to the new team member
optionC: Send technical documentation to the new team member and schedule training for the next iteration
optionD: Have the new team member complete all of the company's mandatory training

question: A team is holding the first demonstration of the software built to date on a medium-sized project. The product owner has uncovered a number of issues they would like to be addressed before providing approval. How should the project manager approach this problem?
optionA: Plan to address the issues through backlog grooming and incorporate them into the next sprint
optionB: Refer the product owner to the change management plan, then escalate to the steering committee
optionC: Refer the product owner to the signed business requirement document and explain that the current plan cannot facilitate these changes
optionD: Tell the product owner the issues will be addressed in the second version of the software

question: A project manager has just finished initiating a project. While planning the project manager notes that several essential team members do not have the required skills for key tasks later in the project. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Develop the resource management plan and ensure adequate training
optionB: Replace the current project team members
optionC: Outsource the task to be completed by a specialized vendor
optionD: Update the issue log to account for the lack of team member qualifications

question: A project to develop a large hydropower plant is in the implementation phase and is managed using a hybrid approach. What should the project manager do to ensure full compliance of quality requirements during the execution phase?
optionA: Analyze the quality requirements.
optionB: Plan quality management
optionC: Continually survey the quality of the deliverable
optionD: Set up quality policies and procedures

question: A project manager finished reviewing the project deliverables for the current iteration with the customer. A new key stakeholder who just joined the customer's team, complains that the results do not provide the capabilities the business anticipated. What should the project manager do to address this issue?
optionA: Create a change request and update the scope management plan
optionB: Conduct stakeholder identification and a project objectives review session
optionC: Update the stakeholder list and fix the deliverables
optionD: Update the project management plan and lessons learned

question: As part of the strategic plan, a company decides to implement a new software platform to manage a centralized document repository. Some requirements are clear and some need more detail. What should the project manager do first to decide how to manage this project?
optionA: Select a predictive development life cycle based on the team's experience
optionB: Determine the most appropriate life cycle approach for the project
optionC: Register all requirements into a backlog for further detailed analysis
optionD: Split the requirements, put them into two separate projects, and apply different approaches

question: One team member is not as active as the rest of the team during a brainstorming session. The project manager has a separate conversation with the team member and learns that the team member is slightly hearing impaired. The team member appreciates the project manager's concern. The project manager then decides to change the time and room for the meeting to ensure everyone can participate. What interpersonal skill did the project manager use?
optionA: Networking
optionB: Emotional intelligence
optionC: Conflict management
optionD: Influencing

question: For the purposes of quality assurance, a quality audit was conducted on the processes being used in the project execution plan. One of the nonconformance issues raised by the auditor was that attendance lists for the project risk review meetings were not available. Why is an attendance list important?
optionA: It is standard practice on projects to conduct risk review meetings which should have records on meeting attendance
optionB: The attendance list is evidence that risk review meetings were held with the appropriate project team members
optionC: It is a record that shows the number of attendees in the meeting
optionD: It is a document that is registered within the lessons learned register

question: A company is initiating a project to enhance one of its existing products. All of its products are developed internally. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ensure the stakeholder engagement plan is accurate and properly documented
optionB: Review the lessons learned from the previous project
optionC: Identify the risk of implementing the new solution and evaluate the impact on the project
optionD: Create a lessons learned document for the initiation phase

question: The client will not agree to closure, claiming that the project team has not performed the code inspections mandated in the development contract. The project team has performed the code inspections, however the records are not complete. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Seek expert legal advice on the interpretation of the clauses in the contract
optionB: Hold a meeting with the project team project sponsor and the client to agree to the further work required to close the project and add to lessons learned
optionC: Close the project and hand over the deliverables to the client
optionD: Hold a lessons learned workshop with the project team and project sponsor to avoid contractual compliance issues arising in future projects

question: A project manager has a team of shared resources from other projects who are working on a client project. Three days before the project is due. The team informs the project manager that the project will be delayed because a component was not delivered on time. Competing priorities of the shared resources are delaying delivery of the component. What should the project manager have done to prevent this delay from happening?
optionA: Updated the risk management plan and registered lessons learned for the project
optionB: Reorganized the team for the project based on the work breakdown structure (WBS)
optionC: Maintained constant communication with the stakeholders of the other projects
optionD: Used the resource management plan to identify the impacts of the other projects

question: A project manager has been managing a highly complex project. The project manager has ensured that all of the required tasks have been completed. During a recent external audit. The project manager was informed of a heavy penalty being levied on the project for the latest module that was implemented. What should the project manager have done to ensure that there were no liabilities arising from the recent implementation?
optionA: Ensured that all defects identified during testing were resolved before implementation
optionB: Ensured that all of the required tasks identified in the scope were completed successfully
optionC: Ensured that all documentation was completed post implementation before closing the project
optionD: Ensured that all the required approvals were received per the organizational procedures

question: A project manager at a company is considering a high-performing junior member of the organization to be the new project manager for a current project. What should the project manager do to prepare for a recommendation to senior management?
optionA: Compile key highlights featuring the team member from the meeting minutes
optionB: Ask the team member to write a short biography listing their qualifications
optionC: Gather project artifacts that demonstrate the team member's high performance
optionD: Calculate the health of the projects on which the team member has worked

question: A project manager accepts a delivery at the project site but the items are of a poor quality. The project manager gets the local vendor to fix the items but more deliveries from this vendor are expected. What should the project manager do going forward?
optionA: Allocate extra time to inspect deliveries for quality assurance upon arrival at the site
optionB: Review the contract requirements and ask for the applicable evidence for quality assurance
optionC: Have the vendor issue the quality documentation prior to the next delivery
optionD: Call the vendor and have them verbally guarantee the quality of the next site delivery

question: During project execution, the risk owner is monitoring the critical speed rate of a power engine to eventually trigger the defined risk-response strategy. During the risk assessment and management process phase, it was defined that the power engine has the following characteristics: 1,600 rpm (rate-per-minute) -> stops working and crashes the system 1,500 rpm (rate-per-minute) -> warns of max rate allowed 1,400 rpm (rate-per-minute) -> reduces the power and brakes the engine Which of the following statements is correct?
optionA: 1,600 rpm is a project risk, 1,500 rpm is an event that triggers a response strategy, and 1,400 rpm is a project issue.
