optionB: 1,600 rpm is a project issue, 1,500 rpm is an event that triggers a response strategy, and 1,400 rpm is a project risk.
optionC: 1,600 rpm is a project issue, 1,500 rpm is a project risk, and 1,400 rpm is an event that triggers a response strategy.
optionD: 1,600 rpm is an event that triggers a response strategy, 1,500 rpm is a project issue, and 1,400 rpm is a project risk.

question: Project A is critical for the company and must be completed within nine months. The project charter has been signed but the project scope statement has not been prepared. Management asks the project manager to move forward with the project without an approved project scope statement. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Escalate the issue to the project sponsor and add it to the risk register
optionB: Refuse to work on the project because management is not following standard project management practices
optionC: Meet with management to explain the potential problems with running a project without a project scope statement
optionD: Start the project with inputs from the project charter to save time

question: A project manager is starting a project using a hybrid approach and notices some team members only have knowledge of predictive approaches. What does the project manager need to do first in order to have good project performance?
optionA: Coach those team members lacking hybrid knowledge to learn on the job.
optionB: Change the team to include hybrid experts.
optionC: Assess the required training per team member.
optionD: Deliver hybrid training to all team members.

question: While reviewing prototypes, the quality team found some deviations that do not affect the mam functionality but have the potential to be an issue in the future. To avoid major problems in the future, the team recommends corrective actions that will require additional funds. The project is already struggling to stay on budget and has even used some of the contingency reserves. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the product designer why the deviation was not considered in the design phase
optionB: Report to the project sponsor that the product is working and the project is struggling with the budget
optionC: Evaluate and initiate the change request process with the stakeholders
optionD: Ask the quality team to discard the sample and test again with a new sample

question: A team has been struggling with various issues during the course of an iteration. The project lead facilitates a discussion of the issues and the team forms new team agreements. During the next iteration, some of the same issues appear again. What should the project lead do next?
optionA: Notify senior management of the issues, and have them review the importance of agreements with the team
optionB: Challenge the team to determine if the issues surfaced again because agreements were not followed
optionC: Post the agreements in a conspicuous place where all of the team members can see them
optionD: Let the team self-organize and determine the best means to prevent the issues from occurring again

question: A technical subject matter expert (SME) identifies an occurrence that should be captured in the project's lessons learned. The SME asks the project manager to write, document and include it in the lessons learned register. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Assign the documenting task to a project team member.
optionB: Ask the SME to document and capture the occurrence.
optionC: Request the SME to wait until the project closure phase.
optionD: Take ownership of documenting this information.

question: During the course of a project, the project manager wants to ensure that the work carried out and the product being created do not deviate from the prescribed business value. What should the project manager pay special attention to in order to achieve this goal?
optionA: Reviewing and updating the requirements management plan
optionB: Carrying out quality audits and failure analyses
optionC: Monitoring the work breakdown structure (WBS)
optionD: Monitoring and updating the benefits realization plan

question: The project sponsor on an agile project informed the project lead that an executive would like an update on the project's progress. What should the project lead do?
optionA: Provide a link to the project's shared drive for the executive to search through for any artifacts that are of interest
optionB: Invite the executive to the project's meeting space to determine if the project information radiators meet their needs
optionC: Reach out to the project management office (PMO) for status report templates and provide project updates in that format
optionD: Ask the project sponsor or product owner to provide an update since the project lead should be trying to keep the team free from impediments

question: During an iteration of a project, a planned activity becomes more complex. The work should be delivered in the shortest time possible. What approach should be used in this situation?
optionA: The team facilitator gets support from external team members.
optionB: The team members bring in a specialist to help them
optionC: The product owner moves it to the product backlog.
optionD: The cross-functional team member work together to complete the activity

question: A multinational company has a plan to expand their business into a new country where they currently have no presence. A project manager is assigned to initiate this project. After reviewing the business case, what should be considered first when developing an appropriate implementation strategy?
optionA: Acquire project resources from the new country to mitigate the risk of uncertainty
optionB: Evaluate the environmental and regulatory factors and identify high-level risks and assumptions
optionC: Identify and monitor the risks closely since the company does not have lessons learned for this country
optionD: Ensure that project sponsors are in agreement on the project deliverables and timeline during the project

question: A project manager is assigned to lead a newly formed agile team. The functional manager has assigned tasks to team members, but the team members do not feel empowered. How can the project manager promote empowerment and accountability among the team?
optionA: Assign the tasks individually based on the role of the team member to ensure expertise on the subject.
optionB: Encourage and assign the team to perform demos of their products or software with the customers
optionC: Give the team autonomy to make their own decisions on how to perform the tasks
optionD: Encourage the team to keep the product owner involved when choosing ways to resolve the given task

question: A project manager who is managing a critical project in a multinational company is conducting a progress meeting with all team members. During the meeting, one of the team members states that they are facing a critical problem that will prevent them from completing their assigned task. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the team member to follow the approved communications management plan to communicate their issue
optionB: Schedule a meeting with the concerned team member to review and update the issue log together
optionC: Review the risk register with the team member to find the proper response action for this issue
optionD: Ask the team member to raise a change request to assess the issue in detail

question: During the last sprint review the product owner stated that the product does not deliver any value. The project manager believes that the product meets all the provided specifications. The team is confused by the product owner's statement. What should the project manager do when using a hybrid approach?
optionA: Escalate the matter to the executive board so they can decide on next steps
optionB: Prioritize the project backlog and ask the development team to fix the issues
optionC: Review the project's benefits management plan with the product owner
optionD: Ask the product owner to terminate the project as it is no longer aligned to the expected benefits

question: A geographically distributed project team has development issues between the collocated and virtual teams causing productivity to decrease. What should the project manager do to address this issue?
optionA: Force the team members to work from one location
optionB: Develop protocols for resolving conflicts between team members
optionC: Obtain special expertise to advise the team members
optionD: Set up face-to-face meetings with project team members

question: A Scrum team has committed to delivering a specific capability in their first release. Multiple operational issues have prevented the developer from delivering key capabilities. The technical lead has also given notice that they are resigning from the company. What should the project manager have the Scrum team do to recover from these issues?
optionA: Review constraints in the ongoing sprint planning and evaluate options for the release plan
optionB: Stop the sprint and replan and prioritize the backlog to reduce resource levels
optionC: Consult the resource management plan for an appropriate response
optionD: Continue with existing sprint plans to ensure some of the scope will be delivered

question: A project manager is leading a large-scale project that involves 70 stakeholders. The project manager has heard various comments and expectations from the customers, some of which are contradictory. Consequently, some requirements are not clear. What should the project manager do to build consensus regarding the requirements?
optionA: Escalate the issue to the management team for their review and guidance
optionB: Create a survey template to collect feedback from stakeholders to reach an agreement
optionC: Organize a face-to-face meeting with all stakeholders to understand their interests and concerns
optionD: Leverage expert judgment to determine the requirements that should be considered

question: A project manager has been asked to lead a project. The performing organization does not have a project management office (PMO) or formal governance policies procedures, and guidelines for this type of project. What should the project manager do first to determine a governance approach for the project?
optionA: Consult a subject matter expert (SME) as to the best governance policies, procedures, and guidelines to be used by the project
optionB: Consult with team members and stakeholders to determine whether the organization has any informal governance policies procedures, and guidelines
optionC: Choose either a predictive or agile framework best suited to the nature of the project, and use this framework as the basis for project governance policies, procedures, and guidelines
optionD: Coach the self-managing team to produce tailored governance policies, procedures and guidelines for the project

question: A key project stakeholder who was a big supporter and motivator for the project team is leaving the organization. The project team is experiencing low morale and poor teamwork. What should the project manager do to improve morale?
optionA: Identify the wants and aspirations of the team
optionB: Build team connections and emotional bonds
optionC: Forge consensus through team participation
optionD: Set goals and push the team to achieve the goals

question: A project manager is appointed for the deployment of a new solution. The solution will be integrated into the environment by a third-party vendor. This vendor just announced a delay in delivering a key component, which will impact the project schedule. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask for expedited delivery of the component to mitigate the risk of schedule delays
optionB: Ensure that relevant stakeholders and expectations are identified and assess the component delay
optionC: Perform a detailed analysis of the release content for each component of the solution
optionD: Propose a new design of the solution maw the external component with an internal one

question: A project manager and protect team are developing a strategic approach to engage the internal and external stakeholders. Which approach should be followed?
optionA: Analyze both internal and external stakeholders and develop a customized engagement strategy for each stakeholder
optionB: Schedule status meetings with all stakeholders to allow their participation in all project discussions and reports
optionC: Classify all high-risk stakeholders and request that the protect sponsor communicate directly with them
optionD: Involve only the internal stakeholders as the external stakeholders should not have access to confidential information

question: A distributed protect team wants to use the common ground principle to ensure that they have a common understanding of the scope. The team asks the protect lead to set up a workshop. What should the project lead do?
optionA: Ask the senior members of the development team to elaborate on the scope in detail
optionB: Invite participants to the workshop with sufficient lead time to prepare
optionC: Reduce the number of participants to ensure that consensus is reached easier
optionD: Provide the participants with specific instructions and sot the expectations

question: A client mentioned that in the past 2 months, they have not been invoiced for completed work. The client has communicated that they will release the funds for other activities it the invoices are not sent. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Work with the client and agree on a schedule to provide them with the invoices
optionB: Reach out to the billing team and instruct them to issue the invoices immediately
optionC: Review the previous billing information and prepare a corrective action plan
optionD: Communicate and inform the client to go ahead and release the funds

question: Midway through the execution of an agile protect there is a shift in the strategic objectives at the organization level to promote digital transformation. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Schedule a meeting with the team to assess the impact of the change
optionB: Escalate to the product owner and cancel the upcoming iterations
optionC: Prepare a user story to handle the change and assign it to the next iteration
optionD: Update the risk-prioritized backlog with the strategic change

question: A project manager is assigned to a project that will improve the business operations for a trading firm. The project team has just completed the discovery phase and needs to make a presentation to the business team in 4 weeks to showcase the feasibility of the solution. How should the project manager advise the team to proceed?
optionA: Develop a conceptual framework.
optionB: Develop a request for proposal (RFP).
optionC: Develop a prototype.
optionD: Develop a minimum viable product (MVP).

question: Project reviews are done regularly in a project. The team has encountered a critical technical issue that will be discussed in the next project review. Who should the project manager invite to the review for an effective decision on the way forward?
optionA: Internal team
optionB: Project team
optionC: Management team
optionD: End user team

question: A project manager is initiating an agile project for which some external components will be delivered by vendors. One of the vendors, however, will be unable to deliver its component in an incremental, collaborative way. How should the project manager handle this situation?
optionA: Submit a request to the project sponsor to have the vendor replaced with a vendor who can work following an agile approach.
optionB: Ask the project management office (PMO) to abandon using an agile approach on the project to accommodate the vendor.
optionC: Have the vendor deliver the component using another approach, then integrate it into the project without changing the overall agile approach.
optionD: Ask the product owner to move the component to the product backlog to be addressed after the work using an agile approach has been completed.

question: A project manager is leading a team that is geographically dispersed. The team needs to collaborate and finalize the monthly reports. Occasionally, meetings occur during the weekends due to the time differences. Team members have expressed that they do not want to work on the weekends. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Take over the activity and deliver the reports whenever work is required on a weekend.
optionB: Avoid reporting during the months that team members would need to work on the weekend.
optionC: Remind the team members of their governance responsibilities documented in the team charter.
optionD: Communicate to the project stakeholders that the reports will be delayed certain months of the year.

question: A project manager is managing a large project. During a review meeting, the project manager discovers that one of the team members who use to be a high performer was not able to complete their work on time.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Talk to the team member to determine why their performance changed.
optionB: Talk to the team member's manager to provide more training.
optionC: Talk to the team member and a human resources (HR) representative.
optionD: Talk to the project lead and ask them to allocate less demanding tasks.

question: An organization is initiating a project that will be using new technology. The complexity of the project requires excellent technical skills. After reviewing the proposed project management plan, the project sponsor asks for options to reduce the labor cost without introducing risk to the project delivery.  What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Review the risk register and assign functional managers as resources.
optionB: Perform an analysis of the key cost drivers and present alternatives.
optionC: Analyze the resource pool and assign internal resources who participated in past projects.
optionD: Review the work breakdown structure (WBS) to ensure there are adequate resources.

question: A project manager is using an agile approach. During the sprint planning meeting, the product owner flagged a backlog item as high business value and easy to implement. However, the other team members identified a high dependency between this item and another item that is flagged as low business value and high complexity.  What should the project manager do to support the backlog prioritization?
optionA: Support the team to move both items to the next sprint when the team will know more.
optionB: Prioritize the item flagged as high business value and low complexity for this sprint.
optionC: Facilitate the discussion until the team reaches an agreement about the two items.
optionD: Prioritize the item flagged as a dependency with low business value and high complexity.

question: A project manager meets with the development team to estimate the time required to complete a software application. The software developers are new to the company, and they have never developed a similar application.  Which estimation technique should the project manager recommend?
optionA: Analogous estimating
optionB: Parametric estimating
optionC: Planning poker
optionD: Three-point estimating

question: A project sponsor insists that the project scope for a new product launch should include two geographical locations. However, after the project scoping session was done, a project charter was completed and approved with one location only.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the sponsor to increase the budget and schedule of the project to accommodate the additional scope.
optionB: Assess the impact to the scope and submit a change request for approval of the two locations before including them in the scope of the project.
optionC: Discuss with the sponsor that the project scope is approved and it is not possible to include two locations as it will affect the budget.
optionD: Encourage the sponsor to start another project for the additional location so that the current project is not impacted.

question: A project is on its fifth iteration out of six. One member of the team has left the company unexpectedly.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Take on some of the necessary work to minimize the impact.
optionB: Invite the stakeholders to discuss a mitigation plan.
optionC: Detail the reason for the project delay in the status report.
optionD: Register an issue and escalate it to the project sponsor.

question: A construction company is executing a building contract that includes firm milestones for replacing certain components of the building. During execution, the client complains that the new components do not meet the requirements.  What should the project manager have done to prevent this from happening?
optionA: Continuously communicated the changes in the work plan and the agreement to the client
optionB: Defined acceptance criteria in a quality checklist agreed upon before starting the build phase
optionC: Provided compensation for issues due to the variance in the agreed-upon requirements
optionD: Approved a detailed change management process before starting the build phase

question: An agile team is in the early phases of the development cycle for a project; however, they have already begun to deliver functionality to the customer. The team has identified risks to the project and are working on developing the mitigation strategy.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Escalate the risk to the project sponsor and steering committee.
optionB: Implement the risk mitigation strategy according to the highest impact.
optionC: Incorporate and prioritize the risks in the risk register according to impact.
optionD: Determine if any of the new risks have any financial impact.

question: A project stakeholder complained that they did not receive an important delivery that was stated in the schedule. The team member responsible for this deliverable explained that they sent an email to the stakeholder, advising them that the deliverable would not be delivered on time.  What should the project manager have done to avoid this situation?
optionA: Confirmed that the stakeholder was made aware of the delivery delay.
optionB: Communicated with the stakeholder directly regarding the delivery delay.
optionC: Told the team member to send the unfinished deliverable to the stakeholder and finalize it later.
optionD: Ensured that the team member did not communicate directly with the project stakeholder.

question: After sending an on-site meeting invitation to seven people for the kick-off meeting of a project, a key stakeholder declines because they will be at another location for the rest of the month.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Change the kick-off meeting to a virtual meeting so all can attend at the same time.
optionB: Hold the kick-off meeting with the rest of the stakeholders to avoid a delay in the project.
optionC: Reschedule the kick-off meeting for the following month so all can attend on-site.
optionD: Make arrangements for the stakeholder to join the kick-off meeting virtually.

question: At the end of a project, the project manager was asked to provide a performance rating of the project team members.  What should the project manager mainly make reference to?
optionA: Input from project stakeholders
optionB: Feedback from the project sponsor
optionC: Agreed-upon key performance indicators (KPIs)
optionD: Competencies of team members

question: A project manager prepared a project benefits management plan.  Which of the following should be included in this document?
optionA: Strategic alignment, benefits owner, risk register
optionB: Target benefits, benefits owner, lessons learned
optionC: Project requirements, target benefits, issue log, metrics
optionD: Target benefits, strategic alignment, time frame for realizing benefits

question: In a global project, the main definitions were developed in country A, and the delivery of the project will be completed in phases in countries B, C, and D. Country B discovers that one of the legal requirements was not addressed.  What should the project manager have done to avoid this situation?
optionA: Managed risk mitigation strategies specific to each country.
optionB: Asked procurement to assign resources located in each country.
optionC: Selected countries that had similar regulatory requirements.
optionD: Identified the regulatory differences among the countries.

question: In a frequently changing project, the project manager discovers a customer requirement change during a daily meeting. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Escalate to management for approval since the change was not included in the original requirements.
optionB: Tell the customer that the requirement change will be put into the next project phase if management approves.
optionC: Give the change to the scrum master to investigate how much additional effort the change will require.
optionD: Validate the requirement change with the product owner and development team before redefining the scope.

question: A customer is concerned with the quality of the product delivery, as the production deployment is approaching. What should the project manager do next to ensure acceptance of the deliverables?
optionA: Verify the production budget before advancing the product.
optionB: Evaluate the quality checklist for product compliance.
optionC: Review the approved exit criteria for the product.
optionD: Test product integration in accordance with the requirements.

question: A hybrid project has just deployed, and the project manager is planning project closure with lessons learned workshops. A key stakeholder informs the project manager that having the Scrum team in the workshops is a waste of time because the project was delivered successfully.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Invite the Scrum team members as optional participants.
optionB: Ask the Scrum team members to share retrospectives.
optionC: Invite the Scrum team members as mandatory participants.
optionD: Ask the scrum master to attend the workshops.

question: An agile project for a database migration impacts nearly all business units of the corporation. Every effort has been made to complete the migration before the end-of-support date for the database platform. A new impediment now implies the need to continue use of the old platform another year at a higher support price.  What should the product owner do about this situation?
optionA: Reprioritize the backlog based on value and cost of delay divided by duration.
optionB: Switch to a predictive approach to prevent any further delays to completion.
optionC: Reprioritize the backlog based on story size and competence availability.
optionD: Remove low-value items from the backlog to compensate for the higher cost.

question: A project manager is leading a product feature rollout that will gain more subscribers for a video-streaming application. During the backlog grooming phase. the business stakeholders were unable to understand the feature integration with the product and raised concerns.  What can the project manager do to demonstrate the feature integration?
optionA: Include the business stakeholders in the iteration review.
optionB: Involve business stakeholders in the iteration retrospective.
optionC: Create a task for the iteration review and add it to the backlog.
optionD: Review the backlog in detail with the business stakeholders.

question: A company is launching a new product that has to be ready before the summer season begins. After the discovery process, the team realizes that the requirements are very uncertain.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask to include some business subject matter experts (SMEs) in the team.
optionB: Register a risk and define a contingency plan to finish the project on time.
optionC: Assist the team in proposing a minimum viable product (MVP).
optionD: Invite stakeholders to discuss project requirements prioritization.

question: A project team has finished its first iteration out of six. The iteration's delivery performance (velocity) was 50%. During the iteration retrospective, the team realizes that the complexity of the work was underestimated.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Update the issue log and escalate it to the project sponsor.
optionB: Ask the technical manager to help the team with the issue.
optionC: Meet with the team to review internal actions to resolve the situation.
optionD: Ask to replace some team members with more experienced ones.

question: A project manager is reviewing a draft of the project charter with key stakeholders. During the meeting, a conflict occurs between the sponsor and the product owner.  How should the project manager deal with the situation?
optionA: Continue the meeting and ask the project sponsor and product owner to take their discussion offline.
optionB: Continue the meeting and use facilitation techniques to improve communication within the team.
optionC: Postpone the meeting and invite a subject matter expert (SME) to join the next meeting.
optionD: Postpone the meeting and ask the project sponsor and product owner to take their discussion offline.

question: In a daily standup meeting, a developer indicates that a backlog item will not be delivered because they need to take an unexpected leave for the next couple of days. The backlog item is a prerequisite for a feature expected by users in the next sprint review.  What should the project lead do?
optionA: Work with the product owner to change the priorities in the sprint backlog.
optionB: Work with the product owner to inform the users that the feature is delayed.
optionC: Ask the development manager to provide a replacement for a couple of days.
optionD: Ask the developer to postpone the leave until the backlog item is delivered.

question: An organization is transitioning to agile delivery, and a new team has been assembled. A project is not going well because the variation of the team velocity is very high and every sprint delivers less than committed. A new project lead with a strong technical background has been assigned to the project.  What should the project lead do?
optionA: Ask that estimations be provided only by senior developers.
optionB: Recommend a different estimation method in the retrospective.
optionC: Allocate more time for estimation in the sprint planning.
optionD: Review and update the estimations in the daily standup.

question: A project team member just informed the project manager that the license for the software that the team uses to perform calculations has just expired. As a result, the team cannot continue with their project tasks.  What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Issue a formal complaint to the project sponsor claiming a lack of proper tools.
optionB: Ask the team members to find an alternative way to perform calculations.
optionC: Ask the team to fast-track the project and perform tasks that do not require calculations.
optionD: Meet with the IT team to evaluate how fast the software license can be renewed.

question: During a monthly review meeting, a high-performing team member raised a concern about the quality feedback mechanism. The team member expressed that they are not able to deliver high-quality output.  What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Request feedback from stakeholders about the quality delivery.
optionB: Assign the work in consultation with the functional manager.
optionC: Discuss this with the team and review the quality process.
optionD: Assign the work based on the skill sets of team members.

question: A member of the project team always extends discussion topics, taking more time than necessary during project team meetings. Other team members feel this member is not being considerate of their time.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Explain to the team that open discussions are needed but remind the team to follow the ground rules.
optionB: Ask this member to only discuss the current topic to achieve team efficiency.
optionC: Ask the team to accept the input from this particular member as their input may be useful.
optionD: Allow the self-organized team to discuss the situation among themselves and come to a resolution.

question: A project manager is working on a software development project for an oil and gas client using an agile approach. The project manager is having difficulty preparing the schedule because the project has various unknowns.  Which scheduling method should the project manager use to develop the schedule?
optionA: Analogous scheduling
optionB: Three-point scheduling
optionC: Iterative scheduling
optionD: Parametric scheduling

question: A company recently adopted agile to develop innovation projects. The project manager is experiencing problems with some team members who consider some agile ceremonies to be unnecessary.  What should the project manager have done before the beginning of the project?
optionA: Prepared an inception deck and clearly explained the purpose of agile ceremonies and their benefits to the project.
optionB: Discussed with the project sponsor about convincing the team to adopt the agile ceremonies as part of their routine.
optionC: Discussed with the product owner and requested assistance by requiring the adoption of agile ceremonies.
optionD: Conducted a survey to determine if the team was willing to adopt agile ceremonies on the current project.

question: A company routinely outsources resources for specific core activities. Due to a sudden, unforeseen risk, all of the team members are needed to work remotely, including the outsourced ones.  How can the project manager address this challenge to assure outsourced vendors deliver?
optionA: Develop a new strategy for communication and management of resources.
optionB: Review the risk management plan for the mitigation activities.
optionC: Review the coordination and communication costs with the supplier.
optionD: Submit a change request to increase the contingency budget.

question: A project is on its second iteration out of six. The team realizes that a key deliverable will depend on the acquisition of a new device.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Invite the stakeholders to discuss prioritization of a new deliverable.
optionB: Detail the reason for the deliverable delay in the status report.
optionC: Register a risk and escalate it to the project sponsor.
optionD: Include the responsibility for acquisition with the core team.

question: A project manager works in a matrix organization and is managing an internal software development project that is intended to reduce conflicts in the company's internal tracking system. During development, the project manager is informed that the software has to account for an unexpected change to government accounting requirements. The development team was able to make the change with no additional cost; however, the project manager notices that the testing costs are beginning to exceed the testing budget.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the project sponsor to allocate funds from the contingency reserve to fund the additional testing.
optionB: Conduct a cost-benefit analysis to determine if the funds can be reallocated from the development team.
optionC: Submit a change request to the cost baseline through the governance process to fund the additional testing.
optionD: Update the basis of estimates and the cost management plan to track the additional funding required for testing.

question: A project manager schedules virtual daily standup meetings for a project, but half of the team members regularly join late or miss the meeting all together. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Discuss ground rules with the team that will include daily meetings.
optionB: Agree on a new time and reschedule the daily standups.
optionC: Use one-to-one virtual meetings because they are more efficient.
optionD: Ask senior management for coaching regarding this situation.

question: A project manager is well informed on the industry standards of the organization and believes that they are not reflected in the project deliverables. What should the project manager review next?
optionA: Organizational process assets (OPAs)
optionB: Quality process
optionC: Project charter
optionD: Quality management plan

question: A project manager is assigned to a multiyear project. During project execution, the customer delegates a new representative who contacts the project manager directly with a concern about their participation in status meetings. The representative wants to contact team members directly.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Send the new representative the approved project management and communications management plans.
optionB: Reach out to the customer directly for assistance in incorporating the new representative into the project management plan.
optionC: Meet with the new representative to determine their understanding of the project and address their concerns.
optionD: Meet with the project sponsor to discuss how to incorporate the new representative in the project.

question: A team is preparing the closing phase and building a plan for the next phase. One of the project sponsors is complaining that the last phase had some quality deliverable issues. However, the quality acceptance document was signed.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Postpone the next project phase until the impact of the quality issues is assessed.
optionB: Reopen the quality acceptance documentation to add the sponsor's complaints.
optionC: Schedule a quality review meeting and include the sponsor's complaints.
optionD: Review best practices and lessons learned and apply them to the project plan.

question: A project manager is tasked with developing a coaching model to support and recognize team members' growth.  What should the project manager consider when defining their coaching strategy?
optionA: Individual and personal objectives
optionB: Organization's strategic goals
optionC: Established patterns of communication
optionD: Project team's shared objectives

question: A team realizes that there is no access to data that the project depends on to complete the current iteration. This dependency was known; however, the team is unsure of the available options to remove this obstacle.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Move the dependent task to the next iteration.
optionB: Guide the team to determine alternatives.
optionC: Escalate the issue to the company's IT manager.
optionD: Escalate the issue to the project sponsor.

question: An internal virtual team is meeting daily to review iteration progress, as well as to conduct other technical and follow-up calls with key stakeholders. The team seems to be disengaged.  How should the project manager approach this situation?
optionA: Reduce the number of internal and external meetings.
optionB: Schedule one-to-one meetings and team-building meetings.
optionC: Review team assignments and reduce the workload.
optionD: Give the team members a few days off to reduce stress_

question: A major public-transportation construction project is aimed at significantly reducing emissions. The project has been severely delayed due to noncompliance with environmental codes and bylaws.  What should the project manager have done to prevent this?
optionA: Appointed a senior environmental compliance officer to report directly to the project manager.
optionB: Approached the regulator for a partial waiver in light of the environmental importance of the project.
optionC: Incorporated sufficient schedule reserves based on similar delays in past projects.
optionD: Mapped environmental compliance requirements, identified risks to achieving them, and prepared mitigations.

question: Project acceptance criteria include on-site training for the new users of a system. Due to unforeseen circumstances, all team members have to work remotely for an indefinite period of time.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Reschedule on-site training to online sessions.
optionB: Document the project issue and provide options.
optionC: Create a risk and assign remediation actions.
optionD: Cancel all of the on-site training sessions.

question: A project manager is leading a software development project that will assist in maintenance management for a power plant. The project manager is analyzing project performance data and trying to forecast if the project will have any slippage in the future.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Perform schedule analysis.
optionB: Perform quality control analysis.
optionC: Perform trend analysis.
optionD: Perform root cause analysis (RCA).

question: A project has been reporting a declining schedule performance index (SPI) for the past four reviews. No corrective action is under development, and the project team does not seem concerned.  What should the project manager do first to address the SPI trend?
optionA: Notify the project stakeholders that the scope needs to be reduced in order to hold the costs within budget.
optionB: Engage with the project team to create a plan that will deliver benefits on a defined and incremental basis.
optionC: Contact the project sponsor to let them know you require more resources to meet the schedule.
optionD: Meet with the project scheduler to rebaseline the project using a more realistic schedule.

question: A highly critical project is in jeopardy due to missing professional resources.  What should the newly assigned project manager do first?
optionA: Find available professionals within the organization to fill the gaps.
optionB: Determine the possibility for team members to split up the required tasks.
optionC: Allocate funding for seeking external professionals to fill the gaps.
optionD: Request additional budget for team training for the missing expertise.

question: Travel restrictions are suddenly imposed during a project's execution. The team members reside in different geographic locations.  What should the project manager do next to address this issue?
optionA: Obtain and implement the sponsor's recommendations for a solution.
optionB: Ask the team members to proceed independently while examining needs and alternatives.
optionC: Place a hold on activities until the team can resume the work on-site.
optionD: Halt all processes until procurement and implementation of solutions are completed.

question: A project team is performing a post-release evaluation of a product that requires detailed feedback from seven stakeholders. Six of the stakeholders have promptly provided feedback. One of them has not provided any feedback despite numerous requests from the team.  What should the project manager do in this situation?
optionA: Explain to the sponsor why the reluctant stakeholder needs to provide feedback.
optionB: Host a meeting with the reluctant stakeholder and project team to resolve any conflict.
optionC: Meet with all seven of the project stakeholders and request all of their feedback.
optionD: Schedule a meeting with the reluctant project stakeholder to obtain their feedback.

question: A stressful situation has presented some challenges for the team. The project manager notices stress behavior in some of the team members, and it is beginning to spread across the group. The project manager needs to coach the team to change their mindset in order to be more efficient.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ensure that people care about each other and work effectively together through effective team management.
optionB: Create an environment of respect and fairness so the team can increase their project performance in stressful situations.
optionC: Establish a productive environment where all team members can assist one another with the workload.
optionD: Meet with the team to discuss the correct, expected behavior in stressful situations and start practicing it.

question: A project is starting its sixth iteration out seven. During the daily meeting, a team member explains that a key function will take longer to complete than originally anticipated.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask for help to increase the team capacity to deliver on time.
optionB: Ask for a project extension to deliver the committed scope.
optionC: Update the issue log and escalate the problem to the project sponsor.
optionD: Review the options and possible solutions with the project team.

question: A project charter has been approved and the project manager has been assigned to the project. The project manager is currently working with the project team to subdivide the project work packages.  What is the project manager doing?
optionA: Resource leveling
optionB: Work breakdown structure (WBS)
optionC: Decomposition
optionD: Network diagram

question: A large matrix organization is adopting a new communications approach. This is necessary because their projects often require the resourcing of expert knowledge in the form of specialists from various departments and divisions.  What should the project manager do to set up effective communications?
optionA: Focus on the recipients' needs and not the information itself.
optionB: Use the highest possible technical language and avoid using metaphors.
optionC: Ensure that messages sent to the recipients are delivered.
optionD: Plan on transmitting the information in an easily understandable manner.

question: A project manager is working on a unique project that is dissimilar to the project nature of the organization. The project manager is tailoring the artifacts for this new project.  Who should determine which artifacts should be used in the project?
optionA: The project stakeholders should meet and determine the project artifacts to be used by the project manager and the project management team.
optionB: The project manager and project management team should use the standard project artifacts from the database.
optionC: The project sponsor should select the project artifacts that the project manager and project management team should use in the project.
optionD: The project manager and the project management team should select the appropriate artifacts for use in the specific project.

question: An organization is using a hybrid delivery approach for a business project. The product owner, the person who was also managing the project, was promoted to a more senior role. A new project lead has joined the project.  Which artifact should the project lead use to ensure that the project benefits have been identified?
optionA: Statement of work (SOW)
optionB: Business case
optionC: Product backlog
optionD: Solution architecture

question: A multiyear resource constraint project is midway through the execution phase. During a progress update meeting, it has been determined that there might be a schedule delay to deliver the project. The project manager has observed that all of the team members are working hard and lots of deliverables have already been completed.  What should the project manager do immediately about this situation?
optionA: Register the schedule risk and present the new resources requirement to the change management board for schedule recovery.
optionB: Prepare a monthly report by highlighting the completed deliverables and communicate the delay to management.
optionC: Ask the project planner to identify the critical path and respective delayed activities, and then investigate the reasons for the delay.
optionD: Ask the scheduler to update the schedule with the percent of work in progress (WIP) and communicate the results to the team.

question: An organization embarking on a significant transformation initiated a project to improve and document business processes. One of the objectives of the project is to implement agile project delivery.  What is the main reason for adopting agile?
optionA: Projects will be completed faster, saving time and money.
optionB: Projects will be delivered with very low risk to the organization.
optionC: Projects will deliver early and use value based on priority.
optionD: Projects will be delivered with significant cost savings.

question: A company has appointed a supplier to deliver software and has assigned an internal project manager. The supplier states that no technical development or testing is required from the customer. The project manager would like to confirm this with all of the stakeholders.  What should the internal project manager do first?
optionA: Host an alignment session with stakeholders to formalize the project requirements.
optionB: Develop a user acceptance testing plan to ensure the quality of the deliverables.
optionC: Communicate to the supplier that customer testing is required.
optionD: Distribute the project plan to all of the interested parties.

question: A distributed project team has communication issues because of their collaboration tools. The team feels that efficiency could be improved by changing the collaboration platform.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Implement the communication tools used by other project teams.
optionB: Escalate the issue to the sponsor and ask them to decide.
optionC: Inform the project team to continue using the current tools.
optionD: Discuss this with the project team and select the appropriate tools.

question: A few developers have identified a list of impediments at the daily standup and are asking for the project lead's assistance in prioritizing them. There are a few complex backlog items, and a new junior tester has identified a few compliance defects. The product owner and a couple of developers will be leaving the project team, and the contract with the test and production support partner will not be renewed.  Which issue should the project lead focus on first?
optionA: Recruiting, onboarding, and training new developers.
optionB: Finding a new product owner to prioritize the product backlog.
optionC: Developing a new contract for production support.
optionD: Regulatory compliance issues discussed in the meeting.

question: A project manager is leading a project when a key stakeholder requests additional work that is not in the scope. The stakeholder is also concerned that the project sponsors may not approve and fund the additional change in scope.  What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Discuss the requested change with the sponsor.
optionB: Evaluate the cost of the additional requested work.
optionC: Discuss the requested change with the team.
optionD: Evaluate the impact and submit a change request.

question: A project manager has just received communication from an operational functional manager to complete an additional scope item for a project that was formally closed a few weeks ago. The scope looks relatively small and simple to handle as part of the daily operations activity.  How should the project manager deal with this request?
optionA: Check the alternative resources available in the organization for the request.
optionB: Confirm that the budget and resources are available to execute the work request.
optionC: Evaluate the nature of the request and plan communication accordingly.
optionD: Submit a change request and allocate the budget and resources needed for execution.

question: A new team member has joined a project team. During the first sprint, the new team member approached the project manager and requested to implement a new way of testing. The team has been resistant to the proposed change.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the new team member to focus only on development and not do the testing.
optionB: Coach the new team member to conduct the testing the way it has always been done for this project.
optionC: Schedule a meeting with the new team member to learn about the new method of testing.
optionD: Request that the new team member do the testing the way it has always been done for this project.

question: A steering committee member is complaining about the weekly report. They stated that the report is too long and has unnecessary details. As a result, they are unable to obtain the main message and take action.  What should the project manager do to avoid similar complaints?
optionA: Send a shorter daily report to this steering committee member.
optionB: Demonstrate the weekly reports in a presentation for the steering committee member.
optionC: Verify the information needed for steering committee members.
optionD: Present the status at a weekly meeting with the steering committee.

question: All project team members refer to the project manager for various decisions. This causes delays for some tasks. as the project manager is usually preoccupied in meetings throughout the day.  What should the project manager do to prevent these delays?
optionA: Meet with the team in 2 weeks to respond to all of the open tasks.
optionB: Review the Pareto diagram to identify the source of delays.
optionC: Delegate the decision-making authority of some tasks to the team.
optionD: Consolidate the decision-making authority to remain with the project manager.

question: A customer is concerned about the time required to complete a project and is asking the project team to reduce the number of iterations required to complete the product.  Which approach should the project manager take?
optionA: Ask the team to raise blockers or impediments in daily meetings.
optionB: Prioritize the tasks with high risks to reduce the number of iterations required.
optionC: Ask the team to challenge the project estimations for a faster delivery.
optionD: Prioritize deliverables based on business value and define frequent releases.

question: A human resource (HR) acquisition process for a large project has recently changed. One major process change includes the approval of the financial manager and the recruitment manager. This change to the process implies longer processing. The project urgently needs new resources.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the financial manager to delay implementation due to potential project delays and penalties.
optionB: Assess the impact of the change and review the project management plan for next steps.
optionC: Adapt the resource management plan and ask for financial approval before sending it to the customer.
optionD: Review the project schedule to determine which technique will reduce impact on project duration.

question: At the end of a project's initiation phase, the budget was developed and sent to the approval board. During the approval meeting, one of the key stakeholders asked how the budget was developed for future uncertainties.  How should the project manager reply?
optionA: Probabilistic analysis was used to develop the budget to address future uncertainties.
optionB: The budget was developed by using the lessons learned from previous project data.
optionC: Recurrent team meetings are planned to control the budget against future uncertainties.
optionD: Feedback from stakeholders will be addressed at each board meeting to adapt the budget.

question: A project team member is sick and will not be able to return to the project for a few weeks. During the daily meeting, the team shares their concerns as the sick team member was the only one skilled in the component they were developing.  What should the project manager have done to prevent this?
optionA: Facilitated cross-functional knowledge transfer during the project.
optionB: Acquired more than one resource skilled in each component.
optionC: Outsourced development of the specific component to another team.
optionD: Requested robust documentation for the component's build.

question: A key stakeholder who is highly involved in the project claims that the reports sent by the project team are inadequate. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Explain to the stakeholder that these are the approved templates for the reports.
optionB: Ask the project team to review and modify all of these reports.
optionC: Ensure that the reports comply with the communications management plan.
optionD: Ask the sponsor to meet with the stakeholder to diffuse the situation with the reports.

question: A company's key product is evolving and requires the use of a new technology. No one on the team is familiar with this technology; however, experienced developers on the team volunteered to study the concepts and application and believe they will be able to take full responsibility for the new technology.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Outsource the technology work to a third party so as not to delay work.
optionB: Descope this requirement as the developers have more important tasks.
optionC: Hire externally since the internal developers already have assigned work.
optionD: Support the developers with their intention to learn the new technology.

question: Contract terms used during the tender phase for a new power-generation facility must be revised before signing with the successful bidder because the terms of the tender have been amended to accommodate the new financial regulations on company tax.  Which approach should the project manager take to implement this amendment?
optionA: Sign the contract as per the original terms but allow the successful bidder to submit a new contract price.
optionB: Discuss the new terms with the successful bidder to assess its impact on the contract price.
optionC: Retender the entire scope because the terms of the contract have changed significantly.
optionD: Amend the contract terms and sign a revised contract with the successful bidder.

question: A project manager is managing an agile project for the first time. Early on, the project manager discovers the team is struggling to agree on the scope of a feature during a sprint.  How should the project manager help the team resolve the issue?
optionA: Direct the senior-most member to determine the scope on behalf of the team.
optionB: Encourage the team to collaborate to resolve their understanding of the feature.
optionC: Ask the team to log the story in the product backlog and move on to the next feature.
optionD: Discuss this with the team and decide what the scope of the feature should be

question: A project manager is leading a hybrid project and is collaborating with the client to develop the project contract. Some delays have been experienced due to unforeseen technical difficulties and new dependencies. However, the project manager is optimistic about recovering the delays in the upcoming sprints. A key stakeholder asked the project manager if the contract deadlines can be met.  What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Clarify the current work progress, causes for delays, existing risks, and planned corrective actions.
optionB: Ask the stakeholder to remain calm and confirm that they are participating in all team meetings.
optionC: Study the contract terms and deadlines to ensure they are not under risk and confirm them with the stakeholder.
optionD: Submit a request for extra time and budget related to the dependencies and technical difficulties.

question: A large global organization developed a new medical implant that requires compliance with local government regulations. The approval process for one country is lengthy and will impact the intended launch date.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Organize an online distribution channel from another country.
optionB: Ask the sponsor to authorize the launch and then wait for approval.
optionC: Ask the board to use their influence and speed up the approval.
optionD: Work with the team to find ways to bypass the regulations.

question: A project manager notices that a new junior team member's suggestions are constantly rejected by senior team members. The senior team members find the suggestions valid and innovative, but unrealistic. Following several project assignments, the senior members request to have the junior team member removed.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Remove possible conflicts from future project assignments.
optionB: Accept the demands and remove the junior team member.
optionC: Group the new team members together for training purposes.
optionD: Encourage further and deeper discussions among team members.

question: A project manager is leading a project with strict time constraints. In team meetings, one of the team members is always silent. The project manager determines that this team member is not knowledgeable about the technology solution. The project manager is concerned that this problem will impact productivity.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Arrange formal training for this member to gain sufficient knowledge to reduce the impact on team performance.
optionB: Assign an experienced team member to work with this member on a daily basis in order to become knowledgeable about the technology.
optionC: Let the team lead the meeting discussions so that every member has a chance to prepare and speak up.
optionD: Let this team member understand the urgency and encourage them to spend extra time to become knowledgeable about the technology.

question: A project manager is assigned to a new project. The project is for a new product that the company wants to launch as soon as possible to test market readiness. The project is part of a large business transformation, and the objective is to open delivery channels for the new product.  Which delivery approach should the project manager recommend?
optionA: A predictive approach with an experienced project team.
optionB: An adaptive approach with clearly defined user stories.
optionC: An adaptive approach with loosely defined large epics.
optionD: A predictive approach with clear acceptance criteria.

question: A project management office (PMO) director finds that the project managers leading software development projects are not consistently seeking approval from other division leaders in cybersecurity and operations before deploying code into production. The PMO director asks the project manager to develop a solution for this issue.  What should the project manager do to fix this problem?
optionA: Create a new policy requiring project managers to email division leaders before deploying code into production.
optionB: Establish a daily scrum meeting and invite division leaders to attend so they can be aware of upcoming code releases.
optionC: Provide division leaders with a teleconference phone number to call if they have concerns after code is deployed into production.
optionD: Launch an enterprise governance structure comprised of division leaders to establish policies for code releases.

question: A project manager is part of an organization that is assessing the use of agile delivery approaches. A new project management office (PMO) manager who had a bad experience with a Scrum approach recommended that the project board replace Scrum with a predictive approach.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Review the communications management plan to identify new stakeholders.
optionB: Define a risk management plan for the new approach, as needed.
optionC: Define a project management plan for the new approach, as needed.
optionD: Review the benefits realization plan to include the cost of the change.

question: A project team is trying to meet the milestone target dates in order to receive a bonus promised by the project sponsor. Unforeseen challenges and poor communication among the team members resulted in mistakes and delays. Tensions are high, and the sponsor is concerned.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Schedule a team-building activity to boost the team's morale.
optionB: Discuss with the team how the project objectives can be met.
optionC: Request that the sponsor increase the bonus for high performers.
optionD: Organize a team meeting to remind the team of the ground rules.

question: A project manager holds periodic progress review meetings to discuss issues.  What should the project manager do first on the agenda?
optionA: Elaborate the risk mitigation strategy and risk register.
optionB: Update resolution approaches and action assignments.
optionC: Formulate project management plan integration.
optionD: Produce lessons learned documentation.

question: A project manager has recently been assigned to a new project. When the project manager first meets the project team, the team tells the project manager that all of the management plans and documents for the project are missing.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Continue working on scheduled tasks to avoid delaying the project and leave the development of project artifacts for later.
optionB: Ask the stakeholders to develop all of the project artifacts so the project team can continue their scheduled activities.
optionC: Adapt the project management plans and documents from previous executed projects in order to save time.
optionD: Create the project management plans with the project team and share the documents with the stakeholders.

question: During the early phase of a project, the requirements documentation was not approved. It was identified that the leader of a user party was not included in any of the requirements collection communications.  Which of the documents was likely missed or outdated?
optionA: Stakeholder Register
optionB: Risk Register
optionC: Project Charter
optionD: Business Documentation

question: A project manager is managing the transition to operations. The project sponsor wants to ensure that good support is provided to the end users.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ensure that comprehensive documentation is handed over.
optionB: Ask the project team to provide operational support for 1 year.
optionC: Ensure that knowledge is transferred to the operations team.
optionD: Ensure that the user guide is detailed and has clear instructions.

question: A project with a hard timeline is starting its first iteration out of six. The project team is lacking the necessary skills to execute.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Add a subject matter expert (SME) to the project team.
optionB: Fill the skill gap personally to execute the project.
optionC: Allow the team to proceed as they attempt to meet the timeline.
optionD: Invite stakeholders to discuss a mitigation plan to finish on time.

question: Project stakeholders are engaged in a discussion on how to achieve the best user experience in the design of a new application. The agile team is divided on the approach. The conflict is more of a collective disagreement than an outright conflict.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Apply appropriate conflict resolution techniques to solve the issue.
optionB: Engage in individual conversation with each team member.
optionC: Call a team meeting to have a formal discussion of the issue.
optionD: Allow the team to work through it on their own unless help is needed.

question: A project team has been working together for about 2 years. One of the team members has consistently shown high performance and stood out among their peers during the execution of the project.  How should the project manager recognize high performance?
optionA: Acknowledge the high-performing team member in the next team meeting.
optionB: Thank the team member privately to avoid conflict among the team members.
optionC: Ask the sponsor to approve a bonus for the high-performing team member.
optionD: Choose a reward for the team member that aligns with their personal goals.

question: In the middle of an iteration, an agile team working on the development of a new product was notified that an important team member will leave the project for a few weeks due to some urgent personal issues. What should the project manager do regarding the activities that were the responsibility of this team member?
optionA: Reach an agreement with the team on how to handle the situation.
optionB: Allow senior management to decide how to proceed with the project.
optionC: Reach out to the procurement team to hire a substitute for the team member.
optionD: Convince the team member not to leave until the project is completed.

question: During execution of a complex project, the project manager encounters numerous change requests from various teams. These changes may result in the project not meeting its objectives.  How should the project manager ensure that these changes are managed effectively?
optionA: Record the changes using the risk register and continue monitoring.
optionB: Include the changes in the backlog and review priorities with the product owner.
optionC: Deny the change requests and keep delivering the project as planned.
optionD: Review the project and communications management plan with the main stakeholder.

question: A project manager is in the process of closing out a project and has been asked by the project management office (PMO) to confirm that the transfer of knowledge to the operations team for support operations has been successfully completed.  Which technique should the project manager apply to verify the knowledge transfer?
optionA: Regression analysis
optionB: Meetings
optionC: Expert judgment
optionD: Brainstorming

question: While a project manager is trying to build the first baseline for a project, a change request is being sent from one of the functional managers.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Apply for a formal change control board (CCB) approval.
optionB: Discuss this with the functional manager and related parties.
optionC: Reject the functional manager's change request immediately.
optionD: Analyze the impact of the change request on the project.

question: A critical project milestone was missed because one of the team members did not complete their tasks on time. This resulted in a heated discussion during a demonstration for the end users.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Discuss the issue with the team member in a one-on-one meeting.
optionB: Escalate the performance issue to the team member's functional manager.
optionC: Ask the team member to justify the delay during a team meeting.
optionD: Review the human resources (HR) policies for relevant corrective actions.

question: A project team member identified a procurement risk and sent an email to the project sponsor highlighting the risk. The sponsor forwarded the email to the project manager asking for further details. After speaking with the sponsor, the project manager decided to take preventive action_  Which document should the project manager review with their team?
optionA: Quality management plan
optionB: Communications management plan
optionC: Risk management plan
optionD: Procurement management plan

question: A project manager is leading a cross-departmental project that involves many stakeholders. During the project, the project manager observes that the stakeholders are diverse and have different expectations about how the project should be handled. This leads to frequent confusion and misunderstandings among the stakeholders.  What should the project manager do to integrate the diverse stakeholder groups?
optionA: Develop a joint quality policy for the project and seek a commitment by all of the departments.
optionB: Analyze the probability and impact of the risks linked with the situation and implement the proper response plan.
optionC: Hold separate meetings with the individual stakeholders and escalate their concerns to the project sponsor.
optionD: Advise the team members to focus on project work and avoid getting distracted by the stakeholders' disagreements.

question: A project manager was informed by their supplier that there will be an upcoming raw material shortage due to a regulatory change.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Seek advice from the legal department and implement penalties.
optionB: Search for a new supplier that can deliver the same materials on time.
optionC: Tell the supplier that they have an obligation to supply the raw material.
optionD: Assess the possible impact of the raw material shortage on the project.

question: A key stakeholder is refusing to participate in a crucial project stage and disagrees with the project team's approach. This situation is affecting the project team's morale.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the project team to meet and document why the stakeholder's approach is incorrect.
optionB: Schedule a meeting with the project team and the key stakeholder as soon as possible to discuss and agree on an approach.
optionC: Discuss the issue with the project team during a project status meeting and request that they change the approach.
optionD: Ask the project sponsor to meet with the project team and key stakeholder to discuss the approach.

question: A project manager is leading a project in an organization that has a functional structure. The project manager has been informed by the team that the tasks related to the purchase of services are taking too long, as the purchasing department has other priorities.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the project team to keep developing other tasks that do not depend on the purchase of services.
optionB: Meet with the purchasing manager to find the source of the delays and agree on a purchasing schedule.
optionC: Request that the purchasing tasks be outsourced through an existing purchasing vendor.
optionD: Modify the project schedule to accommodate the delays in the purchase of services.

question: A project is on its fourth iteration out of six. During iteration planning, a team member informs the project manager that their computer is not working.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Suggest that the team member contact the IT department.
optionB: Update the issue log and escalate the problem to the product owner.
optionC: Ask the other team members to step in and do the work.
optionD: Facilitate a priority resolution of the issue with the IT department.

question: A project manager was recently assigned to rescue a high-priority project for an Olympic facility. The project is behind schedule. with a heavy contractual penalty. The former project manager had numerous conflicts with the project team members and a few stakeholders.  What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Review the lessons learned register with the former project manager in a private meeting.
optionB: Meet the project team to assert authority and reassign the project tasks for a timely delivery.
optionC: Review the project schedule and ask for the contingency reserve to crash the project.
optionD: Meet the project team and stakeholders to identify the root cause of the issue and develop a solution.

question: A new project needs to be submitted for urgent funding approval. The project, which will use a new technology, is vital to the organization. The entire Scrum team has worked together for over 3 years on multiple projects and delivered the previous project under the approved budget.  Which estimation technique should the project manager implement in this context?
optionA: Definitive estimate
optionB: Order of magnitude
optionC: Budget estimate
optionD: Story points

question: A project requires the procurement of a large amount of equipment that needs to be on-site before any other activity can begin. The procurement department has a lengthy approval process.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Contact the vendor that supplied similar equipment for a previous project.
optionB: Use the existing equipment and replace it later with the new equipment.
optionC: Ask the project sponsor to expedite the vendor selection process.
optionD: Work with the procurement team to find alternative options.

question: An organization that embraced agile a couple of years ago is looking for a more efficient way to ensure that the increments produced in each sprint meet the end users' quality requirements.  What should the project lead recommend?
optionA: Develop a more comprehensive template for the definition of done (DoD).
optionB: Establish a quality assurance (QA) team separate from the development team.
optionC: Organize more frequent sprint reviews with a broader audience.
optionD: Increase the percentage allocated for testing each backlog item.

question: A project manager has just been appointed to a project that has two major deliverables. Both deliverables have the same level of priority and are to be delivered at the same time. The members of the team are complaining about the lack of information regarding which deliverable needs to be finished first.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Meet with the project sponsor and key stakeholders to assess each deliverable's value to the organization and set execution priorities.
optionB: Ask key stakeholders to cancel the project due to the difficulty of executing both deliverables at the same time.
optionC: Ask the team to start working on the easiest deliverable first so they gain experience to execute the second deliverable.
optionD: Require that the project team execute both deliverables at the same time, since this was requested and approved in the project charter.

question: During the execution of a project, an experienced team member informs the project manager that they cannot take part in all of the scheduled project activities due to a conflicting operational schedule.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Encourage the team member to prioritize scheduled project activities.
optionB: Replace the team member with another available resource on the team.
optionC: Discuss the situation with the team member's functional manager to see if the schedule can be adjusted.
optionD: Check with the project management office (PMO) on the available resources to complete the activities.

question: A project manager is working on a large IT project. During a review for one of the deliverables. a stakeholder raised a concern about the final product.  What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Discuss this with the team and put the stakeholder's concern in the issue log.
optionB: Set up a meeting with the sponsor to discuss the details of the deliverable.
optionC: Discuss this with the team and review the project requirements documentation.
optionD: Set up a meeting with the product owner to discuss the stakeholder's concern.

question: A large project requires new equipment to support the project execution. The procurement manager communicated to the project manager that the delivery of the newly purchased equipment will be delayed. The project manager is concerned that this will directly effect the project schedule.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Update the sponsor of the potential issue and ask for any suggestions.
optionB: Validate the information and update the risk management plan.
optionC: Source second-hand equipment in order to prepare for any delivery delays.
optionD: Update the risk register and discuss it with the project stakeholders.

question: A project manager is leading a project team composed of members with varying levels of knowledge and experience. Some are experts and some have less than 1 year of experience. The project schedule was approved by the steering committee.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the less-experienced members to perform tasks exactly as they are instructed by the experienced members.
optionB: Ask each experienced member to be the mentor to one of the less-experienced members.
