optionD: Convince senior management to introduce rewards to resisting departments.

question: During a project to develop a new pharmaceutical product, the project manager was informed that there has been a change in government regulations regarding the materials of the project. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Update the contingency plan to take this issue into account.
optionB: Meet with the stakeholders to update the risk register and risk management plan.
optionC: Study the new regulations with the team and evaluate if there is any impact on the project variables.
optionD: Review the procurement documentation and modify requirements as needed.

question: A globally distributed project team is running behind schedule due to the lack of team commitment and low morale. In order to bring the schedule back on track, what should the project manager do first?
optionA: Set up a meeting to perform a root cause analysis.
optionB: Permanently colocate the team for better performance.
optionC: Update the issue log and communicate it to the team.
optionD: Seek the sponsor's approval to extend the project schedule.

question: A company has transitioned and is now delivering projects using a hybrid approach instead of a predictive approach. The distributed project team's knowledge of agile is varied. The project manager feels this new methodology will impact the timely delivery of the project.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Use the predictive approach for team members who are not knowledgeable in agile project delivery practices.
optionB: Ask to execute the project with a predictive approach since there is a budget and schedule risk.
optionC: Use crashing to reduce the critical path to ensure enough buffer to include the impact of the agile methodology update.
optionD: Plan for training on agile tools and techniques used in the defined hybrid methodology for consistent application by all team members.

question: A new relevant project stakeholder suggested a change to some of the project parameters midway through execution. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Reject the change because it is contrary to what was agreed to during earlier phases of the project.
optionB: Transfer the change to the steering committee for them to evaluate and decide the appropriate next steps.
optionC: Evaluate the proposed change with integrated change controls and discuss the change with the project sponsor.
optionD: Accept the change and use contingency funds to implement this change with minimal schedule impacts.

question: A project manager just finished a meeting to identify the main stakeholders of the project. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Analyze the stakeholders.
optionB: Monitor all stakeholders.
optionC: Keep all stakeholders informed.
optionD: Engage the stakeholders.

question: In a functional organization, a product analyst is assigned to a short-duration application development effort. The analyst expresses concerns about the task and asks the project manager to provide the support of a peer with expertise in this domain.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Enroll the analyst in a capacity-building program, and keep this analyst assigned to the task.
optionB: Recognize the analyst's concerns and reassign the task to another team member.
optionC: Ask the analyst to use skills to develop the tool, then move development to another team member.
optionD: Make sure the analyst has regular pairing meetings with the other team member throughout task execution.

question: A project manager works in an organization that wants to implement agile methods. Traditionally, the project progress was communicated via a weekly email to stakeholders. The development team uses a burndown chart and a kanban board to visualize progress.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Use the burndown chart and the kanban board as an auxiliary communication channel.
optionB: Provide access to the burndown chart and kanban board and ask stakeholders to use them.
optionC: Organize training for all stakeholders on the burndown chart and kanban board.
optionD: Continue using only the traditional communication channels with external stakeholders.

question: A customer requests additional changes 1 day before the planned change date. How should the project manager respond to the change request?
optionA: Reject the changes as the lead time is too short.
optionB: Check if the changes are covered in the statement of work (SOW).
optionC: Determine whether the project team is capable of making the changes.
optionD: Review the additional changes and perform integrated change control.

question: A company is transitioning from a predictive approach to an agile approach. A project manager is assigned to the first pilot with an inexperienced team. Due to an unexpected event, the whole team is asked to work remotely. During the second sprint, the project manager starts to notice a lack of commitment from the team members.  What should the project manager do in this situation as a servant leader?
optionA: Coach team members to increase their engagement and collaboration.
optionB: Request an exception to allow the team to return to work on-site.
optionC: Force the team to attend the daily standups to gather the project status.
optionD: Allow the team to address the problem as a self-organized team.

question: An agile team has been assigned to a project that mandates the implementation of changes to key government products. The team has been given 6 months to fulfill this mandate.  What should the team lead do next?
optionA: Create the project charter and statement of work (SOW) to estimate the changes and the scope of the change.
optionB: Create all of the stories just for the next sprint and skip the epics until the next sprint.
optionC: Create all of the stories needed to fulfill this change, document them in the backlog, and prioritize them according to business value.
optionD: Create the epics at a high level for the requirements and begin grooming sessions.

question: A project manager has been assigned to a hybrid project. The project manager needs to ensure all team members are collaborating and are aware of the project's ongoing changes.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Encourage collaboration on a daily basis, facilitating different communication channels.
optionB: Distribute a project newsletter that includes any project changes and required project information.
optionC: Meet daily with the project team and include a monthly report on the risks and issues.
optionD: Send out daily emails with the project status and task lists to all team members.

question: A project leader is assigned to a new project and is asked to assemble an effective five-member agile team. If the project leader has no restrictions, which team should they choose?
optionA: A team whose members have more general aptitudes and can collaborate on different tasks
optionB: A team whose members work independently and are the best subject matter experts (SMES)
optionC: A team whose members have more general aptitudes but like to work individually
optionD: A team whose members have different skill sets and are spread out geographically

question: A project manager is leading the first agile project for the organization. During the kick-off meeting, the project manager notices that the team does not have the same understanding about agile approaches. The project manager is concerned about the impact of that confusion.  What should the project manager do to address this situation?
optionA: Evaluate the possibility of managing this project using a predictive approach.
optionB: Mentor the team to explain agile principles and create a shared understanding.
optionC: Hire a functional manager who is familiar with agile methodologies.
optionD: Submit a change request for a new team that has agile experience.

question: The project manager's firm is executing a construction project. The project is stalled due to reemerging conflicts and misunderstandings among stakeholders.  What should the project manager do to ensure a smooth start and completion of the project?
optionA: Invite all the stakeholders to a change control board (CCB) meeting, share feedback and facts, and come to a consensus.
optionB: Advise the firm to cancel the project due to misunderstandings among the stakeholders and the associated risks.
optionC: Conduct an on-site survey, start the project to avoid any undue delays, and ensure costs are under control.
optionD: Determine the root cause of the misunderstandings, get all parties to reach a consensus, and help to implement the outcome.

question: A project manager has been assigned to take over an existing software project. The project manager inherited a lean team comprised of key stakeholders, subject matter experts (SMEs), and senior developers. While reviewing the project status with the team, the project manager observes that the team seems to lack direction and enthusiasm.  What should the new project manager do?
optionA: Encourage participation in decision making and empower the team.
optionB: Ensure everyone performs their assigned tasks as planned.
optionC: Meet with the project sponsor and propose a corrective action for the project.
optionD: Organize frequent team building sessions and update the risk register.

question: A project manager implementing a hybrid project is dealing with multiple stakeholders in a rapidly changing business environment. How should the project manager ensure that the needs of stakeholders are consistently met?
optionA: Add more iterative techniques to improve stakeholder learning.
optionB: Use iterative life cycles involving stakeholders to enable the team to improve the product end result through successive prototypes.
optionC: Identify all the critical stakeholders during project initiation.
optionD: Assign one team member to one stakeholder to ensure that the responsible team member is conversant with the needs of the stakeholder.

question: In an agile environment, a project is running iteration four out of six. A team member leaves the company with no replacement.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the sponsor for an experienced team member in the company to help the project team.
optionB: Reduce the scope of the project and inform stakeholders.
optionC: Ask the team for extra work to fulfill the project commitment.
optionD: Update the issue log and refer to the resource management plan to address the situation.

question: A new team member is assigned to a team that consistently delivers each iteration. The new team member does not understand many of the processes followed and begins to negatively impact the schedule.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Allocate time within the iterations to mentor the new team member.
optionB: Assign easier activities to the new team member.
optionC: Place the new team member on a performance improvement program.
optionD: Ask another team member to take some of the new team member's work.

question: During the project planning phase, a project manager is informed that they cannot start one activity before another department implements the required IT system. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Fast track this dependency to avoid delaying the project.
optionB: Perform Integrated Change Control.
optionC: Ask IT to prioritize the needed system to meet the schedule.
optionD: Include the dependency in the project schedule.

question: A project manager is building a team to work on a service integration project that will transition technology management services from company A to company B. The project team will consist of members from both companies. Prospective team members for the project are located all over the world, have different types of technology backgrounds, and use different approaches for work.  How should the project manager build a cohesive, high-performing team?
optionA: Ask the human resources (HR) department to arrange interview meetings to select the team.
optionB: Organize the team members into several kick-off sessions based on technology type.
optionC: Ask prospective team members to write a short biography explaining how they can contribute to the team's success.
optionD: Review the list of team members skills and understand how they will work together to deliver the project outcomes.

question: A project manager is leading a project at a contracting company, and the project team just completed an iteration. The product passed inspection, but an additional feature was added to the product. The customer notices the additional feature and thinks it will introduce new risks to the product.  What should the project manager do to avoid this situation in the future?
optionA: Follow the proper change control process and evaluate the change for further impact.
optionB: Perform frequent reviews with the customer to ensure that the product is working as expected.
optionC: Manage the scope baseline to influence the factors that drive change.
optionD: Work with the customer to ensure the feature adds value.

question: A project team delivered a critical deliverable to the customer. The customer complained that the maintenance manual was not included.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Review the terms and conditions of the contract.
optionB: Submit a change request to include the manual.
optionC: Review the stakeholder engagement plan.
optionD: Add the needed manual and update the risk log.

question: A company is moving its headquarters to another city. The project manager responsible for the assignment has been using a predictive approach during the transition. However, the information systems will be migrated using an agile approach. The project manager needs to decide which kind of contract to sign with the vendor responsible for migrating the systems. The project manager is concerned about controlling finances while delivering results.  How should the project manager address this situation?
optionA: Sign a single agreement for the whole project.
optionB: Confirm payment after each project retrospective.
optionC: Negotiate payment after all project migration is completed.
optionD: Use fixed-price increments as user stories are completed.

question: A leader from project B consistently reaches out to a team member in project A for assistance. What should project A's project manager do?
optionA: Tell project A's team member to ignore project B's leader.
optionB: Talk with project B's leader to discuss possible impacts to both projects.
optionC: Allow project B's leader to continue building relationships.
optionD: Ensure project A's team member can finish the work committed to project A.

question: A risk was identified at the beginning of a project, and a response plan was established. Unforeseen consequences resulted in a higher level of risk. The project manager has an idea that could address the new risk in an efficient way, but the response is different from the original risk mitigation plan.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Submit the new response plan to the stakeholders for their review.
optionB: Obtain management approval prior to implementing the new risk response.
optionC: Implement the new response to address the risk.
optionD: Use the management reserve to mitigate the risk.

question: The testing backlog for a hybrid project has increased significantly and is becoming a bottleneck. The team has researched a tool that could resolve the bottleneck, and the project manager has been informed.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Escalate the issue with the product owner.
optionB: Reduce the testing scope of the backlog.
optionC: Add developers to remove the backlog.
optionD: Enroll team members in training on the tool.

question: A project manager has taken over a project that has been without a project manager for the last couple of weeks. The team is feeling lost and there are a few team members who are confused about the next steps and the final outcome of the project.  What should the new project manager do?
optionA: Set short-term goals in order to create a winning culture internally and praise team members for achieving them.
optionB: Ask the project sponsor to provide team members with a project direction regarding outcomes.
optionC: Avoid conflict and let the team self-organize on how they want to work on the project tasks.
optionD: Escalate the situation to the steering committee and request that more time be allotted to the project.

question: A project manager is leading a project that will be delivered using a Scrum framework. The organization has an innovative project management office (PMO) that fully supports agile and also has a very friendly procurement team. A new vendor needs to be engaged to provide more developers for a new reporting platform.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Consult the development team and engage a vendor that is recommended by them.
optionB: Use a formal approach using procurement policies, procedures, forms, and work instructions.
optionC: Consult the product owner and engage a vendor that is recommended by them.
optionD: Use an agile approach and engage a vendor that delivered well in a previous organization.

question: A project manager has been appointed to lead a project but has not previously worked with the project team members. The project manager notices that the team is a mix of senior and junior professionals.  What should the project manager do to start establishing a successful relationship?
optionA: Schedule one-on-one meetings with the project team members to coach them on how to do their work better based upon previous experience.
optionB: Start speaking with each team member separately to understand their needs and personal goals to determine a leadership style.
optionC: Establish authority in the team by setting ground rules and key performance indicators (KPIs).
optionD: Schedule a team-building activity and start meeting personally with the project team members.

question: A project manager wants to ensure that the project acceptance criteria are met for all project deliverables. What should the project manager do to accomplish this?
optionA: Create a statement of work (SOW) and ensure it remains unchanged during the project life cycle.
optionB: Include project stakeholder expectations and needs while creating project acceptance criteria.
optionC: Schedule regular meetings with project stakeholders to make sure they are satisfied.
optionD: Discuss project acceptance criteria with the project sponsor before the execution phase.

question: A project team member does not submit the project status report on time. The team member is frustrated about being required to complete the report. The team member believes that the report does not reflect the reality of the project, has too many pages, and will not be read by stakeholders.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Review the requirements of the report with the team member to redefine its purpose.
optionB: Instruct the team member to provide the report and document this in the performance review.
optionC: Reassign the report to another team member to prepare and submit it as requested.
optionD: Escalate to the team member's functional manager that the report was not submitted as requested.

question: A project manager has been assigned to a new project. There is one team member who never says anything during meetings. After meetings, however, the team member sends detailed emails with very good suggestions that help with project execution.  How should the project manager guide the team members?
optionA: Remind the team members to follow the team charter.
optionB: Arrange a team-building activity to involve all team members.
optionC: Motivate the team members to speak freely in the meeting.
optionD: Review the communications management plan with the team members.

question: The project manager of a high-risk project is concerned about a delay in the schedule that might force the project to move its go-live date. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Capture the risk in the risk register and monitor it to prevent it from becoming an issue by taking the proper response action.
optionB: Raise a change request to the change control board (CCB) to ask for funds to onboard new resources to expedite the project.
optionC: Ensure that the project meets the committed time lines as this is the core objective and purpose of the project.
optionD: Ask the sponsor to start a new project to support the existing project and help it meet the original time line.

question: A new privacy law will go into effect at the beginning of the next calendar year. The project manager realizes the project needs to be compliant with the new law.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Inform the legal department that the project scope will be updated.
optionB: Inform the product owner that the project will continue as planned.
optionC: Inform the project steering committee of this constraint.
optionD: Inform the project team and create a spike for the next iteration.

question: A key customer stakeholder asks the project team to include new tasks in the backlog and begin analyzing new requests. The customer expects results as soon as possible and pressures the team to attend noncritical meetings. The team is frustrated by this situation.  How should the project manager approach this situation?
optionA: Work with the team to receive customer directions and improve the process.
optionB: Ask the customer to work with the product owner to prioritize all requests.
optionC: Call for an internal team retrospective and create an improvement action plan.
optionD: Understand the customer's perspective and provide mentoring on agile mindsets.

question: The operations director complains to the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) about the outcome of a project's first sprint. The operations department will not be able to support a new product due to poor performance indicators. The project team facilitator asks for feedback from the project team and is informed that performance information is available in the application server log.  How should this complaint be addressed?
optionA: Request that the issue be included in the next board of directors meeting to explain all of the needs.
optionB: Add the complaint to the product backlog to be addressed in the next sprint.
optionC: Invite a member of the operations team to be part of the validation and sprint meetings.
optionD: Ask the operations director to define the acceptance criteria to make clear the delivery is correct.

question: A global petroleum crisis has affected the distribution of crude oil in the region where the construction project is underway. Materials are not being delivered on time and this phase of construction is already behind for what was initially planned.  What should the project manager do first to prevent the project from going further off track?
optionA: Propose a pause in this phase to save labor costs and asset depreciation.
optionB: Proceed with the project using management reserves to cover any delays or losses.
optionC: Establish new partnerships with other suppliers in anticipation of any delays.
optionD: Perform a risk assessment and define a risk response action plan.

question: A project manager is managing the opening of a new office overseas. At the beginning of the project, possible delays due to legal permits are raised by one stakeholder. Subject matter experts (SMEs) reassessed the concern and suggested assigning more time for this permit, and the change control board (CCB) agrees.  Which document should the project manager update first to document this change?
optionA: Schedule baseline
optionB: Scope baseline
optionC: Risk register
optionD: Cost baseline

question: After a project team has been working on a project for several months, the project is cancelled. The project sponsor is putting pressure on the project manager to perform closeout duties as fast as possible so that the project team can move on to other work. The project sponsor has instructed the team not to waste time archiving the project artifacts for the cancelled project.  How should the project manager handle this situation?
optionA: Archive the project artifacts on the project manager's local computer for future reference.
optionB: Document the project sponsor's instructions as the archived project artifacts.
optionC: Comply with the project sponsor's request to not archive the project artifacts.
optionD: Consult with the project management office (PMO) for guidance on project artifacts.

question: A project manager is newly appointed to an ongoing project that will develop a new solution using an affiliate of the company. The deploying resources will come from another entity of the company. When asked to confirm the availability of the deploying team, the deploying manager declined.  What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Refer to the project's resource management plan.
optionB: Ask the project sponsor for external resources.
optionC: Reschedule the project taking this new information into account.
optionD: Create a change request to be validated by the project sponsor.

question: A project manager works for a company that has a reputation of delivering environmentally sustainable projects. During the half- yearly review of the project, the project manager raises serious concerns with the project sponsor regarding the project's viability and success. There are some stakeholders who oppose this project on the grounds of compromising land erosion.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Request additional resources from the business unit manager due to the project's complexity.
optionB: Calculate float on the project because it has severely affected the project's major critical path.
optionC: Propose to close the project because it no longer fits the business values of the organization.
optionD: Calculate earned value (EV) because the project manager is forecasting a loss for this project in the yearly review.

question: A project manager is assigned to a project with a long time line and complex scope. The client requires a high-level, long-term plan as well as something that will work immediately, adding features to the product as the project progresses.  How should the project manager plan and deliver this project?
optionA: Plan the project with a predictive approach with a work breakdown structure (WBS) and then execute it using an agile approach to deliver value incrementally.
optionB: Plan the project with a predictive approach and a work breakdown structure (WBS) following the plan and deliver value at the end of the project.
optionC: Agree on a minimum viable product (MVP) first to be delivered immediately with the client and then release the rest of the scope at the end of the project.
optionD: Select an agile approach and manage the project according to best practices to ensure value is delivered to the client.

question: An organization is producing a product using a hybrid approach with several phases. Some of the phases are planned to be executed in predictive and some in agile. During the agile phase, the project manager notices that the team members sometimes unknowingly work on the same task.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Communicate the task assignments to the team members in a clear manner.
optionB: Confirm that the agile coach has made the task assignments clear.
optionC: Verify that the team members have made the task assignments clear.
optionD: Verify that the product owner has made the task assignments clear.

question: A project manager created a contingency plan associated with a risk. The risk was realized, but the client insists on using a new workaround instead. The requested workaround will introduce delays and require additional budget.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Request to use the management reserve to keep the schedule.
optionB: Discuss the options with the client as part of the change control process.
optionC: Proceed with the approved risk response plan.
optionD: Mitigate risks associated with the workaround to avoid project delays.

question: A project manager is leading three projects in a program focused on starting product commercialization. Once the three projects start going to market, the project manager stops attending the recurring team meetings. The program manager asks the project manager to continue attending these meetings to maintain those team touchpoints. This request does not match the project manager's expectation, since a program manager is overseeing the remaining work.  How should the project manager approach the situation?
optionA: Schedule a meeting to discuss the different perspectives and agree on a decision.
optionB: Politely inform the program manager that attending these meetings is no longer required.
optionC: Provide an answer via email recommending a division of tasks between both roles.
optionD: Attend only the program meetings where the market launch is being monitored.

question: During the execution phase of a healthcare IT project, the project manager finds one stakeholder is very difficult to communicate with and obtain feedback from on project deliverables. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Share a template with the stakeholder to receive feedback on deliverables.
optionB: Use networking skills to approach the stakeholder.
optionC: Ask the project sponsor to arrange a meeting with the stakeholder.
optionD: Update the stakeholder engagement plan for the stakeholder.

question: In an agile project that is about 45% complete, most team members are siloed and lack an understanding of each other's work. What would have most likely caused this communication breakdown?
optionA: The daily standup meetings were not consistently attended.
optionB: The weekly project status reports were not published regularly.
optionC: The sprint review meetings were not held regularly.
optionD: The project manager failed to develop a communications management plan.

question: A project manager is leading a project that is at 90% completion. One of the key stakeholders requests a certification program to be included as part of the project. Another stakeholder disagrees and informs the project team that there should be no change to the project management plan since the project is nearing completion.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Raise a change request to the change control board (CCB) and inform the project sponsor about the change.
optionB: Update the project management plan and adjust the project budget with this change request.
optionC: Ask the key stakeholder to take the lead in handling the request since they are more knowledgeable.
optionD: Request a meeting with the stakeholders and their team members to inform them about this change.

question: In a product development project, the project manager is constantly receiving complaints from stakeholders about functionalities being delivered, but not required by the business departments. The project sponsor wants to know if the project resources are being used effectively.  What should the project manager have done to avoid delivering work that is not adding value to the business?
optionA: Ask the stakeholders to document their complaints in change requests.
optionB: Define a product scope and ask the stakeholders to not deviate from it.
optionC: Encourage the product owner to meet with the stakeholders and create a product backlog based on their needs.
optionD: Document the stakeholders' needs, review them during the retrospective, and create improvement plans.

question: The project leader for an agile team has discovered that a certain team member has been struggling with an impediment that is hindering the team's progress. The project is now at risk of completing later than expected.  What should the project leader do?
optionA: Escalate the impediment and associated risks to the business sponsor.
optionB: Identify the impediment and associated risks at the daily standup.
optionC: Report the impediment to the functional manager.
optionD: Identify the impediment during the retrospective.

question: A project manager is working on a project using a hybrid approach. The project is scheduled to be completed in three more sprints. One of the team members notifies the project manager that they are leaving the company, which was approved by their functional manager.  What should the project manager do first in this situation?
optionA: Ask the functional manager for an immediate replacement for the team member.
optionB: Review the risk management plan and mitigation plan to understand the impact of this issue.
optionC: Ask the functional manager why a decision was made without consulting them.
optionD: Use soft skills to influence the team member to stay until the project is completed.

question: During the execution of a hybrid project, one developer had to be replaced. The new resource is extremely competent in quality assurance tasks, but does not have much experience in development.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Allow the team to reevaluate the tasks and determine how they should be allocated.
optionB: Request that all quality assurance tasks be allocated to the new resource.
optionC: Move the developer to another team and look for a replacement developer.
optionD: Maintain the same task allocation structure to avoid any disruption in the project team.

question: In a project steering committee meeting, a few stakeholders raise concerns that the project manager's report shows that the outcome of the project is already in the market while the project is still in development. The project manager explains that the project is being delivered in sprints and involves different releases.  What should the project manager do to avoid a reoccurrence of this scenario?
optionA: Ensure the content of the project report is clearly understood and request any necessary feedback.
optionB: Ensure that all product features are completed as per the communicated specifications before releasing to market.
optionC: Send a detailed report to each steering committee member ahead of the meeting.
optionD: Invite critical stakeholders to the daily project review meetings to ensure their full engagement and involvement.

question: A company has an existing contract to maintain and enhance a client's customer database. The company's legal department informs the project manager that a new piece of legislature requiring stricter protection of customer information might soon be signed into law. The law will require additional security features to be implemented into the database the project manager is maintaining. These features are not included in the scope of the current contract.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Update the risk register to include this issue and discuss the appropriate risk response plans with the project sponsor and client.
optionB: Ask the legal department to raise the issue in the next contract negotiation with the customer.
optionC: Seek the project sponsor's support to influence the client to amend the contract immediately.
optionD: Wait until the legal requirements are finalized so the change in scope can be concretely defined.

question: A company has decided to initiate a project to eliminate a sales channel that has been unprofitable for the past 3 years. Some members of the project team are pessimistic about the project.  What should the project manager do in this situation?
optionA: Communicate the project's impact and plans to engage the project team throughout the project.
optionB: Engage the functional managers to describe the project's impact to the team members directly.
optionC: Escalate the team's concerns and ask the project sponsor to change the team's composition.
optionD: Provide team members with specific and clear instructions on the project objectives and tasks.

question: A geographically distributed project team working on an iterative project adopts a new mode of communication following changes in health protocols. The colocated team members are finding themselves challenged with understanding verbal communication and collaboration methods.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Add collaboration tools to the communications management plan.
optionB: Allow collaboration to smooth out communication between team members.
optionC: Escalate these communication challenges to the project sponsor.
optionD: Organize a team meeting to resolve the communication challenges.

question: A project team is executing a large regulatory project comprised of a multitude of internal and external stakeholders. An initial impact analysis revealed several systems, including an enhancement to existing modules as well as new builds. After completion of the initial design workshop, the team conducted a brainstorming session to better understand the types of likely users.  Which technique will best serve this purpose?
optionA: Power user grid
optionB: Personas
optionC: Power influence grid
optionD: Salience model

question: A project with multiple teams recently transitioned from a predictive approach to agile as requested by the product owner. Midway through implementation, a team member noticed there was no technical capability to support the current business requirement; therefore, the project will need to be reworked and the issue needs to be communicated to all stakeholders.  What should the agile project lead have done to avoid this situation?
optionA: Requested the product owner's approval to add an external expert to define the acceptance criteria
optionB: Defined a clear acceptance criteria at the initiation phase and continued with the project
optionC: Assessed the technical and organizational readiness for the project and identified risks at the beginning of the first iteration
optionD: Increased the communications between the team member and the product owner

question: A company has been following a predictive approach and always waits for the preceding phase to be completed before evaluating the quality of their products. A new project manager with experience in hybrid approaches has been assigned to help increase the efficiency of the company's quality management process.  What should the new project manager do to address the process improvements?
optionA: Discuss the process improvement with the project management office (PMO) lead to update the project delivery framework.
optionB: Define a ground rule to comply with the quality standard and ask the team members to apply it.
optionC: Understand the context and interdependencies of the process from the team members and then define improvements.
optionD: Continue with the process as is, and wait until the next phase to suggest any improvements.

question: A human resources (HR) cost report was disclosed, by error, to all members of the project team. This situation generated a conflict between the team members about differences in their salaries.  What should the project manager have done to avoid this situation?
optionA: Ensured reports with significant information were not included in the communications management plan
optionB: Included noncompliance punishment measures in the communications management plan
optionC: Defined the appropriate recipients for the report in the communications management plan
optionD: Validated the information and the appropriate recipients per the communications management plan

question: A project manager is managing a project in the execution phase, which was agreed upon with the sponsor. However, the sponsor is constantly micromanaging and requesting iterations that are affecting the team's effectiveness. The sponsor indicates that as long as the project scope is not affected, these iterations are needed to simplify the project.  How should the project manager handle the situation?
optionA: Review validation and control procedures.
optionB: Perform stakeholder requirements activities.
optionC: Approach the sponsor about using an agile approach.
optionD: Discuss reducing interruptions with the sponsor.

question: A project team is experiencing conflict between two team members. Team member A feels that team member B is always talking over team member A and does not listen to any advice. Team member B is not willing to listen to feedback.  What should the project manager do to resolve the issue?
optionA: Report the performance issue to both of the team members' supervisors.
optionB: Review the ground rules for collaboration within the team.
optionC: Modify the communications management plan and resend it to the team.
optionD: Move one of the team members to a different project team.

question: A project manager is nearing completion of an automation project. One of the key stakeholders requests a meeting to discuss some new ideas that would make the project even more appealing to end users. As a result, the stakeholder suggests that the project manager does not close the project.  What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Add it to the issue log as an ongoing issue.
optionB: Review and validate the scope management plan.
optionC: Update the project charter with the new requirement.
optionD: Add a risk to the risk register.

question: During the release of an important product, a vice president for a different product line brought a valid concern to the project team, which had to be completed before the release. The vice president has not participated in other product discussions until now. This additional work resulted in a delay of the product release.  How should the project manager have handled this situation earlier in the project?
optionA: Identified the vice president as a stakeholder
optionB: Recorded the vice president's concerns in the risk register
optionC: Shared project boundaries so that everyone was aware of the scope
optionD: Escalated any dissent to top management right away

question: A project manager is working on a time and materials (T&M) project using a hybrid approach. The milestones and outcomes are defined for the first 6 months with incremental releases every month. After the first 2 months, the client communicates their dissatisfaction with the results and asks to change the course of the project. The project manager held a face-to-face meeting with the client and now has a better understanding of the newly desired milestones and outcomes.  What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Draft a contract change with the desired scope changes and send it to the client for approval.
optionB: Forward the client's request to management as a change request to get formal approval.
optionC: Finish the current monthly release as it was planned and replan for the future months.
optionD: Document the information in the meeting minutes and share it with the project stakeholders.

question: A project stakeholder has left the company. The new stakeholder is a family member of one of the team members. This stakeholder does not attend meetings. The project manager finds out that the stakeholder has been asking the family member for project updates.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Forward the project status reports.
optionB: Escalate this to the project sponsor.
optionC: Request a meeting with the stakeholder.
optionD: Design an updated status report.

question: A team member is openly criticized by others during a standup meeting for failing to complete yesterday's tasks. What should the agile coach do first to address the situation?
optionA: Avoid the discussion by referring to the team charter.
optionB: Let the discussion go on as it is important that the team is clear on priorities for the day.
optionC: Address the team members involved during the next sprint retrospective.
optionD: Emphasize the ground rules and then focus on today's activities and impediments.

question: A project manager was recently assigned to a new project that is about to start. The organization has already signed a fixed-cost contract with the customer detailing the scope and final delivery date, but the project manager has identified several internal constraints and conditions that will certainly prevent the project from being completed in the number of iterations initially planned.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Create an issue log template that will be used to identify and track impediments.
optionB: Create a schedule management plan to ensure the project meets the delivery date.
optionC: Create a contingency plan in case the project deviates from the initial plan.
optionD: Create an assumption log and map assumptions to impediments based on the impact to the project value.

question: As a project is reaching completion, the project sponsor tells the project manager to immediately close the project and to move on to another project. Which critical task should the project manager complete before closing the project?
optionA: Update and close both the risk register and issue log with the latest updates, and save them in the organization's project management information system (PMIS).
optionB: Archive all the project documents following the organization's accepted practices so the documents can be used in other future projects.
optionC: Ensure that the whole team is appropriately recognized and organize a project farewell party to celebrate the project success and closure.
optionD: Meet with the project sponsor and advise that the new project might be difficult to undertake because the current project is not yet complete.

question: A project manager is leading an integration project for a retail company. The project demands a lot of time from the stakeholders to make important business decisions. The project is critical and must be completed on time and within budget.  What should the project manager do to ensure that key stakeholders are available for this project?
optionA: Share the project schedule, milestones, and meeting agendas with the stakeholders ahead of time.
optionB: Add time reserve in the project schedule to allow extra time for the stakeholders to make decisions.
optionC: Schedule meetings with all of the stakeholders to make business decisions when needed.
optionD: Work with the available stakeholders to make business decisions and keep all unavailable stakeholders informed.

question: A recently concluded quality audit failed and came back with multiple action items. A newly appointed project manager is reviewing the project status with the team. New stakeholders have been identified, and new audit resources may have to be added to the project.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Perform stakeholder engagement.
optionB: Perform integrated change control.
optionC: Update the quality management plan.
optionD: Update the risk management plan.

question: A new agile project is starting. The project manager is asked to confirm the scope to address the concerns of one of the stakeholders.  What should the project manager use to explain the project scope?
optionA: User stories
optionB: Product backlog
optionC: Product roadmap
optionD: Business requirements document

question: A project team member is struggling to deliver an assigned task. In a team meeting, the project manager determines that there are other members on the team who have more experience with similar tasks.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask one of the more experienced team members to support the team member with the task.
optionB: Ask the experienced team members to produce a manual on how to complete the task.
optionC: Reassign the task to one of the more experienced project team members for a faster completion of the assigned task.
optionD: Inform the project management office (PMO) of the issue and request a replacement for the less experienced team member.

question: This graph describes the current performance of a project in relation to cost and schedule. What should the project manager do to bring the project back on track?
optionA: Review project schedule because the project is under budget and behind schedule.
optionB: Review project scope because the project is under budget and ahead of schedule.
optionC: Review project schedule and cost because the project is over budget and behind schedule.
optionD: Review project cost because the project is over budget and ahead of schedule.

question: A project manager is leading an agile software development project with strict deadlines. The client complained that the last deployment did not meet the acceptance criteria. The development team lead is arguing that the deployment met all specifications and has provided evidence of the client's specifications.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Schedule a meeting with all stakeholders to understand what went wrong and who should be held responsible.
optionB: Meet with the client and discuss the project deadlines.
optionC: Seek approval for more time for rework and resolve the issue.
optionD: Review the requirements traceability matrix with the team lead and the client to adequately resolve the issue.

question: A project sponsor is concerned that the scope is not being met correctly and has questioned several team members about this individually. When the project sponsor approached the project manager, the project manager realized that the issue was that the project sponsor understood the scope in a different manner than the project team.  What should the project manager do to address this issue?
optionA: Facilitate a stakeholder alignment session so that the team and project sponsor are in agreement with the deliverables.
optionB: Set up a daily standup and request that the project sponsor attend to understand the project's tasks and deliverables.
optionC: Ask the project team to compile a project scope document and obtain approval from the project sponsor.
optionD: Request that the project team change their task deliverables to reflect the project sponsor's requirements.

question: A project manager is part of a distributed team. The project team is using a product backlog, but due to an excessive workload, the backlog items are not very detailed. In the retrospective, a couple of new team members are raising the issue of knowledge transfer inside the team.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Organize knowledge-sharing workshops and ask one of the senior team members to facilitate them.
optionB: Hire a technical writer to document the work completed to date and develop a handover document.
optionC: Ensure that formal email communication is used when more information is needed to understand the work done.
optionD: Ask the team to outline their expectations and confirm with them the approach to use for knowledge transfer.

question: The sponsor approaches the project manager with new features they want added to the project. The project is 95% complete, but the sponsor insists that continued support for the project relies on the addition of the new features.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Implement the new features after assessing the impact.
optionB: Reject the new features since it amounts to gold plating.
optionC: Assess the impact of the features and refer it to the change control board (CCB).
optionD: Add the new features to avoid losing the sponsor's support for the project.

question: A project manager has been moved to a new division and is in charge of an existing project in an unfamiliar domain. When attempting to gain an understanding of the risks for this agile project, what is the primary tool the project manager should employ?
optionA: Workshops for risk avoidance
optionB: Probability assessments
optionC: Collaborative discussions
optionD: Interview with the project champion

question: A new project manager has been assigned to an environmental project. After reviewing the project plan, the project manager notices that health and safety requirements have not been properly addressed. This is a serious concern, and the project manager wants to fix this issue immediately.  Why is this situation problematic?
optionA: It is imperative that established performance metrics are met.
optionB: Injury or loss incidents could delay project deliverables.
optionC: The project manager must follow their employer's organizational process assets (OPAs).
optionD: The project manager is obligated to comply with the project location's regulatory requirements.

question: A new major project is starting that consists of two interconnected subprojects. One of the subprojects was assigned to a contractor who commits to submitting biweekly status reports and attending weekly integration meetings. Halfway through the project, the contractor stops participating in the meetings and does not submit the reports. Their excuse is that these activities are consuming too much time.  How should the project manager handle this situation?
optionA: Assess the situation as a risk and reach out to the contractor to check the origin of this resistance.
optionB: File a claim for not fulfilling the contract terms in accordance with alternative dispute resolution.
optionC: Remind the contractor to join the meetings and submit their report as this is their commitment.
optionD: Compromise with the contractor to only attend the weekly meetings without submitting the reports.

question: In the middle of an iteration, the product owner tells the agile team that the government has updated legal requirements. This will result in some changes in the product definition.  How should the project manager handle this situation?
optionA: Continue work and ask the product owner to assess the changes and add/remove the stories as needed in the backlog.
optionB: Ask the product owner to add new changes to the bottom of the backlog in order to handle the modifications as a change request.
optionC: Review the iteration backlog because the product definition has changed and needs to be reassessed before continuing the project.
optionD: Ask a business analyst to assess the changes and then add/remove the stories in the backlog and prioritize them by business value.

question: A project manager has just taken over a project that is in the requirements gathering phase. A stakeholder indicates that they have not received any progress updates even though reports have been sent on a weekly basis.  What should the project manager do to ensure all stakeholders are receiving proper information about the project?
optionA: Hold a steering committee meeting with all stakeholders to provide a comprehensive update on the project progress.
optionB: Create daily progress reports and send them to all stakeholders.
optionC: Assess all of the project stakeholders and document their preferred communication method and frequency.
optionD: Include stakeholders in the weekly status meetings with the team.

question: A project manager is managing a new development program to automate some technical functions. During project kickoff, the project manager expresses the need for a technical architect to support the project for a moderate amount of time. The project sponsor informs the project manager about an existing technical architect who possesses valuable knowledge but is already assigned at the portfolio level.  What engagement model should the project manager use for the technical architect role to ensure project success?
optionA: Share the existing technical architect so they can be allocated to the current project and other projects.
optionB: Hire a new technical architect who would be solely dedicated to the current project.
optionC: Hire a new technical architect who would be shared between the current project and other projects.
optionD: Assign the existing technical architect to solely be dedicated to the current project.

question: A project manager has recently joined a small company. The company's chief operating officer (COO) asked the team to skip some steps in the process in order to work more quickly. The project manager wants to ensure that these steps are not skipped in the future.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Redesign the process so the team can move more quickly.
optionB: Notify all team members that all steps in the process must be completed.
optionC: Schedule a review of the process steps with the team and the COO.
optionD: Escalate the issue to the other executive leadership members.

question: A project manager is assigned to deliver a development project with subcontracted resources from a sister company. What should the project manager do to ensure a smooth inclusion of the new subcontracted resources?
optionA: Share the project team ground rules with the subcontractors.
optionB: Schedule a formal meeting to cover the mission and vision.
optionC: Organize a team-bonding exercise with the subcontractors.
optionD: Facilitate a working session to review the ground rules.

question: According to the project contract, the delivery date is approaching. However, one important material is still not on site. The construction work will have to stop and wait for this special material, delaying the project.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Engage the project team to look for alternatives to find a solution.
optionB: Record it in the risk register.
optionC: Ask the client to help solve the problem.
optionD: Start procuring this material from another supplier.

question: A project manager is reviewing the lessons learned for an historical project. The review identifies that the client's engineer was adamant that they review all changes, even those not identified in the contract.  How should the project manager deal with this when planning the project?
optionA: Update the project charter with this information regarding change management.
optionB: Talk with the client to ensure they are aware of the change management procedure.
optionC: Ensure the change management plan highlights this requirement to prevent future issues.
optionD: Update the project risk register to identify this risk and describe how to mitigate the issue.

question: A project manager is assigned to a large construction project with more than 100 project team members. The project manager is having a hard time keeping the project on track and deriving the planned benefits. The project manager wants to make sure that each requirement is linked to the business and project objective.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Understand the project management plan.
optionB: Review the requirements on a weekly basis.
optionC: Implement a requirements traceability matrix.
optionD: Add the requirements to the project charter.

question: While managing a project using a hybrid approach, the project manager realizes that there is a high level of rework due to quality issues. Because of that, each feature is taking longer than initially estimated.  What should the project manager do to address the issue?
optionA: Address the issue during the next sprint planning meeting.
optionB: Extend the dates for future project milestones.
optionC: Initiate a change request to extend the project end date.
optionD: Escalate the issue to the project sponsor.

question: A project manager has been authorized to begin a project and realizes that an effective high-performing team is needed to finish the project successfully. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Set performance standards and direction.
optionB: Hold early kick-off meetings and regular weekly meetings.
optionC: Select members for their skill or potential.
optionD: Establish the project scope and set clear team objectives.

question: A project manager has been assigned to a high-visibility project that has been identified as having medium complexity, based on previous similar projects. The project needs to be delivered to the customer as a ready-to-use product.  Based on this scenario, what should the project manager focus on throughout the project life cycle?
optionA: Stakeholder engagement and lessons learned
optionB: Resource management and lessons learned
optionC: Time management and stakeholder engagement
optionD: Cost management and risk management

question: An organization imports many of the materials for a product build. Due to global shipping delays, some of the essential materials have yet to arrive, resulting in the inability to finish building the product for the upcoming release. The project manager is meeting with stakeholders to discuss options.  What should the project manager recommend?
optionA: Request marketing to launch an advertising campaign for the product that is currently in stock.
optionB: Update the project management plan, factoring in furloughs of the assembly team to reduce expenses.
optionC: Meet with the engineering team to manufacture the materials in-house.
optionD: Explore if the materials could be supplied locally and obtained on time.

question: During the first project meeting with a new project manager, a stakeholder complains about not receiving periodic reports. What should the project manager do first?
optionA: Update the project management plan with the new information and inform all of the relevant stakeholders.
optionB: Meet with the stakeholder to better understand their expectations and update the stakeholder engagement plan.
optionC: Invite the stakeholder to all future project review meetings and update the project management plan.
optionD: Add the stakeholder details into the periodic reports and update the project management plan.

question: A project manager arranged a team-building activity to build and maintain teamwork, trust, and commitment due to internal team conflicts. Two months after completing the training, another situation is causing new delays in the project.  What should the project manager do to address this concern?
optionA: Ask human resources (HR) to coordinate another activity.
optionB: Inform HR about the situation and ask for support.
optionC: Meet with the team to explain that conflicts must be addressed and solved.
optionD: Reassess the team situation and provide a proper solution.

question: A project manager has been managing an agile project for 6 months. Over the last two iterations, the team velocity has decreased due to a new technology that was needed for the product.  What should the project manager do to continue with the delivery plan and return to the expected velocity?
optionA: Seek sponsor approval for additional funding to hire new team members, increasing the capacity of the team and compensating for the productivity lost with the new technology.
optionB: Replace poorly performing team members with more experienced members, setting an example of accountability for the team.
optionC: Use retrospectives to better understand the new technology's impact on the schedule, map the skill gaps, and adjust the team accordingly.
optionD: Reevaluate the backlog by looking for high-value/low-effort items, and negotiate a new minimum viable product (MVP) strategy with key stakeholders.

question: During the execution of a project to develop a prototype, the customer asks the project manager to stop the prototype line and purge a specific component based on recent reliability tests that have deemed the component to be deficient. The project manager checked the quality management plan and there is no reference to this component.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Call a technical meeting with the customer to agree on a specification for the component and document it in the quality management plan.
optionB: Keep running the manufacturing line because there are no quality specifications for this component.
optionC: Inform the project sponsor of the situation and wait for the sponsor to provide further directions.
optionD: Submit a change request to proceed with the replacement of the component and wait for further customer instructions.

question: During the setup of an agile project, the product owner expressed clear interest in having features released during product development over having the product completed in one year. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Facilitate sprint planning sessions with a focus on defining the minimum viable product (MVP).
optionB: Design a set of metrics including velocity, which is a good measure of value delivered.
optionC: Promote a productive environment where everybody can work without interruptions from the rest of the team members.
optionD: Create a reward system recognizing group contributions to get people motivated and improve performance.

question: During a meeting to define project scope a stakeholder tells the project manager that the main requested feature in the contract is not applicable, and this is documented in the lessons learned. What should the project manager do?
optionA: Ask the sponsor to close the project and pay the contracted penalty.
optionB: Meet with the sponsor to ask for their support.
optionC: Check with the team to learn what can be done, and consult an expert.
optionD: Check that this information was documented correctly.

question: A lead project manager for an agile project needs to prioritize requirements, define the scope of the initial product, and deliver the approved scope in a series of multiple versions. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Determine the expected benefits of each requirement to maximize the overall business value.
optionB: Ask the lead developer to run a meeting with the stakeholders to agree on an ordered list.
optionC: Work with the product owner to evaluate and prioritize the requirements.
optionD: Prioritize the requirements based on the hierarchical level of the requesting stakeholders.

question: A defect is identified during user acceptance testing that could significantly impact the system's performance. The project team has advised that this defect puts the delivery date at risk.  Which risk management process should be performed?
optionA: Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis, to assess the extent of the system performance impact
optionB: Monitor Risks, to install system performance monitoring tools and update the risk register
optionC: Plan Risk Responses, to outline the possible options to bypass the system performance issue
optionD: Perform Quantitative Risk Analysis, to outline the details of the system performance issues

question: At the start of a project, the sponsor declares that demonstrating benefits from the product will be extremely important. The project sponsor calls a meeting with the project manager and the project leadership team to discuss the best approach because the project has a high degree of uncertainty and many changes are expected.  What should the project manager propose?
optionA: Develop requirements and designs to support a faster product release.
optionB: Outsource development of the product to a third party with more experience.
optionC: Recommend an agile approach so the project can be delivered iteratively.
optionD: Emphasize the adoption of a predictive approach to minimize ambiguity.

question: A functional manager is concerned that the project's quality management techniques have advanced beyond the department's capabilities and wants the project team to review all quality management activities in two full-day workshops the following week. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Indicate that this was a not a requirement identified during project planning and it is outside of the scope.
optionB: Draft a project decision request to include in the scope for the current iteration and ask the sponsor to approve.
optionC: Explain that the team is fully dedicated to the current sprint activities and negotiate a mutually agreeable time.
optionD: Add this to the project backlog and have the product owner determine where it fits in terms of priority.

question: A project manager is assigned to a dental equipment development project that is in the middle of its design phase. After reviewing the project prototype, it is identified that a couple of requirements specifications are missing.  Which action should the project manager take next?
optionA: Ask the team to wait until they are able to update the requirements specifications.
optionB: Discuss with the team and build a workaround plan to immediately deliver the pending requirements specifications.
optionC: Meet with the development team to review and assess the requirements specifications.
optionD: Prepare a change request for the change control board (CCB) to remove the missing requirements specifications.

question: A customer discovered quality issues with the latest deliverables. However, the project team immediately resolved the issues.  Now that the project is back on track, what should the project manager do next?
optionA: Perform lessons learned to ensure the issue does not happen again.
optionB: Reassess the risk log to ensure it is up to date.
optionC: Schedule a team meeting to review the issue.
optionD: Monitor quality metrics to ensure the project continues as planned.

question: A project manager uses a laissez-faire leadership style with a newly hired project team. The project manager quickly notices that team members are underperforming, the schedule is delayed, and the project is overbudget.  What should the project manager have done at the start of the project?
optionA: Managed the team as necessary and allowed them to work on their own
optionB: Adapted a direct management style according to the project team's needs
optionC: Established goals and provided the project team with sufficient authority to work
optionD: Adapted a servant leader management style to support the team's development

question: A project stakeholder has expressed concern that the established success criteria for the project are not being met. What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Document the agreed-upon ownership of benefits realization.
optionB: Review the established project benefits tracking metrics.
optionC: Create a project benefits management plan.
optionD: Update the project business case document.

question: A project team member informs the project manager that a stakeholder is contacting the team member to request status updates. The team member is being distracted by these repeated requests, which are interfering with the completion of assigned tasks.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Review this stakeholder's communication requirements.
optionB: Inform the team member to stop sending any further updates to the stakeholder.
optionC: Increase the frequency of updates given to this stakeholder.
optionD: Raise this issue to the project sponsor in the next project status review meeting.

question: A project selection committee is shortlisting projects for the coming year. Which selection criteria should the project manager recommend?
optionA: Projects with the least associated risks
optionB: Projects with maximum revenue generation
optionC: Projects with the least duration
optionD: Projects that maximize the business value

question: An agile project manager has started working in a company that builds shopping centers. The project manager wants to implement some agile practices, which are relevant to the project.  What should the project manager do to gain buy-in from the different stakeholders?
optionA: Send the project management plan, which includes the suggested agile practices, to the stakeholders.
optionB: Organize a meeting with relevant stakeholders explaining the benefits of agile and the practices relevant for the project.
optionC: Ask the project management office (PMO) to get buy-in from the stakeholders because agile is an approach that differs from their previous ways of working.
optionD: Organize a meeting with a consultant to provide training to the stakeholders on agile practices.

question: A project manager is managing a project which is approaching the end of the execution phase. A high-level stakeholder informs the project manager that a very important requirement was not included in the scope of the project, and that without that requirement the project will deliver no value.  What is the first thing the project manager should do?
optionA: Inform the stakeholder that it is impossible to add new requirements to an approved project scope.
optionB: Include the requirement into the project and schedule it as soon as possible.
optionC: Inform the project sponsor about the situation and request assistance.
optionD: Evaluate the impact that the inclusion of this new requirement will have on project performance.

question: A supplier informs the project manager that producing the quantity of a key component for the project will require an additional month. The project manager has to meet an important milestone in a week.  What should the project manager do next?
optionA: Perform market research to find out if there are other vendors that can produce similar kinds of materials.
optionB: Submit a change request to the change control board (CCB) asking to extend the deadline in order to reflect the late delivery.
optionC: Involve the legal department, as the vendor is breaching the contract by not delivering the full amount in time.
optionD: Ask the vendor if the minimally sufficient materials can be produced in time to meet the deadline.

question: Multiple agile teams are working on a product deliverable. During the last few iterations, one of the teams received several unplanned, nonproduction support requests from other teams. This affected the velocity of the team and the planned deliverable.  What should the project manager do in this situation?
optionA: Tell the team to extend and complete the planned deliverable as well as incoming requests.
optionB: Ask the team to accommodate most of the requests in each of the iterations.
optionC: Inform members of the other teams to add these requests directly in the iteration backlog.
optionD: Direct the team to only focus on the planned deliverable and not take on any unplanned activity.

question: A project manager determines that a critical path activity is going to be delayed. The team proposes a fallback plan that could get the project back on track; however, the plan would require an additional cost to an already tight budget.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Add additional resources to the project to fast track certain activities and reduce delays.
optionB: Communicate the delay to stakeholders and maintain the existing budget baseline.
optionC: Evaluate the fallback plan proposed by the team and submit a change request, if required.
optionD: Use the existing budget for executing the fallback plan and update the baseline.

question: A project manager has taken over an existing project. According to the previous project manager, the project is on track and within budget. However, stakeholders are unhappy with the recent progress report since the metrics show that the project is delayed and the cost is higher than expected.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Schedule a meeting with the previous project manager.
optionB: Submit a change request to the change control board (CCB).
optionC: Schedule training for project team members.
optionD: Conduct an earned value analysis (EVA).

question: A project manager is leading a project that has been in execution for 1 year. An experienced team member is performing well, but often disagrees with the project manager and refuses to implement their decisions. Part of the team supports the team member's defiance, while the other team members do not.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Conduct a performance review and define and document the goals for the team member.
optionB: Remove existing ground rules and create new ground rules that support the project manager.
optionC: Clarify decisions and request that the project team follows the project manager's decisions.
optionD: Understand what the team member wants and find possible opportunities to address it.

question: A project manager is working on a large project in another country and realizes that only a few people from the project team are working on all of the releases. What should the project manager do to prevent this in the future?
optionA: Speak to the customer and add the issue to the issue log.
optionB: Document the risk register in the project charter.
optionC: Review user roles and update the team charter.
optionD: Involve the product owner to rewrite the user stories.

question: During the executing phase, a project manager is reviewing the issue log and finds there are outstanding high-priority issues that are still open. Most of the open issues require effort from external domain experts who are not on the project team.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Request that the project team members learn the required domain knowledge and resolve the open issues in a short time.
optionB: Review the open issues with the issue reporter and issue a change request to hire an external domain expert.
optionC: Ask the issue reporter to close the issues, because there are no project team members who have the required domain knowledge.
optionD: Reduce the project scope to ensure that the project team has the knowledge to deliver the system on schedule.

question: A project manager in one country is reporting to a lead project manager for a new software development project in another country. The lead project manager constantly requests updates from the project manager, often demanding information via multiple communication channels if the project manager does not respond within a few minutes of a request. Both of them are equal in seniority and both report to the same functional manager.  How should the project manager proceed?
optionA: Refer the lead project manager to the communications management plan.
optionB: Negotiate a mutually agreeable feedback cycle with acceptable timelines.
optionC: Update the communications management plan and the stakeholder engagement plan.
optionD: Escalate the issue to the functional manager and explain the situation to them.

question: A project manager and project team have brought a project back on track after mapping and removing impediments. During the current sprint, the team reported that an impediment that previously caused major delays has appeared again. The team tried implementing the same mitigation tasks that worked previously. However, the tasks are not having the same result with the impediment.  What should the project manager do?
optionA: Escalate the issue with an impediment to the project sponsor.
optionB: Implement the mitigation plans listed in the organizational process assets (OPAs).
optionC: Use the contingency budget to implement schedule compression.
optionD: Reassess the issue as part of monitoring and controlling.

question: Within a project, senior management is requesting project information so they can analyze the data to make project decisions. What information should the project manager provide so that senior management can get a broader view of the project?
optionA: Higher-level activities completed
optionB: Milestones status report
optionC: Risk register information
optionD: Resource breakdown structure (RBS)

question: A project manager finds an unexpected issue halfway through a customer's project. After analysis, the project team determines that the issue will affect the timeline unless more resources are allocated to the project.  What should the project manager do?
